item.title: Tottenham show off first sections of retractable NFL pitch being laid as race to finish 62,000-seater stadium in time for new season continues
item.description: Tottenham's new 62,000-seater stadium took another giant step towards completion as work continued in laying the retractable NFL pitch ahead of the new season.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham's new stadium took another giant step towards completion as work continued in laying the retractable NFL pitch.

The pristine green surface has started to light up the north London club's new 62,062-seater stadium.

Tottenham's new stadium has been hailed as one of the country's most revolutionary to date and part of the design includes the retractable pitch to cater for both football games and NFL matches.Â 


The football pitch will be rolled out in three sections to overlay the NFL turf with the first American football match pencilled in for October 14Â when the Seattle Seahawks play the Oakland Raiders.

That is part of the ten-year agreement between Spurs and the NFL and it will come as welcome relief to those across the Atlantic to see the turf begin to be laid.Â 

Pictures of the ongoing construction shows four big screens have been put in place in each corner of the ground, while an LED lighting display hugs the exterior of the new arena.

Lettering on the outside of the new stadium was a landmark moment the club shared on Monday as the personal touches to the club take hold.Â 

Mauricio Pochettino will wait with interest for the announcement of Premier League fixtures on June 14 as he will then discover where Tottenham will begin the 2018-19 campaign.

It is hoped the stadium will be complete and ready for the start of August but they may request to play the first month of games away from home in a bid to tie up loose ends.Â 

Liverpool placed a similar request as they redeveloped their main stand and wanted to switch a fixture from home to away.Â

item.title: 'I really hope he can stay - we don't want our best players leaving': Former Celtic skipper Tom Boyd urges Stuart Armstrong to stay at the club
item.description: Stuart Armstrong appears to encounter more forks in the road these days than a rally driver. He signed an improved two-year deal to stay at Celtic this time last year but is now linked with a move away from Celtic.
item.content:encoded:
Stuart Armstrong appears to encounter more forks in the road these days than a rally driver.

In signing an improved two-year improved deal to stay at Celtic this time last year, the midfielder was never going to swerve speculation about his future for too long.

About to enter the final year of his contract again, the 26-year-old knows well how it works. Either he joins the likes of Tom Rogic and Kristoffer Ajer in committing to the club for the best years of his life. Or else it will protect its position by listening to all reasonable offers.


Brighton and West Brom, his main potential suitors, have the capacity to offer him remuneration likely to be beyond Celtic's reach.

For former Celtic skipper Tom Boyd, though, the player's choice is becoming abundantly clear.

'What do you want to be as a player?' he asked. 'Do you want to be a winner? Or do you want to just earn good money?

'I really hope Stuart can stay at Celtic. We don't want our best players leaving.

'I know in the grand scheme of things there's a big gap between the Scottish Premiership and the English Premiership. And he clearly has a decision to make.

'But I don't want to see Stuart go. Hopefully we can get him to stay - a five year contract would be nice.

'I think he's a happy man at Celtic. He'll win things there.' His medal haul to date isn't too shabby, though. Four titles, two Scottish Cups, two League Cups - have all been attained in three-and-a-half years.

Perhaps, for Celtic, therein lies the problem. Success may not have come easy to the former Dundee United player but he's enjoyed it so quickly and to such an extent that he might feel the need for a challenge elsewhere.

And if it comes to pass that the player and his current paymasters come to an amicable agreement, shake hands and move on, Boyd feels the depth of the squad he'd leave behind would cope.

'Celtic are well covered in the midfield areas,' he said. 'If something was to happen, that Stuart decides to leave, then we've certainly got a lot of other options.

'We've got good players in there; (Callum) McGregor and (Tom) Rogic - similarly attack minded boys.

'But, we don't want a player like that to leave and what he brings to the football club. He's got great drive and ability and we'd rather see him here.

'At the moment, where it lies, if somebody was to come in and make a good offer then there needs to be serious consideration.

'But he's still a Celtic player and hopefully he will stay a Celtic player.' Brendan Rodgers could certainly do with Armstrong remaining on board at least for the duration of the Champions League qualifiers.

Set to face the first of four hurdles on July 10/11, the Celtic manager faces an appreciably tougher task to take his side into the group stages than in the past two years.

'There's so much against Celtic in terms of qualifying,' Boyd offered.

'They've now got four rounds to overcome and that's a massive ask.

'Hopefully they do well. But we need all of the other Scottish clubs to get better. It helps the coefficient. Ultimately, that can stop Celtic from having to play four qualifying rounds.

'We need Scottish football to get better and I think the signs are there we can.' With Steven Gerrard in at Rangers, Alan Stubbs the new manager of St Mirren, and Neil Lennon, Steve Clarke and Derek McInnes remaining in charge at Hibs, Kilmarnock and Aberdeen, Boyd envisages the forthcoming domestic campaign being compelling.

'The competition in the league is improving,' he said. 'I know Celtic are still the strongest side but things are getting better.

'The Steven Gerrard factor is unknown at the moment. Hearts should also be better. Hibs did ever so well last year.

'So we hope Scottish football can keep on the rise and get the country back on the map in terms of Europe.

'We've seen it so many times in recent years, clubs being knocked out in the first round of qualifiers; clubs from countries like Estonia and even last year, Luxembourg.

'To get better, to stop us having so many qualifiers, we need to achieve better results. It means everybody - it can't just be one team delivering.'Â

item.title: Manchester United target Justin Kluivert signs for Roma in Â£16m deal to end hope of a Premier League move
item.description: Kluivert, who was heavily linked with a transfer to Manchester United, has reportedly made the move from Ajax to last season's Champions League semi-finalists for Â£15.85m.
item.content:encoded:
Justin Kluivert has turned down a chance to move to the Premier League after securing a deal to join Roma.

Kluivert, who was heavily linked with a transfer to Manchester United, has made the move from Ajax to last season'sÂ Champions League semi-finalists for Â£15.85m.

The 19-year-old was greeted by roughly 500 Roma fans at Fiumicino Airport on Monday evening. The club announced the news on theirÂ Twitter account.

Scroll down for videoÂ 


He will complete a medical at Roma's training facility on Tuesday before being unveiled to the club's fans at the Stadio Olimpico.

Kluivert, who is one of three sons belonging to former Ajax legend Patrick, has been on the radar of a number of Europe's top clubs for the last two seasons.

Last season he performed well for Ajax, scoring ten goals and providing assists.

His father Patrick spoke as recently as last weekend about wanting his son to stay in Holland to continue his development.

'I personally said to him maybe it's better to stay one more year at Ajax, to make some kilometres, to be important for the team,' Kluivert told ESPN.

'He's 19 years old. He's still young, but he makes his own decisions, and as a dad, I have to stand behind all the decisions that he makes.

'It looks like he's going to leave Ajax. I think it's 90 per cent sure that he's going away.'

The move to Roma is a blow to United boss Jose Mourinho. Mourinho, a known admirer of Kluivert, had been interested in signing the youngster.

Mourinho was pictured giving him a hug after the Europa League final in which United beat Ajax 2-0 in Stockholm. Â But a move to the Theatre of Dreams will, for now at least, not happen.

item.description: The 22-year-old Uruguay international has emerged as a preferred option for Unai Emery who wants a defensive midfielder brought in as part of his summer recruitment plan.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal remain in talks with Sampdoria over the proposed Â£22million transfer of Lucas Torreira.

The 22-year-old Uruguay international has emerged as a preferred option for Unai Emery who wants a defensive midfielder brought in as part of his summer recruitment plan.

Torreira has a buy out clause but it's understood Arsenal may need to pay in instalments as they look to make the most of their relatively limited budget this window.


Massimo Ferrero, the Sampdoria president said: 'Lucas Torreira has a release clause. Everyone knows it. Whoever wants to take Torreira will have to work with that release clause; â‚¬25m.'

Arsenal have signed Stephan Lichtsteiner on a free and have agreed a deal worth around Â£16m with Borussia Dortmund for Sokratis Papastathopoulos which is expected to be confirmed next month.

They also have an interest in Sporting Lisbon winger Gelson Martins and have discussed a potential bid for Caglar Soyuncu at Freiburg.Â

item.title: 'I couldn't have hoped for a better opportunity': Manchester City assistant coach Domenec Torrent leaves to manage New York City FC
item.description: Manchester City assistant manager Domenec Torrent has left his position at the Etihad Stadium to become New York City FC's new manager following Patrick Vieira's move to Ligue 1 side Nice.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City assistant manager Domenec Torrent has left his position at the Etihad Stadium to become New York City FC's new manager.

Torrent, who also worked with Pep Guardiola at Barcelona and Bayern Munich, replaces Patrick Vieira in charge of City's sister club in Major League Soccer following the Frenchman's move to Nice.

'Though I have enjoyed a wonderful 11 years working alongside my colleague and close friend Pep Guardiola - it has always been my ambition to manage a team again and I really couldn't have hoped for a better opportunity than at this football club,' Torrent said on NYCFC's official website.


'I know we have a very talented team, I have watched many of the matches and I enjoy the way the team plays and I now can't wait to begin working with the players on the training pitch.

'Though I have been fortunate enough to visit New York on numerous occasions, I am looking forward to living and coaching in this special city and meeting the fans as soon as possible. I am eager to experience and play a part in the soccer culture of New York.

'I'd like to thank the players and all my colleagues at Manchester City for making my time at the football club such a wonderful and memorable experience.'

Torrent has been Guardiola's assistant for the last 11 years and has helped win 24 trophies at Barcelona, Bayern and City, most recently the record-breaking Premier League title.

item.title: Dean Henderson on verge of sealing new Manchester United contract amid Arsenal and Chelsea interest
item.description: The 21-year-old keeper is set to sign an initial two-year extension at Old Trafford that includes the option for a further 12 months. He will also spend next season on loan in the Championship.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have won their battle to keep young goalkeeper Dean Henderson at Old Trafford, as the Englishman is set to sign a new three-year deal at the club.

Henderson, an England U21 international, spent last season on loan at League One Shrewsbury and was one of the stars of their promotion push, with the club eventually defeated in the play-off final. He kept 19 clean sheets and was named in the PFA League One Team of the Year.

Henderson, whose existing contract expires this summer, had attracted interest from Premier League clubs including Chelsea and Arsenal, while Benfica, Roma and Olympiacos also had scouting reports on the 21-year-old goalkeeper.


However, United are now on the brink of sealing a new contract for Henderson, with the goalkeeper expected to sign an initial two-year deal that will also give United the option of a one-year extension.

Henderson, who is keen to play first-team football to continue his development, will then be loaned out to a Championship club next season.Â 

Stoke have been monitoring Henderson in the eventuality that Jack Butland leaves the club, while Leeds United and Bristol City are also among his admirers.

item.title: Chelsea supporters pose with players as club announce new Â£10m-a-year sleeve sponsorship deal with Hyundai
item.description: The glossy shot of a player posing in a club shirt - whether as a new signing, to promote a new sponsor or for any reason - has become a staple of modern Premier League football.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea have secured the most lucrative shirt-sleeve deal in the Premier League after revealing Hyundai as their new Â£40million sponsor.

And two Chelsea fans got to join their heroes in a photoshoot unveiling the new kit.

The South Korean car manufacturers are spending Â£10m per season to have their logo printed on the players' sleeves in domestic games, starting from next season.


Chelsea already rake in Â£40m a year from main shirt sponsors Yokohama Rubber and a further Â£60m from kit-makers Nike.

But the Â£40m total from Hyundai outstrips any Premier League rivals when it comes to advertising on shirt sleeves, which was first introduced last summer.

Arsenal recently penned a Â£30m, three-year deal with Visit Rwanda, while Manchester United are understood to be close to a similar agreement with American kitchen and bathroom firm Kohler.

Chelsea will wear their new shirts, complete with sleeve sponsors, for the first time on July 23 when they face Perth Glory in a friendly in Australia.

While they have their sponsors sorted however, Chelsea are still uncertain about the future of their manager, Antonio Conte.

The Blues have been stuck in limbo as they wait to see whether lawyers acting on behalf of Maurizio Sarri can get him out of his contract stand-off with Napoli.Â 

As it stands, Conte remains in charge, although his players do not expect him to be there for the start of the 2018-19 season.Â

item.title: Gareth Southgate excited to get England's World Cup campaign started... as referee Martin Atkinson hits out at lack of Premier League officials in Russia
item.description: Southgate is ready to get England's World Cup campaign started ahead of their departure. The Three Lions leave for Russia on Tuesday before next Monday's Group G opener against Tunisia.
item.content:encoded:
Gareth Southgate is ready to get England's World Cup campaign started ahead of their departure.

The Three Lions leave for Russia on Tuesday before next Monday's Group G opener against Tunisia in Volgograd.

They also face Panama in Nizhny Novgorod on June 24 and Belgium in Kaliningrad four days later.


'We're pleased with how preparation has gone up until now, we fly out tomorrow so it'll be good to get on with it now,' said Southgate. 'Everybody is looking forward to getting to the first game.'

Southgate was speaking as he waved off Martin Atkinson from St George's Park ahead of the Premier League referee's charity bike ride to Russia.

He is aiming to raise Â£60,000 for the Jane Tomlinson Appeal, Yorkshire Young Achievers, St David's Hospice Care in Newport and the University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire Charity.

Atkinson is planning to reach Kaliningrad for England's final group game against Belgium on June 28.

'Our journey might get just as hard as theirs as we go along,' said Southgate. 'He's a nutter, but we knew that anyway.

'It's fantastic they are raising money for really good causes. It's going to be a grueling adventure but we're very proud of what they are all doing.'

Premier League referee Atkinson insists British officials have shown their quality in recent years, despite missing out on this summer's World Cup.

The 2018 global showpiece gets under way in Russia on Thursday, and for the first time since 1938 the tournament will feature no home nation referees.

Mark Clattenburg was the only Briton on FIFA's long list of candidates in 2016 but lost his place when he quit the Premier League in 2017 to become Saudi Arabia's new head of referees.

Clattenburg took charge of the Euro 2016 final while Howard Webb officiated Spain's World Cup final win over Holland in 2010.

Atkinson said: 'When you look at the last eight years, what we have achieved as a group of match officials is untouchable. The World Cup final, the Champions League final, Olympic final, Europa League final - we have all contributed.

'Unfortunately, circumstances change and we haven't got anyone there now. That's not due to the ability of the referees at all.'Â

item.title: PSG step up chase for N'Golo Kante as sporting director Antero Henrique 'meets with agent in London and Paris'
item.description: According to Paris United, Thomas Tuchel's PSG are looking to strengthen their midfield for a Champions League run after also meeting with the entourage of Julian Weigl in April.
item.content:encoded:
Paris Saint-Germain are continuing their long-running pursuit of N'Golo Kante, with the latest reports suggesting that sporting directorÂ Antero Henrique has met with the Chelsea midfielder's agent in London and Paris over recent weeks in order to discover his future intentions.

That is according to Paris United, who claim Kante's official representative - Karim Douis - and part of his entourage are keen for him to sign for PSG and that the formerÂ Boulogne and Caen man, also on the radar of reigning European champions Real Madrid, is no longer completely dismissive of a potential return to his native France.

The report goes on to state that Chelsea, looking to restructure their midfield as they keep an eye on the likes of Amiens' Tanguy Ndombele, Napoli'sÂ Amadou Diawara and Jean Michael Seri of Nice, would look to receive around â‚¬80million (Â£70.3million) for a player they signed from Leicester City in aÂ Â£30m deal back in July 2016.


Prominent agentÂ Pini Zahavi, who was involved in Neymar's world-record move to the Parc des Princes from Barcelona last year, is said to have a key role in any potential deal, particularly in terms of sourcing an adequate replacement for Chelsea.Â 

Links between PSG, also pursuingÂ Julian Weigl following the appointment of former Borussia Dortmund boss Thomas Tuchel, and Kante are certainly nothing new and last month the 27-year-old insisted he had not received any approaches from interested parties while reiterating that he was only focused on the World Cup in Russia.

However, it has been claimed that many of Chelsea's FA Cup-winning stars have become concerned by the delay in tying down a replacement for Antonio Conte, who is still expected to leave Stamford Bridge this summer following a woeful defence of the title he claimed in his maiden season at the helm.

Just as he was during Leicester's shock title success in 2016 with his sheer energy, incredible work rate, tackling prowess and combativeness, Kante was a crucial figure in that Chelsea triumph and subsequently received several high-profile individual honours including the PFA Player of the Year award.

He has made a total of 89 appearances across all competitions for the Blues in two seasons, including 48 last term as they not only failed to defend their crown but also missed out on a place in the top four.Â 

Kante will be a key cog of France's star-studded midfield as they aim to banish memories of their painful Euro 2016 final defeat on home soil and Les Bleus head coach Didier Deschamps reportedly made it expressly clear that he wanted all transfer business involving his players to be completed by the weekend before the tournament gets underway.

Following a somewhat disappointing final warm-up friendly draw against the United States in Lyon at the weekend, a game in which Kante featured for the full 90 minutes, France flew into Moscow'sÂ Sheremetyevo International Airport on Sunday before arriving at their World Cup base at theÂ Hilton Garden Inn, New Riga.

Deschamps' side open their Group C campaign against Australia in Kazan on Saturday before facing Peru inÂ Yekaterinburg and Denmark in Moscow.

item.title: Eden Hazard wants clarity over managerial situation at Chelsea as his own future hangs in the balance
item.description: Eden Hazard wants to know who will be in charge of Chelsea next season and has suggested that his future at the club could be affected by it.Â
item.content:encoded:
Eden Hazard wants to know who will be in charge of Chelsea next season and has suggested that his future at the club could be affected by it.Â 

There has been much speculation surrounding Antonio Conte's future at Stamford Bridge and failure to guide them to Champions League qualification last season will have seen the Italian come under more scrutiny.Â 

However, after being linked with a move away from the Premier League side for months, Conte could well likely see out the year that is left on his contract as Roman Abramovich looks to keep costs down.


Former Napoli coach Maurizio Sarri looked to be the favourite to replace Conte but a move now looks off the cards.

Immediately after Chelsea's triumph in the FA Cup last month, Hazard cast doubt over his future with the club and it appears that the Belgian star will not decide where he will end up until the situation becomes clearer.

The 27-year-old has two years left on his current deal with Chelsea.Â 

'Yeah, I want to know,' Hazard told reporters. 'I want to know, but like I say I am focused on the World Cup.

'If we have something new â€“ manager or players â€“ it is always good to know it, because I want players that can [help bring success back to] Chelsea next season.

'But, to be fair, the transfer market is not here yet. We will see after.'Â Â

item.title: David de Gea admits he could be banned from Manchester United's dressing room... for his music taste!Â
item.description: Man United's goalkeeper de Gea has joked about being forced out of the dressing room because of his taste in music.Â De Gea admits that his taste in music differs massively from his team-mates.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United's goalkeeper David de Gea has joked about being forced out of the dressing room because of his taste in music.Â 

The Spaniard has often been linked with a move back to his homeland, but seems to think some of his team-mates wouldn't mind him leaving after subjecting them to his heavy metal music.

De Gea has been preparing for the World Cup with Spain and the No 1 kept a clean sheet in their final World Cup warm-up against Tunisia.


Speaking to Copa 90 about life at Old Trafford, De Gea said: 'I always put my music on.

'It is true that they might ban me from the dressing room one day.

'I get a lot of criticism about my music but I always try and play them good music.

'They like to play different kinds of music but I always play them a bit of mine.

'I like metal and rock bands like Avenged Sevenfold and Metallica. When I put it on in the dressing room, everyone moans! Most of the other players are into hip-hop.'

De Gea has been regularly linked with a move to Real Madrid and replacing Keylor Navas - who made a clanger against England last Thursday.Â 

Former boss Zinedine Zidane was content with Navas in goal, but a new boss may not be. President Florentino Perez is a long-term admirer of Spain's No 1 and could reignite a pursuit for him.Â 

For now, De Gea will be focused on the World Cup, and Spain are one of the favourites to win the prize as they did in 2010.Â 

Spain start their campaign against Portugal on June 15, before matches against Iran and Morocco completing Group B.Â

item.title: Arsenal legend Tony Adams brands Unai Emery 'irrelevant' and insists Sven Mislintat holds the key to success
item.description: Arsenal's fate lies in Sven Mislintat and Co's hands - not Unai Emery - according to club legend Tony Adams. The former captain believes the head coach role is 'irrelevant'.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal's fate lies in Sven Mislintat and Co's hands - not Unai Emery - according to club legend Tony Adams.

The former captain believes the head coach role is 'irrelevant' if they are not involved in acquiring the players that will improve the side.Â 

Emery signed on as Arsenal's head coach in a new look structure for the club. But it is head of recruitment Minslintat and head of football relations Raul Sanllehi, who will be pulling the strings behind the scenes for the Gunners.Â Â 


Adams told the Daily Star: 'Your head coach is irrelevant.

'You are only as good as your recruitment. It's all about getting the right players in this game.

'We're going to have to see if the guys Ivan Gazidis has brought in are good in that market.

'It's a market that's very overcrowded and we're probably down the pecking order in terms of finances.

'It'll be difficult if they're looking for European players - it'll be quite tricky.'

So far in this window, Arsenal have only signed one player. Stephan Lichsteiner joined the side on a free transfer from Juventus.

It is an astute first signing from the new-look system at the Emirates, but will by no means be enough to appease the fans or help move them up the league table.

Arsenal are close to completing a deal for Borussia Dortmund defender Sokratis Papastathopoulos for around Â£15m.Â 

Mislintat brought the Greek centre-back to Dortmund during his time at the club.Â Â

item.title: 'All that remains is for a fee to be agreed': Arsenal edge closer to snapping up Â£35m-rated Freiburg defender Caglar SoyuncuÂ
item.description: Arsenal are edging closer to securing a deal for Caglar Soyuncu, the Freiburg defender's agent has confirmed. Soyuncu has been heavily linked with a switch to the Gunners
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal are edging closer to securing a deal for Caglar Soyuncu, the Freiburg defender's agent has confirmed.

Soyuncu, who is valued at Â£35million, has been heavily linked with a switch to the Gunners and his agent Mustafa Dogru stated that 'all that remains is for a fee to be agreed'.

Dogru also disclosed that Sven Mislintat, Arsenal's head of recruitment, has a strong interest in Soyuncu having scouted him when he was working at Borussia Dortmund.Â 


As reported by Turkish Football, Dogru said: 'Sven Mislintat has been keen on Caglar since he was at Borussia Dortmund.

'He first scouted him back in Germany.

'Sven is interested in Caglar, there are concrete talks, all that remains is for a fee to be agreed.

'We will see what happens next.'

A Turkey international with 16 caps, Soyuncu commenced his senior career with Altinordu in his homeland prior to joining Freiburg in 2016.

Last season Soyuncu, who is extremely composed in possession, produced some excellent performances for Freiburg and has also attracted interest from Liverpool.

Arsenal have already made one defensive signing in this transfer window, bringing in experienced right-back Stephan Lichtsteiner.

In addition, the Gunners are expected to secure a deal for Borussia Dortmund centre-back SokratisÂ Papastathopoulos.

Should both Papastathopoulos and Soyuncu join Arsenal, it would surely mean that one of the club's existing centre-backs will depart, with new head coach Unai Emery assembling his squad ahead of his first campaign in charge.

Arsenal's defence was a major cause for concern last season - they let in 51 goals in the Premier League, 24 more than champions Manchester City.

item.description: The north London club have offered him a new deal, although that will involve a pay cut from his current Â£120,000-a-week wages. New manager Unai Emery wants him to stay at the Emirates.
item.content:encoded:
Juventus are on the cusp of offering Jack Wilshere a contract.

Sportsmail understands the Italian champions want the midfielder, whose contract with Arsenal expires later this summer.Â Â 

The north London club have offered him a new deal, although that will involve a pay cut from his current Â£120,000-a-week wages. New manager Unai Emery wants him to stay at the Emirates.


But Juventus are keen to exploit any uncertainty over that new offer and bring him to Serie A.

They are likely to snap up Emre Can, who Liverpool announced they would release after he turned down a new contract.

And Can could now be paired with Wilshere â€” who has been left out of the England squad for the World Cup.

The 26-year-old Wilshere has been with Arsenal since 2001 and has never had any manager except for Arsene Wenger, who left at the end of the season.

item.title: Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola rubbishes Yaya Toure's claim that he favours white players: 'They were lies and he knows it'
item.description: Toure left City at the end of the season and then brew up a storm earlier this week by claiming in an interview with France Football that Guardiola does not like picking African players.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola has emphatically refuted Yaya Toure's allegations that he favours white players, branding the midfielder's comments 'lies'.

Toure left City at the end of the season following eight hugely successful years but he brewed up a storm earlier this week by claiming in an interview with France Football that Guardiola does not like picking African players.

Kevin De Bruyne quickly leapt to Guardiola's defence and now the City manager has himself moved to quash Toure's serious allegations.


'They were lies and he knows it,' he told TV3 in Spain. 'We were together for two years and he says it now â€“ he never told me to my face.'

Toure fell out of favour under Guardiola last season, making just one Premier League start all campaign as City marched to the title in record-breaking fashion.

And the Ivory Coast midfielder claims the former Barcelona and Bayern Munich boss was 'cruel' to him in his final year at the Etihad.

'Pep did everything to spoil my last season. He was cruel with me,' Toure told France Football. 'Do you really think he could've been like that with Andres Iniesta?

'It got to the point I asked myself if it was because of my colour. I am not the first. Other Barcelona players asked the question.

'Maybe us Africans aren't always treated the same by certain people. When you see the problems (Pep) has often had with African players, everywhere he has been, I ask myself questions.Â 

'He is too intelligent to be caught. He will never admit it. But the day he picks a team with five Africans in it, I promise I will send him a cake.'

The pair could come face-to-face again soon, with the 35-year-oldÂ Toure currently in talks with West HamÂ over a move to the London Stadium this summer.Â Â Â 

He was paid Â£220,000 a week by City and would have to accept a pay cut at West Ham, but the Hammers are confident of getting the deal done.Â

item.title: Ruben Loftus-Cheek holds off Chelsea future talk until after World Cup... but suggests Antonio Conte's future will have an impact on his final decision
item.description: The 22-year-old is due to return to Chelsea following an impressive season on loan at Crystal Palace, but it is unclear as to whether he would get the first-team football his talent warrants.
item.content:encoded:
Ruben Loftus-Cheek is putting any decision on his future on hold until England's involvement in this summer's World Cup is over.

The 22-year-old is due to return to Chelsea following an impressive season on loan at Crystal Palace, but it is unclear as to whether he would get the first-team football his talent warrants.

A number of clubs would jump at the chance to sign him on a permanent basis, but Loftus-Cheek says his future is likely to be impacted by the future of Antonio Conte, who is still expected to depart Stamford Bridge after two years in charge.


The midfielder also says it would be disrespectful to Gareth Southgate and his England team-mates to even consider his future while competing in Russia. As a result, he will refuse to entertain any more questions until their tournament ends.

He said: 'It's unfair to my team-mates if I'm not fully focused on this so all the talk about my future will have to wait until after the World Cup.

'I've enjoyed Palace but I don't know what happens from here as there are so many variables.

'Different things happening at Chelsea may affect my whereabouts next season.'Â 

Loftus-Cheek was a key player at Selhurst Park as Crystal Palace recovered from a terrible start to finish 11th in the Premier League.Â 

Among the many things he learned during his time in south London, the most prominent lesson was how important it is to play regular football.

He continued: 'I've really realised the importance of playing regularly for my own progress and development.

'I felt like I got better and better every game at Palace so playing regularly is the key going forward and that will help me make my decision after the World Cup.'

item.title: Jorginho on cusp of Â£60m Man City move, claims Napoli president: 'I think the deal can be done in next few days'
item.description: Italy international Jorginho remains City's prime target this summer but talks had recently slowed down, with the clubs' valuations still around Â£9million apart and Napoli demanding over Â£60m.
item.content:encoded:
Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis has provided Manchester City with a huge boost in their pursuit of Jorginho, claiming a deal is close.

Italy international Jorginho remains City's prime target this summer but talks had recently slowed down, with the clubs' valuations still around Â£9million apart and Napoli demanding over Â£60m.

However, it appears now that Jorginho is closing in on a move to the Etihad before the World Cup following more positive talks in the last couple of days.


De Laurentiis told the Sun: 'I think the deal can be done in the next few days. Everything is possible as we have a good relationship with Manchester City and their people but we must negotiate.

'We are still not in agreement over the price for the player but we'll be near to the conclusion as they made an effort in the last few days'.Â Â 

Napoli have been searching for a replacement with Sampdoria's Lucas Torreira their prime option.

Uruguay international Torreira is also a target for Arsenal and has a release clause set at Â£22m.

Meanwhile, despite winning the Premier League in record-breaking fashion last season â€”Â becoming the first team in history to reach the 100-point barrier â€” Pep Guardiola is desperate to add to his City squad this summer.

They are also closing in on a Â£75m move for Leicester star Riyad Mahrez following their failed attempts to sign him in January.Â Â

item.title: 'They don't look at me the same way': Manchester City's Pep Guardiola says he will never manage Barcelona again
item.description: The Catalan tactician won an incredible 14 titles during a four-year spell as Barcelona head coach including three La Ligas, two Champions Leagues and two Copa del Reys.
item.content:encoded:
Pep Guardiola says he has no intention of trying to recreate his success at Barcelona, admitting his time in the Nou Camp dugout has come and gone for good.

The Catalan tactician won an incredible 14 titles during a four-year spell as Barcelona head coach including three La Ligas, two Champions Leagues and two Copa del Reys.

But the Spaniard admits he would not be able to live up to his own legacy because he couldn't recreate the unique circumstances that opened the door to their domination.


'As a coach (of Barcelona), it's over. I am not the same, nor do they even look at me in the same way,' he said on Spain's TV3.

'I was at a fantastic age in which I was taking on the world. We took it on with some incredible players, a young president (Joan Laporta), Txiki (Begiristain)... it was a generation of brutal players and the best player in the world (Lionel Messi).Â The stars aligned.'

Many of the figures behind Barcelona's success under Guardiola have since moved on, withÂ Begiristain joining him at Manchester City and Laporta moving along for Sandro Rosell in 2012.

But one enduring figure at the Nou Camp has been Messi, who has remained at the club for the whole of his professional career and continues to perform at an exceptionally high level.

As one of the managers lucky enough to have worked with Messi, Guardiola knows the five-time Ballon d'Or winner better than most and revealed his lasting memory is how introverted the forward was off of the pitch.

Guardiola continued: 'Messi is unique. He won't complain off the pitch, but when he doesn't like something on it, he says. Off the pitch he's so quiet.'

item.title: Liverpool 'ready to make Â£15m bid for Nick Pope as they look to resolve goalkeeping problems'Â
item.description: In a bid to solve their goalkeeping problems, Liverpool are 'to make a Â£15million bid for Nick Pope' this summer as Jurgen Klopp has been left unconvinced by Simon Mignolet and Loris Karius.
item.content:encoded:
In a bid to solve their goalkeeping problems, Liverpool are 'to make a Â£15million bid for Nick Pope' this summer.

The Burnley stopper, according to the Sun, is wanted by Reds boss Jurgen Klopp after being left unconvinced by both Simon Mignolet and Loris Karius.Â 

Pope, who has two years left on his deal at Turf Moor, is currently away with England at the World Cup.Â 


Klopp axed Mignolet as his first choice goalkeeper midway through last season but Karius' two errors in the Champions League final raised questions about his long-term suitability at the club.

Roma's Alisson has been monitored by the club but would cost in the region of Â£70m - Pope would make a far cheaper alternative and is already used to the rigours of the Premier League.Â 

Burnley are preparing to enter European football next season after a fine campaign where Pope played a starring role in the absence of Tom Heaton.

But Pope's sale, with Heaton - who was first choice before he was injured - back fit again, would provide additional funds to add more bodies ahead of the extra games in Europe.Â 

Liverpool themselves want depth but it appears Lyon forward Nabil Fekir will not be moving to Anfield after the French club announced negotiations had ended on Saturday night.

The France international, who scored 23 goals for Lyon in Ligue 1 last season, was Jurgen Kloppâ€™s prime target for the summer and has been identified as Philippe Coutinhoâ€™s long-term replacement.

But medical checks saw issues come to light which is said to have made the Merseysiders think twice and the move is now dead.Â

item.title: Liverpool's Â£53m move for Nabil Fekir is OFF after Lyon announce negotiations 'had not succeeded' and he will stay with French side
item.description: Liverpool's Â£53million move Nabil Fekir is off after Lyon dramatically cancelled negotiations. He scored 23 goals for Lyon in Ligue 1 last season and was Jurgen Kloppâ€™s prime target.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool's Â£53million move Nabil Fekir is off after Lyon dramatically cancelled negotiations.

The France international, who scored 23 goals for Lyon in Ligue 1 last season, was Jurgen Kloppâ€™s prime target for the summer and has been identified as Philippe Coutinhoâ€™s long-term replacement.

A five-year deal, worth more than Â£140,000 per week, had been agreed and Liverpoolâ€™s medical team travelled to Paris on Friday to conduct a medical at France national team base in Clairefontaine.

It had been expected that Liverpool would be in a position to announce his signature later that day but it is understood issues arose during the course of the fitness tests to make the Anfield club think twice.

There were suggestions in France that Liverpool had tried to renegotiate the terms of the deal that had been struck by Sporting Director Michael Edwards but that was never the case.

When the issue dragged into Friday, Lyon posted a statement on their website which confirmed the move was dead and made it clear that negotiations will not resume.


It read: 'Olympique Lyonnais informs that the tripartite negotiations with the Liverpool club and Nabil Fekir for the transfer of the captain of OL have not succeeded and that Lyon has decided to put an end to this negotiation on Saturday night.

'Although Liverpool has been the priority of a possible transfer of Nabil, and subject to other proposals consistent with the interest of Nabil and OL and from ambitious clubs, Lyon is delighted soon to be able to count on the presence of the captain who is a leading rookie for this season 2018/2019 during which the club will play the Champions League being in the 3rd hat of the draw.'Â 

The statement was posted on Lyon's official club website, but was removed from the page shortly afterwards.Â 

It is currently unknown as to why the original message was taken down.Â Â

item.description: The forward is hot property among Premier League clubs following Stoke City's relegation to the Championship and it appears he is nearing a move to Merseyside.
item.content:encoded:
Xherdan Shaqiri remained coy over his future after refusing to rule out a potential switch to Liverpool.

The forward is hot property among Premier League clubs following Stoke City's relegation to the Championship and it appears he is nearing a move to Merseyside.

But after admitting that Anfield is a 'great' stadium, Shaqiri told reporters on Friday that he is more focused on his World Cup duties with Switzerland.

Ricardo Rodriguez and Haris Seferovic were on target for the Swiss at theÂ Cornaredo Stadium in Lugano.

item.title: Wayne Rooney moves closer to DC United switch as Everton striker is pictured in Belfast collecting paperwork to play in MLS
item.description: The Everton striker has been in talks with MLS side DC United for the past month and moved a step closer to a switch by fulfilling some administrative duties in Northern Ireland.
item.content:encoded:
Wayne Rooney has been spotted in Belfast collecting the relevant paperwork required to complete his deal to MLS side DC United.

The Everton striker is poised to leave his boyhood club this summer with a move across the Atlantic becoming increasingly likely.

Rooney has been in talks with the MLS side for the past month and moved a step closer to a switch by fulfilling some administrative duties in Northern Ireland.


The 32-year-old visited the US Consulate in Belfast on Friday as part of his visa application process.Â 

Rooney was seen with agent Paul Stretford outside the Consulate, before he was picked up in a chauffeur-driven car.Â 

Marco Silva insisted he will not make a final attempt to convince Rooney to remain at Everton when he was formally presented as the club's new manager on Monday.

Though there are some at Goodison who want him to stay, notably chairman Bill Kenwright, major shareholder Farhad Moshiri was the first person to raise the possibility of him leaving.

Silva was given the opportunity to say there was a place for Rooney in his plans but admitted he is yet to meet the player.

'It's not in my hands â€” it is something that started before (I signed),' said Silva. 'It was Wayne's decision with the club before I came.

'Before everything is done I will talk with Wayne because he is a club legend. I hope everybody works out this situation â€” him and the club. We will see.Â 

'Wayne needs to take this decision and the club needs to take this decision as well.

'After I have enough time to talk with him and see everything. When everybody talks about his legs nobody expects Wayne to be the same as five or 10 years ago. It's not just with him. It happens with all players.'

item.description: 23-year-old Sergej Milinkovic-Savic has been heavily linked with a move away from Lazio after they failed to secure Champions League football next season.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United target Sergej Milinkovic-Savic insists he is focused on the World Cup and will decide his future afterwards.

Milinkovic-Savic has been heavily linked with a move away from Lazio after they failed to secure Champions League football next season.

Jose Mourinho is still searching for another midfielder despite agreeing a fee for Brazil international Fred, with Marouane Fellaini likely to be off this summer.


However, United may be put off by the Serbia international's fee, with Lazio setting an asking price of Â£87.5million.

With his future uncertain at Lazio, Milinkovic-Savic admits he is not focusing on a potential move until after the World Cup finishes.

'I am trying to remain concentrated, even though every day I read something new about me,' he said ahead of Serbia's friendly clash with Bolivia.

'Obviously, I feel pressure on me and know that I'll have to live with this situation throughout the World Cup. It's the same pressure as when I play for Lazio, so I am accustomed to it.

'I will decide where to continue my career after the World Cup. There's a very good atmosphere among the squad and it feels like I've been here for years. I can't wait to start the tournament.'

item.description: Manchester CityÂ will focus on Real Madrid's Mateo Kovacic if they fail to make a breakthrough in negotiations for Napoli's Jorginho. Talks between City and Napoli have hit stalemate.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester CityÂ will focus on Real Madrid's Mateo Kovacic if they fail to make a breakthrough in negotiations for Napoli's Jorginho.

Talks between City and Napoli have hit stalemate with the clubs still around Â£9million apart and the Italians demanding over Â£60m for the Italy international.

Jorghino remains their prime target but City will walk away unless Napoli soften their stance.


To City's advantage, Jorginho has warned he will refuse to sign a new contract at Napoli if they fail to agree terms for his sale.

City have had a Â£40million bid rejected and made revised offers, including add-ons, but are now considering their back-up options with 24-year-old Croatia international Mateo Kovacic of Real Madrid ahead of Southampton's Mario Lemina as their next targets.

Jorginho's agent, Joao Santos said: 'Jorginho is a great professional, but this is the opportunity of a lifetime for he and his family. If he does not go to Manchester, he will not be very happy

'As of today, he remains a Napoli player. Manchester City? We must not be hypocrites, any player would like to go and have a starting position with Guardiola.

'Napoli and City have not found an agreement. There is a distance of about â‚¬10m. City are now working on their second choice,' Santos told CalcioNapoli24.Â 

'The player is waiting for Napoli's decision: he still has two years on his contract, we will not renew.'

Napoli have been searching for a replacement with Sampdoria's Lucas Torreira their prime option.

Uruguay international Torreira is also a target for Arsenal and has a clause set at Â£22million.

item.title: Manchester United target Marko Arnautovic refuses to rule out move away from West Ham this summer: 'Whatever happens will happen'
item.description: Austria international Marko Arnautovic has been heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford after enjoying a brilliant season for West Ham in the Premier League.
item.content:encoded:
West Ham forward Marko Arnautovic has opened up about his future amid interest from Manchester United, claiming 'whatever happens will happen'.

Arnautovic has been heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford after enjoying a brilliant season for West Ham in the Premier League.

Jose Mourinho recently flew to Austria to watch the Â£40million forward playing in a friendly against Russia ahead of the World Cup, fuelling further talk of a potential move.


And speaking ahead of Austria's friendly with Brazil on Sunday, Arnautovic admits he is 'happy' at West Ham but refused to rule out a move.Â Â 

'I am happy with my job. Whatever happens will happen. I've never heard anything,' Arnautovic told Sky Austria.

'Even three weeks ago I haven't heard anything. That's why I cannot say anything about it.

'The only thing that bothers me is that I am in good health and that I am able to play football.

'I have a contract at West Ham, that's all we have to talk about.'Â Â Â 

United have also been linked with Mario Mandzukic after Juventus told the Croat he can leave if he wants.

However, it is unlikely that Mourinho would sign either player if United were able to land Gareth Bale this summer.Â Â 

United see Arnautovic as an impact player or an option from the left if Anthony Martial pushes for the exit door in the transfer window.

item.title: Liverpool's Â£53m move for Nabil Fekir is still on despite fitness concerns and disrupted negotiations, claims French FA chief Noel Le Graet
item.description: Nabil Fekir'sÂ move to Liverpool is still on according to French FA president Noel Le Graet. Talks stalled on Friday, with Lyon unhappy that news of the imminent transfer had been released.
item.content:encoded:
Nabil Fekir'sÂ move to Liverpool is still on. according to French FA president Noel Le Graet.

Talks stalled on Friday, with Lyon unhappy that news of the imminent Â£52.8million transfer had been released.

The playmaker had a medical at France's HQ in Clairefontaine, outside Paris, on Thursday which raised an issue over a previous knee injury though that was subsequently resolved. Yet French media believe the issue centres on Lyon wanting more bonus payments.

Fekir has joined up with France's squad and spoke to president Le Graet on Saturday morning.

Le Graet said: 'I saw Nabil this morning for 15 minutes. He is a boy who has his feet on the ground. He is in the middle of negotiations and I think that it will be done.


'That does not prevent him from being very focused on the French national team,' he told Le Progres.Â 

'He was in very good spirits. It would be better that his transfer be done before the departure for Russia, but he does not seem worried. He seemed optimistic on the matter because the medical that he underwent was positive.Â 

'With a transfer, it is always like that. Each party tries to enforce their price, bring it down or bring it up. As soon as there is a little hitchâ€¦ that is all part of the game.'Â 

The France international, who scored 23 goals for Lyon in Ligue 1 last season, is Jurgen Klopp's prime target for the summer and has been identified as Philippe Coutinho's long-term replacement.Â 

A five-year deal, worth more than Â£140,000 per week, has been agreed and it had been expected that Liverpool would be in a position to announce his signature on Friday night.

Fekir has previously had serious knee problems, suffering a cruciate ligament rupture in his right leg in September 2015. He also requiredÂ arthroscopic surgery to clear a joint a year later.Â 

However a day of confusion began with Lyon issuing a terse statement on their website, rejecting Friday's report that Fekir on was on the brink of moving to Anfield.

It read: 'The information on the transfer of Nabil Fekir is false. Olympique Lyonnais categorically denies the false information disseminated by the media about the transfer of Nabil Fekir to Liverpool.

'In this period of transfers where the slightest rumour is often presented as a reality, Olympique Lyonnais says that only the information disseminated by the club on its website is authentic.'

It is very much Liverpool's intention to sign Fekir, who was also wanted by Atletico Madrid and was watched by Manchester City last autumn.

After taking Mahrez back into the fold following his 10-day absence since his January move fell through, Leicester are now prepared to let the Algerian leave.

Despite winning the Premier League in record-breaking fashion last season - becoming the first team to break the 100-point barrier - Guardiola is desperate to add to his formidable City squad.

City have also offered Â£40m for Italy international Jorginho but Serie A side Napoli want closer to Â£60m.

item.title: 'When I get my mind loaded with different stuff, it makes me play better': Sebastian Prodl on London life, England's World Cup chances and the family kitchen business
item.description: EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW BY MATTHEW SMITH: Prodl could have been part of Leicester's Premier League title glory - but he has not regretted moving to Watford - and London - for one second.
item.content:encoded:
When his Werder Bremen contract expired in the summer of 2015, Sebastian Prodl was faced with a choice as he prepared to move to the Premier League â€“ Watford or Leicester.

He chose Watford, which might have caused great regret for most players as Leicester went on to lift the trophy the following May.

Prodl does not regret it for a second â€“ not just for the three seasons of Premier League football, but for three years of happily living in Hampstead. He encourages any English player to do the same in reverse; experience living in a foreign culture.

He tells Sportsmail: 'I love London: it's so cosmopolitan and open-minded. I never thought twice about moving here even though I had other offers, and I never get tired of it. There are so many museums and so many galleries.

'I can only speak for myself, but it is very important to have interests outside of football. There are some players who are focused on football 24/7, but I need a work and life balance, I need other stuff to do so when I'm on the pitch I can be more concentrated, more competitive, it makes me play better. When I get my mind loaded with different stuff, I feel better when I'm on the training ground and playing at the weekend.'

Prodl comes from a family of footballers â€“ his brother and cousin played professionally in Austria, while another cousin, Viktoria Schnaderbeck, signed a contract with Arsenal last month.


He is excited to welcome Viktoria to the lifestyle he loves as living in London has helped him improve on the pitch â€“ and he suggested English players could benefit with a similar type of education abroad.

'I think young English players could benefit from moving abroad, although you also have a lot of good clubs in England. The gap between the smaller teams and the top is less than in Germany, for example.Â 

'But obviously, if you move abroad you get different ideas and experiences. When I played in Germany, when I played in England, when I had a Spanish, coach, an Italian coach, a Portuguese coach, they gave me different ideas.'

His unusual attitude to life as a professional footballer has been influenced by the fact that, while the modern Prodls might be making their careers in sport, there is a different career path associated with that name in Austria.

The family business, started in Styria two generations ago by Josef Prodl, has become a successful producer of high-end kitchens.

The 30-year-old wants to carry on in football for as long as possible â€“ but has not ruled out a reversion to the traditional family values.

'I've always tried to get some kind of balance in my life as a professional footballer, to get the best performance not only out of my body but out of my mind. Especially now I'm getting older â€”Â I'm not old, but getting older â€”Â you have to find other interests for a career after retiring.

'I'm trying to get to know myself a little bit better because I don't want to retire in four or five years and not know what to do. I'm thinking about coaching, but I want something to get the best out of me. There's the family business, I would be more than happy to join, but I'm not so good at organising, so we'll have to see in the next couple of years.'

Prodl is in Vienna, preparing to make his 68th international appearance, against Brazil. It comes a few days after he put in a stellar performance as Austria stunned Germany 2-1 in a World Cup warm-up clash.

A warm-up for Germany, not Austria. They failed to qualify, finishing behind Serbia, Ireland and Wales in a group where they were top seeds.

That underachievement leads Prodl to feel a certain kinship with England, particularly when it comes to Euro 2016.

They both reached France with unbeaten qualifying records and were viewed as dark horses for the title. Both were dumped out by Iceland â€“ Austria in the group stage, England in the last 16.

Speaking about the Three Loins ahead of the World Cup, Prodl says: 'When Austria qualified for Euro 2016, everyone expected us to be dark horses because we had nine wins and one draw in qualification. Everyone expected us to go through the group stage easily.

'It's the same with England â€“ expectations are always high because qualification is very good. It doesn't make it easier.

'I feel sympathy with England. I play with the players, I know the people at Watford. I want them to get far and have success.'

Prodl's connection to England also comes from his three years at Vicarage Road where he has been one of the most consistent performers. Scouts from West Ham, Arsenal and Crystal Palace attended the game against Germany. All are in need of central defensive reinforcements.

Consistency has not been easy, given how Watford's owners are inclined to chop and change their managers. For Prodl, club uncertainty is an occupational hazard.

'There has been a lot of changing, but that is just the philosophy of Watford so you have to go with it. I've had four managers in three years, a lot of players coming in and leaving all the time, it's part of the philosophy and so far it has been successful.

Despite this, he admits a certain frustration that successive good league starts have not been converted into something more tangible, particularly last summer under Marco Silva, who had the Hornets on the verge of the top four before a collapse in form â€”Â combined with interest from future employers Everton â€” led to the boss being sacked.

Prodl says: 'We had a manager and players last season who were going into their first year in the Premier League, and weren't sure how to get a good season out of it.

'So we put some really good performances into the first half, then maybe we got a little bit tired, a bit lazy somehow, and maybe there was inexperience in the manager â€”Â not ability, they are two different things â€”Â in how to handle a whole season.'

item.title: Richard Scudamore on stepping down as Premier League executive chairman: 'I was 39 when I got the job, you don't want to do it when you're 60'
item.description: Richard Scudamore announced earlier this week he will be leaving his position as executive chairman at the end of the year after almost two decades spent in the Premier League's top job.
item.content:encoded:
Richard Scudamore has opened up on his decision to step down as Premier League executive chairman after announcing his departure will come at the end of the year.

Scudamore announced earlier this week he will be leaving his position after almost 20 years spent in the Premier League's top job.

And the 58-year-old explained that the length of his tenure was one of the reasons he knew it was the right time to leave, sayingÂ 'I was 39 when I got this job. You don't want to do it when you're 60.'


Premier League clubs on Thursday struck a new deal over sharing future revenue from international broadcast deals, with future increases divided according to league position.Â 

Scudamore waited for that wrangle to be agreed before announcing he would be stepping down from his role later this year after almost 20 years in charge.

'A number of the clubs were palpably relieved that this has been resolved; we've been at it for four years,' said Scudamore. 'It's been difficult and challenging as all the executives at the clubs get on pretty well together.

'There are good friends, and partnerships and friendships around that table that I don't understand and you wouldn't understand either.

'The executives who attend are friends, even if they are on opposite sides of the argument. And it was a big issue in the way of normal dealings. It was great that we don't have to talk about that again now. That was a general view.

He added: 'I'll concentrate now on the rest of the international rights process. Hopefully we'll get that completed by December, then I'll spend Christmas in the sunshine somewhere.

'When I joined our turnover was Â£160million. We will give away Â£460million this year. The biggest of the banks don't get anywhere near it. I don't know what greed means really. I'm proud of this, I don't have to defend it.'Â 

The Premier League will also propose a code of conduct for agents in a crackdown on the practices of players' representatives.

Senior Premier League officials will work with the Football Association to present a detailed set of recommendations to world governing body FIFA, which is examining ushering in new levels of regulations for agents.

The league wants agents to pass an exam to represent players in England, to hold a UK bank account and to submit annual financial reports to the FA detailing payments received.

Scudamore announced Premier League clubs reached consensus on the issue at this week's shareholders' meeting.

'We've been working for 18 months on what our clubs would like to do about agents,' said Scudamore. 'We want to boost administrative transparency and put the players at the centre of any transactions, to put the players more in control.

'We've discussed a range of issues and we have reached a position to progress those ideas. So we're going to draft up rules on the basis of that, work this up very quickly and feed this into FIFA.

'There is a suspicion that players sometimes see their net pay but they don't know what's gone on to get to that point. This is about making the player central to this process.

'We have some strong views on this. This is what we'd like to see happen and this is what we'll feed in. We think we've got a contribution to make to that debate.

'I think they will listen to us at least and give us fair hearing on this, because of the amount of market we are involved in. It would be worth FIFA listening.'Â

item.title: Shakhtar Donetsk sign Olarenwaju Kayode 12 months after Manchester City paid Â£3.5m forÂ Nigeria striker
item.description: Nigeria international Kayode, who was signed by City manager Pep Guardiola in a Â£3.5million deal from Austria Vienna last August, has signed a five-year deal with the Ukrainian champions.
item.content:encoded:
Striker Olarenwaju Kayode has joined Shakhtar Donetsk for an undisclosed fee from Manchester City.

The Nigeria international, who was signed by City boss Pep Guardiola in a Â£3.5million deal from Austria Vienna last August, has signed a five-year deal with the Ukrainian champions.

The 25-year-old forward did not make a single appearance for City as he was immediately loaned out to Spanish club Girona before moving to Shakhtar in a similar deal in March.


Shakhtar general director Sergei Palkin told the club's official website: 'Kayode will continue to play for Shakhtar.

'We redeemed him from Manchester City and he has signed a five-year contract.

'He proved himself well, Paulo (Fonseca, Shakhtar manager) is pleased with him.'

Kayode scored three goals in eight games during his Shakhtar loan spell.Â

item.title: Harry Kane's new Tottenham deal sees him take home Â£300,000 per week... but where does that put him the list of the best-paid Premier League stars?
item.description: Tottenham's notoriously strict wage structure has been blown into oblivion with the news that Harry Kane has agreed a new contract worth an incredible Â£90million over six years.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham's notoriously strict wage structure has been blown into oblivion with the news that Harry Kane has agreed a new contract worth an incredible Â£90million over six years.

The deal, which works out Â£300,000 per week including bonuses, places Kane joint-second in the list of the Premier League's best-paid players, alongside Arsenal's Mesut Ozil and only behind Manchester United star Alexis Sanchez.Â 

A sign of how significant this is for Tottenham, Kane is now their only player in the list of the Premier League's top 20 biggest earners with the next highest being French goalkeeper Hugo Lloris, who takes home a comparatively paltry Â£120,000 per week.

But there are few inside the club who will claim their star striker does not deserve his incredible wage packet. Kane, who will lead England to the World Cup in Russia as captain, has scored 135 goals in the last four seasons at Tottenham.

In that time, he has claimed two Premier League Golden Boots, only missing out on a record-equalling his third consecutive top-scorer title due to Mohamed Salah's 34-goal haul for Liverpool. That is despite 2017-18 being his best return to date with 30 goals from 37 games.

That is certainly more than Sanchez has done to justify his own excessive wages at Old Trafford. Since joining from Arsenal in January, the Chilean managed just three goals from his 18 appearances under Jose Mourinho.

It remains to be seen whether Kane's new deal is the exception to the rule or the start of a new era at the club. Chairman Daniel Levy has always maintained a strict wage structure at the club but they are looking to move into the elite levels of the game as they prepare to move to a state-of-the-art 62,000-seat stadium at White Hart Lane.Â Â 

Toby Alderweireld and Mousa Dembele have both failed to agree terms due to to Levy's wage system. Tottenham expect to sell the duo this summer in order to avoid losing them for nothing when their current deals expire next summer.

Tottenham will use the funds generated from their sales to help pay for new deals for other significant stars. Christian Eriksen, whose deal expires in 2019, is currently in talks over an improved deal while Dele Alli and Eric Dier will also be offered fresh terms in the near future.Â

item.title: Roman Abramovich rejects offer to sell Chelsea to Britain's richest man, Manchester United fan Jim Ratcliffe
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Roman Abramovich has rejected an approach from Britainâ€™s richest person to buy Chelsea Football Club. Jim Ratcliffe, owner of petrochemicals giant Ineos is interested in buying.
item.content:encoded:
Roman Abramovich has rejected an approach from Britainâ€™s richest person to buy Chelsea Football Club.

Jim Ratcliffe, the billionaire boss of multinational petrochemicals giant Ineos and a season-ticket holder at Stamford Bridge, expressed an interest in buying the club amid speculation the Russian oligarch could be prepared to sell.

But Ratcliffeâ€™s advances, Sportsmail understands, were swiftly repelled, with Abramovich making it clear he has no intention of cutting ties with Chelsea despite his recent decision to shelve his new stadium plans in response to visa problems with the Home Office.

Chelsea refused to comment on Friday, stating only that Abramovich remains committed to a club he has owned for 15 years. Indeed, sources claim Ratcliffeâ€™s is among a number of approaches that have been rejected, including from China.

Ratcliffe, who on Saturday was knighted in the Queen's Birthday Honours for services to business and investment, already owns a football club in Switzerland and has a personal fortune of more than double that of Abramovich.


The 65-year-old is a Manchester United fan but watches football at Stamford Bridge because it is close to his Chelsea home. Last season he was also a guest at the clubâ€™s Cobham training ground.

Last monthâ€™s Sunday Times rich list valued Ratcliffe at Â£21.05bn, compared to Abramovichâ€™s Â£9.3bn valuation. The club would cost in excess of Â£1bn to buy. Ratcliffeâ€™s company, Ineos, recorded sales of Â£45bn and employs more than 18,500 people in 22 countries.

â€˜Shelling out Â£2bn or so would seem like a drop in the ocean for Jim but at the moment he is torn about what to do,â€™ added a friend of Ratcliffe, who wished not to be identified.

Ratcliffe, who grew up in a council house in Failsworth â€” a small town between Manchester and Oldham â€” was asked in a recent interview about his education and replied: â€˜I just played football, really. Thatâ€™s all I was interested in.â€™

Seven months ago, Ratcliffe bought the Swiss club FC Lausanne-Sport for an undisclosed sum, as part of his companyâ€™s commitment to local sport and with a wish to see the club eventually playing in the Champions League.

A close ally of President Putin, Abramovich bought Chelsea in 2003 in a deal worth Â£140million. He took on the clubâ€™s debts, which were estimated at Â£80m, and has ploughed hundreds of millions into Chelsea, winning five Premier League titles and the Champions League.

But, following Theresa Mayâ€™s crackdown on wealthy Russians living in Britain after the poisoning of Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury, Abramovich, 51, has faced difficulties obtaining a UK visa.

He was reportedly incensed at not being allowed to watch Chelseaâ€™s win over Manchester United in this yearâ€™s FA Cup final on May 19 and within days he applied for and gained Israeli citizenship.

Downing Street has made it clear Abramovich cannot work in Britain on his Israeli passport, although he can visit for up to six months at a time.

A plan was in place to demolish Stamford Bridge in two years but last week Abramovich announced that the Â£1bn redevelopment had been halted in retaliation for the hardline attitude of the Home Office.

Known as a supporter of the UK leaving the EU, Ratcliffe has had his own run-ins with the British Government.

In 2010, when Gordon Brown was Prime Minister, he moved his operations to Switzerland following a row over his wish to postpone VAT payments for six months.

The Treasury refused and for six years the Ineos headquarters remained in Switzerland. It returned to Britain two years ago, where it is based near Harrods in Londonâ€™s Knightsbridge.

Ratcliffe is passionate about sport and believes primary schools should be legally required to make children run a daily mile as a means of combatting the obesity crisis.

He is providing financial backing for the Daily Mile Foundation charity and has said that one of his missions is to improve the countryâ€™s health.

A spokesman for Ratcliffe did not deny the industrialistâ€™s interest in Chelsea.

â€˜We cannot comment on rumour and speculation,â€™ he said.

item.title: Tottenham have joined the Premier League's elite... Harry Kane's Â£90m deal and their new stadium are proof Spurs can compete with rivals but now they must win trophies to match
item.description: Spurs's future among the big boys seemed in the balance. Yet from this position of precariousness, Spurs have taken that leap. Levy has been brave. And they are ready to join the elite.
item.content:encoded:
This was meant to be the summer when it all fell apart for Tottenham.

When the final whistle blew at Wembley, what had been Spurs' temporary home all season, and defeat by Manchester United in the FA Cup semi-final was confirmed, so too was the absence of silverware for another season.

By that point, the Premier League was already destined to be decorated in light blue ribbons. Two years ago, they blew their chance to catch Leicester. Then they blew their chance to catch Chelsea. No one ever had a chance of catching City.


All this having once again played some of the most exhilarating football of any team in the Premier League, alongside City and Liverpool. Yet it was still only one League Cup in 19 years.

And amid all that disappointment, there must have been another niggling concern this might actually be the best it would get. White Hart Lane had already been demolished but were the club's ambitions also about to come tumbling down?

Real Madrid were rumoured to be circling around manager Mauricio Pochettino, the architect of this exciting, young squad. Would he be tempted by one of the biggest managerial jobs in world football?

His comments after the final game of the season hardly breathed confidence. 'I have very clear ideas of what we need to do but I don't know if the club will agree with me,' he said. 'If we want to be real contenders for big trophies... you need to be brave.'

Because while Tottenham might have joined the elite when it comes to their style of football â€“ they were one of only two teams to beat Real Madrid over 90 minutes in the Champions League â€“ off the pitch they were nowhere near. And that was holding them back.

And then there was the talisman, Harry Kane. He might be one of their own, but he is also one of the best strikers in the world. Chairman Daniel Levy's stringent wage structure meant Kane was the club's highest earner on Â£110,000 a week, a salary on par with Leicester striker Jamie Vardy. How strong would those heart strings hold up under the strain of bigger clubs offering much better wages?

Tottenham's future among the big boys seemed in the balance.

Yet from this position of precariousness, Spurs have taken that leap. Levy has been brave. And Spurs are now ready to put themselves among the elite.

First, it was Pochettino. A new five-year contract, which took his salary from Â£5.5million a year to Â£8.5m. Even if he does keep flirting with Real Madrid following the resignation of Zinedine Zidane â€“ 'a club that 100 per cent of coaches dream of managing one day' â€“ Pochettino is happy at Tottenham for now and also does not want to be seen as a mercenary.

And now Kane has committed his future to the club. His new contract is expected to triple his wages to up to Â£300,000 a week. It's no longer Vardy who Kane is on par with, but behind only Manchester United forward Alexis Sanchez as the highest-paid footballer in the Premier League.

Spurs are no longer punching above their weight but paying salaries that justifies them being in the same ring as City and United.

New deals for the influential pair Dele Alli and Christian Eriksen are expected to follow.

That's the manager sorted. And now the club's star players. There is also the none-too-small matter of the new stadium.

Spurs will move into the new White Hart Lane this season, a stadium on which they have spent the best part of Â£1bn to make it one of the most modern stadiums in the world. The capacity will increase from 36,284 to a shade over 62,000. That will make it the second-largest club stadium in the Premier League, behind only Old Trafford. And, maybe more importantly to Spurs fans, a grand or so more seats than the Emirates.

Tottenham have spent so much of their recent existence in Arsenal's shadow. Now, they pay their top players more and have a bigger stadium.

The next step is to see this smashed financial structure translate into big-name signings. At the moment, Tottenham's record signing is centre-back Davinson Sanchez who cost Â£40m last summer. Before him, it was Â£30m flop Moussa Sissoko.

Sanchez has been a fine acquisition, and proven to be worth the cost. But Premier League giants make gigantic signings.

To further challenge the Premier League goliaths, Spurs will have to spend more. United have just paid Â£52m for Fred, Liverpool are set to splash Â£53m on Nabil Fekir. In January, Arsenal spent nearly Â£60m on Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang having bought Alexandre Lacazette for more than Â£50m in the summer.

Now, it's Tottenham's turn to make the same statements in the transfer market.

Kane's contract, Pochettino's future, the new stadium, and the freshly-discarded purse strings have put Spurs, without question, among the elite Premier League clubs off the pitch.

But that means that the excuses have gone, too. The financial disparity between Spurs and the rest can no longer be used as a safety net on which they can land if they fall short once again next season and the ones after that.

Spurs are now on the same level as the biggest clubs in the Premier League. They must start to win the trophies to match.

item.title: Pep Guardiola insists his Manchester City team can't yet be considered the best Premier League team of all time: 'We have to win more'
item.description: The Sky Blues smashed a host of Premier League records as they cruised cruised to the title but manager Pep Guardiola believes that his team must deliver consistent success.
item.content:encoded:
Pep Guardiola believes his Manchester City team still have some way to go if they are to be considered the best Premier League side of all time.

The Sky Blues cruised to the title, finishing 19 points above second-placed Manchester United in what was a one-horse race for the most part.

In doing so Guardiola's men smashed a host of Premier League records, including those for most points (100), most goals (106) and biggest winning margin.


However, the Spaniard agrees that they must deliver consistent success if they are to truly be regarded the greatest in top-flight history.Â 

'We are the best? I'm not sure of that,' Guardiola admitted. 'I'm completely with the people who say that to be considered the best team in the history of English football you have to win more. We won one Premier League title.'

The former Barcelona boss also believes his team's success is largely down to the fact the squad is made up of such good characters. 'Last season and this season, one of our strong points is our locker room,' he added.

'The quality of the human beings they are, how they connect with the rest of the staff, that is I would say the main secret, that counts a lot to me.'

In doing so Guardiola's men smashed a host of Premier League records, including those for most points (100), most goals (106) and biggest winning margin.
