item.title: Exclusive interview with Christian Fuchs on his new FIFA esports team 'No Fuchs Given' and their first signing
item.description: As we previously reported, Leicester City defender Christian Fuchs is starting up his own esports team in FIFA 18 but is open to expanding into other games. The team will be called No Fuchs Given.
item.content:encoded:
As we previously reported, Leicester City defender Christian Fuchs is starting up his own esports team in FIFA 18 but is open to expanding into other games.

The team will be called 'No Fuchs Given' and will represent the former Premier League champion in video game tournaments around the world.

The Austrian international has already signed his first FIFA player, Chiang 'Hibidi' Wen Jun. The pro from Singapore has competed for over 10 years and is well-known for his confident personality.

Premier League teams such as Manchester City and West Ham already have high-profile FIFA players under their brand while others, such as Chelsea legend Ruud Gullit, choose to create academies in order to develop young players instead.

Hibidi isn't the only player under Fuch's name either but he wasn't ready to name any other signees just yet. When asked whether he'd focus on winning tournaments or developing talent, Fuch's promised to do both: 'We have one player that is a top talent and I can tell you his name because I'm very proud that we have him - Hibidi.

'He very professional and definitely the main figure in the whole academy start up but we have a couple others that we want to train and develop their skills to then hopefully over time qualify for more and more events.'

Fuchs is confident that he'll be able to help these players by using his own professional experience to teach them: 'I think there are some parallels between football and FIFA playing, because you have to have good nerves; you have to be good under pressure and when the pressure is on you have to stand with your men and just be strong enough mentally.

'Our main goal is to have the academy known for having players who qualify for tournaments and simply get better by working with us. Obviously we also want give some opportunities in terms of branding,Â we will definitely produce a lot of content with those players to give them as much exposure as possible and build their own name.'

The esports industry is beginning to catch the attention of many high-profile figures from traditional sports but Fuchs has been following for a while. He's had an interest in the scene for some time but it was his son who got him hooked: 'You can't escape the (esports) movement, it's simply developing really fast, growing very fast and wherever you look, wherever you go, you always see esports and literally my son got me more into it because he's watching it nonstop.

'My son follows so many Youtubers and Twitch streamers playing Fortnite and other games, I saw how big it's growing and decided I wanted to try to get in and create something long lasting. It's a very exciting project and I think we can achieve something great.'Â 

Fuchs told us they will stick with FIFA to start with but there is an interest in possibly expanding and the defender is personally a big fan of Overwatch and Fortnite. The team are still in the early stages of development but it's exciting to see what the experienced defender can bring to the world of esports.

item.title: Harry Kane signs new six-year deal with Tottenham worth Â£90MILLION as he doubles his salary and Spurs smash their pay structure to keep star striker
item.description: The England captain has had his Â£100,000-a-week salary doubled but with bonuses his earnings could rise to as much as Â£15m-a-year, putting him on a par with the best paid players in England.
item.content:encoded:
Harry Kane has become one of the Premier Leagueâ€™s top earners after signing a six-year deal at Tottenham that could be worth as much as Â£90million.

Only a fortnight after announcing a five-year contract for manager Mauricio Pochettino, Spurs chairman Daniel Levy has secured the services of his star striker. Deals for midfielders Dele Alli and Christian Eriksen are expected to follow.

â€˜Iâ€™m really excited, itâ€™s a proud day,â€™ said Kane. â€˜Iâ€™m looking forward to the future, to the new stadium first and foremost and just to keep progressing as a club.â€™


In 2016, Kane agreed a Â£110,000-a-week contract that runs until 2022. But as SpursÂ prepare to move into their new stadium, Levy realised that the England captain - who netted 41 goals for Spurs last season - needed to be on a par with the gameâ€™s big earners.

As revealed by MailOnline on Friday, Kaneâ€™s basic salary has nearly doubled to Â£200,000 a week with bonuses taking it close to Â£300,000 if the 24-year-old can score the goals that start to deliver silverware for Pochettinoâ€™s side.

It represents a huge coup for Tottenham, who need to keep their best players ahead of the move to their new ground.

It is also great timing for Kane only days before he leaves for Russia and this summerâ€™s World Cup with England.

HOW KANE'S WAGES HAVE GONE UPÂ 

AUG 2014 â€“ Â£20k (until 2019)

JAN 2015 â€“ Â£35k (until 2020)

DEC 2016 â€“ Â£100k (until 2020)

JUN 2018 â€“ Â£200k (until 2022)

Kane added: â€˜Itâ€™s been fantastic to consistently get in the Champions League, so Iâ€™m really excited to have another go at that and with the Premier League and FA Cup, weâ€™ll look to go as far as we can. For us as a club, itâ€™s just about keeping improving and weâ€™ll work hard to do that.

â€˜Iâ€™m obviously really excited about the World Cup coming up, so itâ€™s nice to get this done before that and Iâ€™m just looking to go out there and enjoy it now.

â€˜Itâ€™s been a great season. Like always, the aim is to try to improve, so hopefully I can do that this summer and obviously next season as well.â€™

Kaneâ€™s new deal comes on the back of Pochettino committing his future to the club with a five-year extension worth Â£8.5m a season. On the Argentineâ€™s new deal, Kane said: â€˜Itâ€™s a big boost and Iâ€™m looking forward to starting next season.â€™

Pochettino has already held face-to-face talks with Eriksen and Alli over their pending new deals.

Heung-min Son is also in discussions over a new contract, with the club hopeful of reaching an agreement to keep the Korean.

Tottenham have pledged at least Â£100m to help Pochettino build a squad capable of sustaining a title challenge next season.

The potential sales of Toby Alderweireld and Danny Rose will supplement Pochettinoâ€™s transfer budget. Spurs officials are working on a deal to land Anthony Martial from Manchester United and are interested in Ajax defender Matthijs de Ligt.

Tottenham have also been linked with Aston Villaâ€™s Â£40m-rated midfielder Jack Grealish, although they will try to do a cut-price deal with the cash-strapped Championship club.

item.title: EFL ditch extra-time from League Cup matches while penalty shootouts will revert to traditional format after the trial of ABBA during 2017-18
item.description: At the EFL's 2018 summer conference, clubs across the leagues have voted on a number of rule changes to next season's League Cup, most notably the removal of extra-time.
item.content:encoded:
The EFL have announced there will be no extra-time in League Cup matches next season.

At the EFL's 2018 summer conference, clubs have voted on a number of rule changes to next season's League Cup, most notably the removal of extra-time.

It was successfully argued that abolishing extra-time during the midweek matches would put to bed any additional fatigue issues.Â 


PROGRAMMESÂ 

EFL clubs are no longer required to compulsorily produce a match programme, the governing body has announced.

At the request of a number of clubs, the EFL addressed the issue of mandatory publication of a match programme at its summer conference.

And regulations were amended so the publication of a programme is no longer required.

The EFL said: "Mandatory publication of a programme was required due to a number of the EFL's partnership, sponsorship and opt in agreements.

"EFL clubs approved an amendment which allows clubs to opt out of providing advertising in match programmes on the basis it is replaced with other inventory.'

This means the clash will go straight to penalties if the scoreline cannot be separated during the 90 minutes.

However, penalty shootouts will revert to their normal format instead of ABBA, which was trialled throughout the 2017-18 campaign.Â 

EFL clubs were also given the option to get rid of the seeding arrangements that take place in the first two rounds of the draw.

The vote determined that this element will no longer feature, meaning round one will remain regionalised into North and South sections.

And finally, it was confirmed by the EFL that VAR (video assistant referee) will be used in the League Cup at Premier League grounds.

Manchester City will be defending their crown next season after beating Arsenal in the final at Wembley back in February.Â

item.title: Tottenham confident Harry Kane will agree long-term deal as they prepare to smash wage structure to keep him
item.description: Tottenham are increasingly confident that Harry Kane will put doubts over his future to bed by signing a long-term deal with the club. Kane can expect to earn more than double his Â£110,000 per week wages.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham are increasingly confident that Harry Kane will put doubts over his future to bed by signing a long-term deal with the club.

The 24-year-old has been linked with a big-money move to the likes of Real Madrid after emerging as one of the best strikers in the world over the last four seasons.

But he looks set to hand his boyhood club a huge boost by agreeing a new contract that will see him become by far and away their highest-earning player.


Kane can expect to take home more than double the Â£110,000 per week that he currently earns at Tottenham, bringing him on par with some of the Premier League's best-paid stars.

As they prepare to move into their new 62,000-seat stadium on the sight of White Hart Lane, the club are keen to start a new era in the right way by holding their biggest players to new deals.

Manager Mauricio Pochettino has already signed a new long-term contract while there is an ambition to extend the deals of Christian Eriksen, Dele Alli, Eric Dier and Jan Vertonghen before the start of next season.

Defender Toby Alderweireld and midfielder Mousa Dembele are expected to be sold in order to raise funds for what is likely to be a much-increased wage bill.Â 

Both have deals that expire in 2019 and have struggled to agree terms with Tottenham chiefs.

Kane heads into the World Cup as England captain looking to add to his two Premier League Golden Boots with an international equivalent.Â 

He has scored 135 goals over the four seasons for Tottenham and further eight in 15 England caps.

item.title: The regeneration of Marcus Rashford: Compared to his performances for Manchester United, Rashford looks a different player in an England shirt... he has the freedom to express himself
item.description: Marcus Rashford was the subject of Jose Mourinho's criticism after defeat at Brighton. But under Gareth Southgate and England, Rashford has the freedom to finally go and express himself.
item.content:encoded:
'You have the answer now when you ask "why always Lukaku?" We are probably not as good as people think individually.'

That was Jose Mourinho's sly dig at Marcus Rashford after Manchester United's defeat at Brighton in the Premier League last month. Rashford had started the game. Romelu Lukaku had not.

This was the same Rashford who lit up Elland Road on Thursday night with a stunning goal and all-round dazzling display in England's victory over Costa Rica.


Rashford launched Gareth Southgate's side into the lead with a 30-yard rocket as he spent all game terrorising the Costa Rican defence.

The 20-year-old has now given Southgate an unexpected decision to make over whether Rashford should start ahead of Raheem Sterling against Tunisia on June 18.

United fans even took to social media to urge Mourinho to sign this 'unknown Rashford lad'.

But how can his performance in an England shirt be so different to when he plays for United?

Just how much better was Rashford on Thursday night?

Almost twice as good. When you compare Rashford's performance against Costa Rica with his average over 90 minutes for United last season, the striker was almost doubly as effective for the Three Lions.

Rashford attempted 51 passes for England against Costa Rica, while his average for United was around 29 â€“ all at the same 78 per cent completion rate.

Crucially for an attacker, though, 32 of those passes at Elland Road ended in the final third. That's the area in which Rashford can have his biggest influence on the game. For United, there were less than 15.

Then there's attempted dribbles, the confidence to take on his man. Rashford attempted 10 of them against Costa Rica, as he frequently left his defenders chasing his heels. For United, he averaged just 5.4.

How is that possible?

In a word: freedom. Southgate gave Rashford much greater licence to roam and express himself.

Rashford started up front with Jamie Vardy against Costa Rica but in the withdrawn role that gave the United striker the freedom to come short, drift wide and do basically what he wanted while the Leicester man pressed high to push the defence back and leave more space for Rashford to thrive.

He does not get that under Mourinho, who is far more restrictive in his demands. Take Rashford's goal for a start. That came from right side. For United, Rashford is hardly ever there. Mourinho plays him mainly as a left-winger in a 4-2-3-1 and expects him to stay there.

According to Opta, only 19 per cent of Rashford's touches for United last season were on the right-hand side of the opposition half. Against Costa Rica, 32.5 per cent of them were there.

How do defensive duties affect Rashford?

That also has an effect on Rashford's ability to influence games. Again, it comes down to freedom within the respective systems.

Southgate's England play with wing-backs. It is their job to track back and stem the danger from opposition wingers. There's an extra centre-back too, which allows the right or left side of the back three to drift wide to lend a hand.

Rashford's defensive duties are, to the nearest decimal place, nil.

He has nowhere near that freedom under Mourinho. United's 4-2-3-1 means the wingers have to do the tracking back to help out the full-backs. It was for this very reason that Antonio Conte switched to 3-4-3 in his first season at Chelsea, to free up Eden Hazard from his defensive shackles.

Last season, nearly 20 per cent of Rashford's touches for United were in his own half. Against Costa Rica, just 7.5 per cent of them were, with 5 per cent still in the middle third of the pitch.

Unless you're David Beckham or Maynor Figueroa, having a fifth of your touches behind the halfway line is not going to help you score or create goals.

How do Southgate and Mourinho differ with Rashford?

'What pleased me most is that Marcus Rashford enjoyed his football tonight. He played with a real swagger,' said Southgate after the game on Thursday night.

The slight implication, perhaps, is that Rashford has not been enjoying it at United. As we have seen, Mourinho is not averse to throwing his players under the public bus when they do not meet his demands.

Southgate, though, appears to want to instil confidence in his young players, and give them the freedom to express themselves as they head into the World Cup to represent a country that has for so long been weighed down by pressure and expectation. This is allowing the likes of Rashford to shine.

Is there a defence for Mourinho?

Of course. Last night was just a warm-up game, with little other than experimentation and preparation on the line. And while Costa Rica are no mugs â€“ they are ranked 23rd in the Fifa rankings, ahead of Sweden and Austria â€“ they are still a side England should beat. And they did so comfortably.

Mourinho does not have that luxury. He cannot afford to experiment in the Premier League, especially when the noisy neigbours are charging off into the distance with the title and the plaudits.

Mourinho relies on his systems and his structures. But last night showed they also come at Rashford's expense.

item.title: Romelu Lukaku thanks Michael Carrick for one-on-one training sessions which made him a 'better player': 'I've had a lot of mentors in my young career and you're certainly one of them'
item.description: Romelu Lukaku has thanked Manchester United coach Michael Carrick for a series of one-to-one training sessions that the Belgian striker says have made him a 'better player.'
item.content:encoded:
Romelu Lukaku has thanked Manchester United coach Michael Carrick for a series of one-to-one training sessions that the striker says have made him a 'better player.'

Carrick, now retired, made just five appearances in the 2017-18 before announcing he was to become a member of the club's coaching staff come the end of the season.

And Lukaku has revealed that the former midfielder's transition from player to coach has been underway since January.


'Michael, I want to say a big thank-you for what you've done for me since January,' the Belgium international told MUTV.Â 

'I mean, not a lot of people will know that now we do video sessions after every single game to prepare for the next game and, like I've said, sometimes you think those video sessions don't help me going forward. But they do because I became a better player and I became a better version of myself.

'I think it also starts in training when we do the extra bits and the extra exercises to become a better player. Your eye for detail really helped me a lot more. I've had a lot of mentors in my young career and you're certainly one of them.'

Lukaku contributed 27 goals and nine assists in his first season at Old Trafford after joining from from Everton for a fee of Â£75million in the summer.Â 

The 25-year-old, who scored in Belgium's 3-0 win over Egypt on Wednesday, is currently gearing up for the World Cup in Russia where he will come up againstÂ  United team-mates Marcus Rashford, Jesse Lingard, Phil Jones and Ashley Young when his side face England in Group G.Â 

But the striker is already excited for next season with the Red Devils - and learning more from Carrick.

'It will be a joy to work with you in the staff next season,' he said. 'Hopefully, I can improve on the bits and pieces that you want me to improve on.

'Good luck after your career and I hope to see you in preseason so we can start a new chapter in the work that we do.'

item.title: Liverpool target Nabil Fekir can create and score just like Philippe Coutinho... but where will the Â£53m man fit in under Jurgen Klopp at Anfield?
item.description: JACK GAUGHAN: Liverpool are working hard to push through a deal for Lyonâ€™s Nabil Fekir before the World Cup starts next week. Sportsmail takes a look at where he might fit in under Jurgen Klopp.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool are working hard to push through a deal for Lyonâ€™s Nabil Fekir before the World Cup starts next week.

Fekir, who is in Didier Deschampsâ€™ France squad, is likely to cost in the region of Â£53million should Jurgen Klopp land his man.

Lyon insisted on Friday morning that there is still some way to go in negotiations and Sportsmail takes a look at the Liverpool target.


Why is Klopp so keen?

Twenty-one goals for Lyon last season is a fair indication, particularly given Fekirâ€™s primary role is to create. It was comfortably the 24-year-oldâ€™s best campaign of his career and came after being handed the captainâ€™s armband last summer as other high-profile stars departed the Groupama Stadium.

Fekir loves to dribble, capable of breaking down stubborn defences in one fell swoop and has an eye for unpicking locks with one pass. There is plenty of excitement about how he is developing in France.

Where would he fit in at Anfield?

A tricky question really. Fekir is most at home as a second striker, which makes Liverpoolâ€™s interest intriguing.

He can play across the forward line but hasnâ€™t found himself much deeper which, given Philippe Coutinho is still to be replaced directly, is where youâ€™d imagine a marquee signing to be stationed.

Perhaps Klopp is mulling over a change in shape, or manufacturing a clearly defined plan B, as they look to bring him to Merseyside. You might imagine Fekir taking up a few different roles within Kloppâ€™s attacking system should the move eventually go through.

Heâ€™s known for his flair, isnâ€™t he?

Definitely. Fekir scored an absolute stunner at the beginning of last season, just 10 minutes into a home game against Bordeaux, which will live long in the memory.

He picked the ball up midway inside Lyonâ€™s own half, driving away from a marker, before looking up to see the goalkeeper around 10 yards off his line. As Fekir hit halfway he somehow managed to skim an effort into the Bordeaux net, a shot that continued rising up until crossing the line. And it was on his weaker right foot.

Have there been any other suitors?

Yes, quite a few across Europe. Fekir is a Barcelona supporter and openly spoken about eventually playing at the Nou Camp, but it is Real Madrid who have kept a closer eye on him.

Former manager Zinedine Zidane said when discussing Franceâ€™s options in 2015: â€˜Nabil is an incredible player. He impressed me technically.â€™

Real are claimed to have had looked into the possibility of signing Fekir a year later, while a number of the continentâ€™s elite clubs have sent scouts to check on his progress.

But it hasnâ€™t been an easy journey?

Fekir joined Lyonâ€™s academy at 12, and has deep affection for the club. Yet they let him go at 14, Fekir apparently not physically strong enough, and he used that knock back to â€˜show them that they had made a mistakeâ€™.

Then there was the knee injury three years ago that put off some other interested parties. He missed seven months of the 2015-16 season, an injury sustained on his full international debut. Heâ€™s battled back from difficulties and is now ready to take the next step in a burgeoning career.

item.title: 'I think you will see better-rested players and see the fruits in the Champions League': Premier League winter break confirmed... and FA Cup fifth round will be played in midweek
item.description: FA chief executive Martin Glenn has confirmed a winter break will be written into Premier League rules from the 2019-20 season and should help boost England and Champions League hopes.
item.content:encoded:
Football Association chief executive Martin Glenn has confirmed a winter break will be written into Premier League rules from the 2019-20 season while FA Cup fifth round replays are to be scrapped.

The move for a break took a step closer this week when broadcaster BT Sport confirmed they had secured more live matches - including the split weekend - which all but announced a deal had been struck before official confirmation on Friday.

And for FA chief Glenn, there is a hope the move will see performances improve for club and country: 'I think you will see it in better-rested players and I think you will see the fruits of it in better Champions League knock-out performances and hopefully England players more rested for major tournaments.Â 


'If you were to look at other countries that do it, they say, their technical people say, itâ€™s as much the mental break as the physical one. There is nothing as intense as an English Premier League season, with 38 games at all count for something.Â 

HOW WILL IT WORK?

The break will not be in place next season and instead will be brought in for the 2019-20 campaign.

It will begin in February 2020 and five Premier League games will take on one weekend, the other five the next.

This gives teams a two-week break between matches in this period.Â 

All three divisions in the Football League will remain unchanged.Â 

FA Cup fifth round, usually played on the second weekend of February, will be moved to midweek with replays scrapped in favour of extra time and penalties.Â Â 

'The hope is that players will be more mentally rested, which makes them fresher, which you will see in, from an England point of view, hopefully going into end of season tournaments with a bit more verve and vim.

'And, as importantly, the reason the Premier League clubs are so keen on it is that in the Champions League knock-out stage, where weâ€™ve not been great over the past few years, hopefully that can help.'

The move brings the Premier League in line with rival leagues in Germany, France, Spain and Italy where they had had a long-standing tradition of a winter break.Â 

Sport Agenda revealed the discussions between the FA, Premier League and Football League edged closer to an agreement back in April.

The break for Premier League teams would be staggered over two weekends, with 10 teams playing one weekend and the other 10 the next weekend, giving each club a two-week rest.Â Â 

It will happen from February 2020 but the move would be structured to include matches every weekend. The break would not affect the Christmas and New Year festive fixtures.

Days between league matches: 14

Dates of break (including cup games): January 6-January 21

Days between league matches: 15

Dates of break (including cup games):Â December 20-January 6

Foreign managers and players have regularly made their feelings known on the benefits of introducing a winter break and the hope is that it can provide a boost to teams both domestically and in Europe.Â 

Glenn also touched on the decision to take away replays from the fifth round of the FA Cup - and play matches in midweek - in a bid to try and limit fixture conflicts.

But any suggestions that the same could eventually happen to the third and fourth round were quickly dismissed.Â 

'The FA Cup is not the same competition it was 20-odd years ago,' Glenn said. 'The Final used to go to replays. The FA Cup has always innovated, so it wasnâ€™t a huge argument.Â 

'We need to make the FA Cup relevant to todayâ€™s generation and also the big clubs. Reducing the number of replays, being a bit flexible about it, is all part of the justification.Â 

'There wonâ€™t be a change to third and fourth round replays. A core essence of the Cup is the giant-killing in the third and fourth rounds. Thatâ€™s absolutely core, what itâ€™s all about. Interestingly, itâ€™s what seems to be one of the reasons it is popular abroad. Everybody likes to see a giant-killing. That wonâ€™t change.'Â

The move took a step closer this week when broadcaster BT Sport confirmed they had secured more live matches - including the split weekendÂ which all but announced a deal had been struck to introduce one. And for FA chief Glenn, there is a hope the move will see performances improve for club and country: 'I think you will see it in better-rested players and I think you will see the fruits of it in better Champions League knock-out performances and hopefully England players more rested for major tournaments.

item.title: Crystal Palace sign goalkeeper Vicente Guaita on a free transfer from Getafe after his La Liga contract ends
item.description: Palace chairman Steve Parish said on the club's official website: 'We are delighted to sign one of La Liga's best goalkeepers and pleased that we beat off the competition for his signature.'
item.content:encoded:
Crystal Palace have announced the signing of Spanish goalkeeper Vicente Guaita from Getafe.

The 31-year-old will join on a free transfer on July 1 after his contract with the LaLiga club expires.

Palace chairman Steve Parish said on the club's official website: 'We are delighted to sign one of La Liga's best goalkeepers and pleased that we beat off the competition for his signature.


'We very much look forward to Vicente joining in pre-season training and helping us push on in the Premier League.'Â 

Palace had the option to sign Guaita for Â£3.5million last January and the keeper even passed a medical at Selhurst Park.

However they decided to wait until the summer to bring him in, with Wayne Hennessey and Julian Speroni sharing No 1 duties last season.

Guaita now looks set to become Palace's first choice keeper, with the club claiming they 'fought off interest from a host of top European clubs' to sign Roy Hodgson's first major summer acquisition.

He played for Getafe for four years and last season kept 12 clean sheets as they finished eighth in La Liga.Â

item.title: Leicester City complete Â£3.5m signing of centre back Jonny Evans from West Brom after activating release clauseÂ
item.description: Leicester have landed the Northern Ireland international for a cut-price fee after triggering a clause in Evansâ€™s contract following West Bromâ€™s relegation from the Premier League.
item.content:encoded:
Leicester City have completed the Â£3.5million signing of West Bromwich Albion defender Jonny Evans.

The 30-year-old completed his medical on Thursday and has signed a three-year deal with wages understood to be around Â£80,000-a-week at the King Power Stadium.

Leicester have landed the Northern Ireland international for a cut-price fee after triggering a clause in Evans's contract following West Brom's relegation from the Premier League.Â 


Evans told the club website:Â 'It's great to join and I'm happy it's all gone through. When this opportunity came up, it's one that I couldn't turn down. It's an ambitious club, the owners are ambitious and everyone wants to push the club forward.

'I hope that I can give lots to the team and the club. It's a great place to play football, the fans really get behind the team and the players are fantastic - these are all factors that made me want to sign for this football club.'

Evans has been a long-term target for Leicester, who tried to land the former Manchester United defender last summer but had multiple bids of up to Â£23m rejected.

Now, they have bagged the former Manchester United centre-back for nearly Â£20m less - although Leicester said the fee was undisclosed on their website - which they will pay Albion in two installments.

Evans had been expected to be at the heart of a tug-of-war this summer with both Manchester City and Arsenal having had offers rejected in the past year.

However, Leicester have been in talks with Evans' representatives for several weeks and were always confident of completing a deal.

Evans becomes Leicester's second signing of the transfer window following the Â£22m arrival of Porto right-back Ricardo Pereira.

Leicester boss Claude Puel is also hoping to sign Alexsandar Dragovic on a permanent deal. The Austria international spent last season on loan from Bayer Leverkusen.

Leicester are also leading the race to land highly-rated Norwich playmaker James Maddison in a deal worth around Â£20m.

Everton and Fulham are also said to be interested in the England under-21 international but Maddison is believed to prefer a move to Leicester to be closer to his family.

item.title: Arsenal and Tottenham lead race for Marseille star Morgan Sanson but Chelsea want 'to pursue other options'
item.description: He only joined the Ligue 1 outfit last summer, but has attracted admirers from the Premier League after an impressive debut season. Arsenal and Tottenham are favourite to sign him.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal and Tottenham are leading the race to land Marseille star Morgan Sanson, according to the player's agent.

The 23-year-old only joined the Ligue 1 outfit last summer, but has attracted admirers from the Premier League after an impressive debut season.

Sanson was a mainstay in Marseille's side last term, playing 53 times as they finished fourth and reached the Europa League final.


His agent is understood to have met with clubs to clarify their interest in him and has said Arsenal and Tottenham are both keen, but Chelsea are set to pursue other targets, having initially expressed a desire to sign him.

Speaking to Foot Mercato, Michael Manuello said: 'Chelsea will not go any further, they are looking at other things.

'Tottenham are looking at Morgan â€“ very much so. Arsenal are looking at him also, but I don't know what Unai Emery will want.'Â 

The new Arsenal boss has been handed a limited transfer budget and the club's recruitment chief Sven Mislintat has made defensive reinforcements their priority this summer.

Stephan Lichtsteiner signed from Juventus earlier this week and the club are expected to announce the Â£16million signing ofÂ Sokratis Papastathopoulos soon.

Emery is also understood to be keen on Nice midfielder Jean-Michael Seri, which could put Tottenham in pole position to sign Sanson.

item.title: Antonio Conte 'turns down Real Madrid job' as Italian wants to see out his contract at Chelsea leaving La Liga giants in disarray over new manager
item.description: Chelsea boss Antonio Conte has 'turned down the Real Madrid job' to remain at Stamford Bridge, according to reports in Italy, leaving the Spanish giants in disarray over their new boss.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea boss Antonio Conte has 'turned down the Real Madrid job' to remain at Stamford Bridge, according to reports in Italy.

Gianluca Di Marzio has said that while Conte is Madrid's primary target to replace Zinedine Zidane following his departure, the Italian manager 'wants to respect' his contract at Chelsea.

It comes as another blow to the La Liga side in their pursuit of a new manager having already been rejected by Mauricio Pochettino, Massimiliano Allegri and impressive young Hoffenheim boss Julian Nagelsmann.Â 


The Di Marzio report reveals one of Conte's biggest concerns is inheriting a squad that is not ready to meet his demanding regime.Â 

Conte also feels a 'coach with strong and decisive methods' would not be welcomed in a settled dressing room, which has seen him cool interest in the Champions League winners.Â 

Madrid are quickly running out of top-level options to replace Zinedine Zidane, who opted to step down from the role after winning three successive Champions League titles.Â 

Quick alternatives are available to them in Arsene Wenger, Guti and Michael Laudrup but the board are not satisfied that any of them would be popular or successful appointments.

Conte's desire to see out his Chelsea contract appears surprising given the strains on his relationship with the club hierarchy last season.

His own position was thrown into doubt despite winning the FA Cup final win and there is still a feeling that he is likely to depart for Laurent Blanc, Luis Enrique or Maurizio Sarri.Â Â

item.title: Manchester United and two Chinese Super League giants 'make Â£35m bids for Benfica star Anderson Talisca'
item.description: Manchester United have entered a bidding war with two unnamed Chinese Super League clubs for Benfica midfielder Anderson Talisca, according to reports in Portugal.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have entered a bidding war with two unnamed Chinese Super League clubs for Benfica midfielder Anderson Talisca.

Having already secured deals for Diogo Dalot and Fred, Jose Mourinho appears keen to keep adding to his side this summer.

But he faces a fight on his hands to secure the 24-year-old's signature, according to reports in Portugal.


O JogoÂ claim that the two Chinese clubs, who insist on remaining anonymous, have matched United's bid and have already laid out draft contracts.

The midfielder has spent the last two seasons on loan at Besiktas, but reportedly sees his future as lying away from Turkey.Â 

The Turkish club have an Â£18.4million option to buy Talisca, after he fired 37 goals in 78 games in his two years there.

The player's representatives have been in Lisbon to work on a deal, having just returned from China to hear their multi million-pound proposals.

Talisca is expected to meet with his representatives over the next few days and make a decision over his future.

Though he appears keen on a switch to Old Trafford and the Premier League, the riches of China could sway his decision.Â

item.title: West Ham United in talks to sign Yaya Toure as former Â£220,000-a-week Manchester City midfielder eyes reunion with Manuel Pellegrini
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Toure is discussing terms. He was paid Â£220,000 a week by City and would have to accept a pay cut at the London Stadium, but West Ham are confident of getting the deal done.
item.content:encoded:
West Ham have opened talks over a sensational move for Yaya Toure, who is very keen to play for Manuel Pellegrini again.

The 35-year-old Manchester City legend is discussing terms. He was paid Â£220,000 a week by City and would have to accept a pay cut at the London Stadium, but West Ham are confident of getting the deal done.

Under Pellegrini, Toure won the Premier League title with City in 2013-14 â€” scoring 20 goals that campaign â€” and collected two League Cups.


The midfielder worked at Fulham's training ground on Thursday as he prepares for Sunday's Soccer Aid match.

Toure made waves earlier this week when he claimed City manager Pep Guardiola does not like picking African players.

He said: 'Pep did everything to spoil my last season. He was cruel with me. It got to the point where I asked myself if it was because of my colour.'

Toure made only one Premier League start last season, in City's final home fixture against Brighton, and there is a sense he wants to prove he can still compete in the top flight with West Ham.Â

item.title: Liverpool close in on Â£53m deal for Lyon playmaker Nabil Fekir as Reds make breakthrough with top target
item.description: Liverpool are on the brink of completing a Â£53million deal to make Nabil Fekir their second signing of the summer. The Reds have made a breakthrough with their number one target for the summer window.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool are on the brink of completing a Â£53million deal to make Nabil Fekir their second signing of the summer.

The France international has been Jurgen Klopp's prime target for the window, as he believes Fekir will prove to be the ideal long-term replacement for Philippe Coutinho and Liverpool's manager wanted the deal wrapped up before the World Cup, as does France national coach Didier Deschamps, whose side face the United States on Sunday.Â Â 

Lyon had taken a tough stance, with president Jean Michel Aulas indicating on Thursday that negotiations had reached a standstill.


'We have not set a base price because we have not discussed this yet,' said Aulas.

And on Friday, they took that notion a step further with a strong statement via their official Twitter account.Â 

'Olympique Lyonnais categorically denies the false information disseminated by many media about the transfer of Nabil Fekir to Liverpool,' it reads.

'In this period of transfers where the slightest rumour is often presented as a reality, Olympique Lyonnais recalls that only the information disseminated by the club on its website is authentic.'

However, Liverpool Sporting Director Michael Edwards has remained in discussions in an attempt to push the deal through and the club's willingness to get business completed has been illustrated by the fact members of Liverpool's medical team are waiting to fly to Paris to complete a medical.Â 

Should there be no complications, Fekir - who scored 23 goals for Lyon last season and was watched by Manchester City representatives at a Europa League game against Everton - would become the third player worth more than Â£50million Liverpool have signed in the space of eight months, following on from Naby Keita (Â£52.5m from RB Leipzig) and Virgil Van Dijk (Â£75m from Southampton).

It would also take their spending for this window to close to Â£100m after their initial purchase of Brazil midfielder Fabinho from Monaco.

Klopp would also like to sign Alisson Becker, the Roma goalkeeper who would cost a world record fee for a player in his position. If the Italian side, who have some financial issues to address, show a willingness to do business, Liverpool would move swiftly for the Brazil No 1 who is also coveted by Real Madrid.

Klopp, in an ideal world, would want the bulk of his business done before Liverpool return to pre-season training on July 2 - their first fixture is the following Saturday at Chester - and the German does not want to end up in a position like at the end of the last campaign when they ran out of attacking options.

It explains why they are considering a move for Stoke forward Xherdan Shaqiri, who has a release clause in his contract that would mean Liverpool could potentially sign him for Â£12million.

item.title: Robert Pires keen on joining new Arsenal boss Unai Emery's coaching staff: 'I could help... I could be a bridge between him and the players'
item.description: Robert Pires, a World Cup winner in 1998, trains regularly with the first-team squad and feels he could help Unai Emery launch a new era at the Emirates Stadium following Arsene Wenger's departure.
item.content:encoded:
Former Arsenal midfielder Robert Pires believes he would be a good fit in new boss Unai Emery's backroom team.

Pires, 44, spent six years with the Gunners before leaving for Villarreal in 2006 and has maintained a close connection with the club.

The Frenchman, a World Cup winner in 1998, trains regularly with the first-team squad and feels he could help Emery launch a new era at the Emirates Stadium following Arsene Wenger's departure.


'If I join Unai Emery's staff, I think it should be good for me, and I hope it should be good for Unai Emery,' Pires told ESPN FC at Arsenal's new Puma kit launch in London.

'I could be like a bridge between him and the players. Because I know the players. For two years I have trained with the guys. So all of them, they respect me.

'And I respect the players, I was an ex-player. So the relationship between the players and me is good. That's why I think I can help Unai Emery.'

Pires never had an official coaching role under Wenger, but hopes to keep training regularly with the Gunners and to speak with Emery.

'I don't know what will happen in a couple of months, but if I can train with the guys I will, because for me it's very important,' Pires added.

'With Arsene Wenger it was easy to keep fit and to still train with the first team. So now, I need to talk with the new manager.'

Retired skipper Per Mertesacker spent last season preparing to take up his new role as Arsenal's academy director this summer and another former Gunner, Swede Freddie Ljungberg, will also become part of the academy coaching set-up.

item.title: Tottenham extend contract of 'reliable custodian' Michel Vorm until 2019
item.description: Dutch international was out of contract this summer, but will now remain in north London as deputy to Hugo Lloris. Vorm made 11 appearances across all competitions last term.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham have activated their option to extend goalkeeper Michel Vorm's contract until 2019.

The Holland international joined from Swansea in 2014 and has made a total of 43 appearances for Spurs.

Vorm played 11 games in all competitions last term, with just one of those coming in the Premier League.


The 34-year-old has been understudy to captain Hugo Lloris since arriving from the Liberty Stadium and his game-time is likely to be limited again next season.

A statement on the club's website read: 'Since joining us from Swansea City in 2014, he has proved to be a reliable custodian whenever called upon.'

The former Utrecht stopper, who has won 15 Holland caps, was out of contract this summer before signing new terms with Mauricio Pochettino's side.

item.title: Borussia Dortmund sign Thomas Delaney for Â£17.5m as midfielder reveals he had Premier League offers
item.description: Borussia Dortmund have signed Danish midfielder Thomas Delaney from Werder Bremen on a four-year contract, the Bundesliga sides announced on Thursday.
item.content:encoded:
Borussia Dortmund have signed Danish midfielder Thomas Delaney from Werder Bremen on a four-year contract, the Bundesliga sides announced on Thursday.

Neither club revealed the financial details of the deal but reports in the German media said Dortmund paid around Â£17.5 million for the 26-year-old.

'I've always wanted to play in the Premier League at some stage and I've had offers too... but when Dortmund came calling, I didn't have to think twice,' Delaney told Dortmund's website.


'For me, BVB are one of the top 10 clubs in Europe and one of the top two clubs in Germany and the stadium is definitely the best in all of Europe.'

Dortmund sporting director Michael Zorc said Delaney's physical presence would boost the club's midfield.

'Delaney is a strong player in terms of his physicality and his character, as well as being an excellent fit for our team thanks to his open manner and fierce will to win,' he said.

Delaney played 32 league games for Bremen last season, scoring three goals and providing five assists.Â 

He is Dortmund's third acquisition in the close season after they signed goalkeeper Marwin Hitz from Augsburg and midfielder Marius Wolf from Eintracht Frankfurt.

item.title: Tottenham leading race to sign Aston Villa's Â£40m-rated star Jack GrealishÂ
item.description: Mauricio Pochettino believes Jack Grealish's skill and high energy fits the profile he wants for his squad and the 22-year-old is keen on developing alongside the likes of Dele Alli and Harry Kane.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham are leading the chase for Aston Villa's Â£40million-rated midfielder Jack Grealish.

Manager Mauricio Pochettino believes Grealish's skill and high energy fits the profile he wants for his squad and the 22-year-old is keen on developing alongside the likes of Dele Alli and Harry Kane.

Grealish has plenty of interest from other Premier League clubs including Leicester City, Everton and West Ham but his preference is understood to be Tottenham.


The main obstacle though is Villa's seemingly high valuation of Â£40m.

The Championship side's perilous financial position has left them vulnerable to offers for their best players but they remain defiant that they will not sell for under their market value.

Rivals believe that is unrealistic and are anticipating that prices will come down as pressure mounts on their finances.

Apart from Grealish, Villa also expect offers for defender James Chester, Andre Green, Keinan Davis and Jonathan Kodjia.

Villa missed a tax payment on Friday, although they have resolved the immediate problem with HMRC, and need to raise money in the long term.Â 

It is understood they asked Burnley to bring forward payment of an instalment on Ashley Westwood's transfer to cover wages and that they scrapped plans to fork out Â£20,000 on club suits for the play-off final.

item.title: 'The club is happy and I am happy in the club': Sergio Aguero insists his future lies at Manchester City and wants to build on 'really good' relationship with Pep Guardiola
item.description: Aguero scored 21 Premier League goals as City eased to the title by 19 points last season. However he is no longer as vital to the team and Gabriel Jesus is often chosen instead.
item.content:encoded:
Sergio Aguero insists he is extremely happy at Manchester City and reveals his relationship with manager Pep Guardiola is 'really good'.Â 

Aguero notched 30 goals in all competitions as City eased to the Premier League title by 19 points last season.

However, the Argentine is no longer as vital to the team as he once was and often Gabriel Jesus is chosen to spearhead the attack instead.


Despite that Aguero, who is expected to play a crucial role for Argentina at this summer's World Cup in Russia, is adamant he sees his future at the Etihad Stadium.Â Â 

'It is really good, we were very clear when we saw each other,' Aguero said in an interview on El Chiringuito de Jugones.Â 

'I try to do my job and he does his job. Obviously, he is always fine with me. I am happy how the season ended.Â 

'The club is happy, and I am happy in the club. I hope to stay until the end of my contract [in 2020].

'I think every year [there are rumours] â€¦ maybe, a few more rumours this year with Atletico. With Madrid as well, since I left Atletico, it sounds like Madrid, Madrid, Madrid. Well, I'm a City player.

'But it is always good that other teams are interested. What I have to do right now is to be focused on the World Cup, and after that, focused on City.'Â 

Once his City deal expires Aguero has announced his intention to rejoin former club Independiente in Buenos Aires where he began his career before leaving for Atletico in 2006.Â 

Aguero broke City's scoring record when he netted his 178th goal for the club in November's 4-2 win over Napoli. He has since moved onto 199.

item.title: Premier League executive chairman Richard Scudamore to step down at the end of the year following 20-year tenure which made division richest in all of world football
item.description: Richard Scudamore knows he is leaving at the right time, having completed another domestic TV rights deal and brokered a peace formula over distribution of overseas money.
item.content:encoded:
Richard Scudamore shocked 20 clubs and his Premier League staff on Thursday by announcing he will quit as executive chairman in December after 20 years at the helm.

An emotional Scudamore announced he was going after the first day of the PL summer meeting and received a standing ovation.Â 

Scudamore, the most influential figure in English football, knows he is leaving at the right time, having completed another domestic TV rights deal and brokered a peace formula over the distribution of overseas money.Â 


The canny Scudamore realised life would only become more difficult for him when the Big Six clubs started fighting for a heftier share of the TV pot last year.

WORLD FOOTBALL'S RICHEST DIVISIONS

English Premier League -Â Â£4.5 billion (â‚¬5.2bn)

Spanish La Liga - Â£2.5billion (â‚¬2.9bn)

German Bundesliga - Â£2.3billion (â‚¬2.7bn)

Italian Serie A - Â£1.7billion (â‚¬2bn)

French Ligue 1 - Â£1.4billion (â‚¬1.6bn)Â Â 

Â 

Figures collected by Deloitte, in accordance with declared revenues of respective European leaguesÂ 

He has found a solution this time, but the top clubs want to dictate PL business rather than let Scudamore call the tune, as he has done for two decades.

Scudamore and his advisers take the credit for maximising global interest in the Premier League with ever-increasing TV deals. HeÂ will be a hard act to follow and certainly there is no one at the Premier League capable of taking over.

He said: â€˜Itâ€™s an absolute privilege to have been allowed to enjoy this role for so long. It is too much fun to be called a job.

â€˜I am sure (the PLâ€™s broadcast partners) will forgive me for singling out Sky for special recognition. Back in 1992 they were the catalyst for the start of the Premier League journey and have backed us all the way since.â€™

Scudamore, who will be 60 next year and suffered a heart scare in 2014, intends to spend more time with his family, but will not retire. He will not be short of offers.

item.title: Middlesbrough defender Ben Gibson attracting interest from host of Premier League clubs
item.description: The 25-year-old had a disappointing end to the season as his club missed out on promotion via the play-offs. Manager Tony Pulis is open to offloading a number of his squad to raise funds for rebuilding.
item.content:encoded:
Middlesbrough defender Ben Gibson is attracting interest from a number of Premier League clubs.

The 25-year-old had a disappointing end to the season as his club missed out on promotion via the play-offs.

Manager Tony Pulis is open to offloading a number of his squad to raise funds for rebuilding and Gibson will attract substantial offers.


Southampton, Everton, Leicester City and West Ham have all posted initial interest as they weigh up targets for the summer.

Gibson was called up to the England squad last year but Boro's relegation from the Premier League effectively put paid to hopes of making the World Cup squad.

West Ham also have an interest in Gibson's team-mate Adama Traore.

item.title: 'The player isn't for sale': Steaua Bucharest president slaps Â£26m price tag on teen Dennis Man as he 'reveals Manchester United approach'
item.description: Man has shown great potential early on in his career and it has even caught the attention of United manager Jose Mourinho, but Becali insisted his young winger is not for sale.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have expressed an interest inÂ Steaua Bucharest teenager Dennis Man, the club's presidentÂ Gigi BecaliÂ has revealed.

Man, only 19 years old, made his debut for the Romania side in 2016 and has gone on to become one of their key figures, having a hand in 12 goals last season.

He has shown great potential early on in his career and has even caught the attention of United managerÂ Jose Mourinho. However,Â according to the Metro Becali insisted his young winger is not for sale.


MAN'S EARLY CAREER

Dennis Man made his professional debut for Romanian second tierÂ UTA Arad in August 2015.

He went on to make 30 appearances and scoring 12 goals before earning a move toÂ Steaua Bucharest in 2016.

He has since become a key member of their squad, featuring in 24 first division games last season and scoring 12 goals.Â 

Becali said: 'Manchester United asked me about Dennis Man and I want â‚¬30million (Â£26m).

'I know that they won't pay this amount, but the player isn't for sale.'

The report has even suggested that Mourinho was spotted inÂ Bucharest Airport earlier this week and attended Romania's 2-0 victory over Finland at theÂ Ilie Oana Stadium on Tuesday night.

Man appeared as a second-half substitute in the 64th minute of the friendly but struggled to have an impact on the game.

Mourinho is a man on a mission this summer, determined to close the gap on rivals Manchester City after they ran away with the Premier League title last season.

United have confirmed the signings of Fred - for Â£52million - and Diogo DalotÂ from Porto for Â£17.4million this week alone.

'Diogo is an extremely talented young defender with all the qualities to quickly become a great player for this club,' Mourinho said.Â

item.title: 'I don't think anything will change before the World Cup': Lyon president Jean-Michel Aulas reveals Nabil Fekir's transfer to Liverpool isn't close
item.description: Lyon president Jean-Michel Aulas has provided an update on Liverpool's pursuit of midfielder Nabil Fekir. The 24-year-old is known to be interested in joining up with Jurgen Klopp and the Reds.
item.content:encoded:
Lyon president Jean-Michel Aulas has provided an update on Liverpool's pursuit of midfielder Nabil Fekir - and it's not good news for the Merseysiders.

The 24-year-old has interest from a number of clubs but is known to be interested in joining up with Jurgen Klopp and his Champions League finalists.

ButÂ Aulas has revealed that the transfer is not close and is unlikely to happen before the start of the World Cup next Thursday.


'The deal is at a standstill. Nothing has happened,' he told the club's official website.

'The whole thing will certainly not be completed during the World Cup, and I don't think anything will change before it.

'We haven't set a starting price because we haven't discussed that yet.'

Liverpool have wasted no time in strengthening their midfield ranks having already signedÂ Fabinho from Monaco andÂ Naby Keita from RB Leipzig.

Fekir scored 23 goals and provided eight assists in 40 appearances during the 2017-18 campaign at the Ligue 1 side.

item.title: 'I'd never say never to anything:' Dele Alli refuses to rule out Tottenham exit in the future but insists he is happy with the club's direction
item.description: Dele Alli has refused to rule out a move away from Tottenham in the future but the England international insists that there's no better place for him to be at the moment.
item.content:encoded:
Dele Alli has refused to rule out a move away from Tottenham in the future but insists that there's no better place for him to be at the moment.

The 22-year-old has caught the eye of some of Europe's biggest clubs since bursting on to the scene with MK Dons three years ago, becoming a mainstay in the Spurs and England squad in the process.

Real Madrid and Barcelona have all been linked with the attacker and he has refused to rule out a move abroad in the coming years, if they made an offer for him.


'I'd never say never to anything,' he told ES Magazine. 'You never know what is going to happen in football.

'I have still got a few years left on my contract. We have got a young team, a young manager, a new stadium, so it is a great place to be at the minute.

'All the players can see the way the club is heading. But you can't look into the future too much as it takes the pleasure out of now.'

Dele is keeping his focus on his first World Cup appearance, as England face Tunisia in their first group game of the tournament on June 18.

'I am over the moon to be selected for the World Cup, it is what you dream of as a kid,' he added.

'We have got a great manager and an ambitious young squad. I am confident we can have a successful tournament.'

item.title: 'Bullies 1 Football 0': Furious fans hit out at new TV deals as they prepare to be hit in the pocket AGAINÂ
item.description: Football fans up and down the country have lashed out at the Premier League following their decision to allow its elite clubs to secure a larger share of TV money.
item.content:encoded:
Football fans up and down the country have lashed out at the Premier League following their decision to allow its elite clubs to secure a larger share of TV money.

In what has been heralded as a small victory for the 'Big Six' it is seen as a catastrophic blow for supporters outside of that bubble.

It was announced on Thursday that clubs have voted to tinker with the international television revenue share from 2019, with more emphasis placed on teams finishing higher up the league.


The news will be viewed as success in boardrooms of Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United, Tottenham, Manchester City and Liverpool.

However, fans outside those teams are less than impressed.

'Bullies 1 Football 0. Premier League overseas rights to be split based on league position,' tweeted @KieranMaguire. 'I'm sure US-owned #MUFC #LFC #Arsenal, Abu Dhabi-owned #MCFC, Russian-owned #ChelseaFC & Bahamas-owned #THFC will do what's best for the English Premier League with the extra money.'

@CheadleWhite was another to express his disappointment with 'Again a deal to screw over 80% of clubs allowing the rest to get richer'.

'Unnecessarily taking money away from the smaller clubs and giving it to clubs who already have more than enough. Great move @premierleague,' wrote @Bruskk_.

This announcement was the final straw for many supporters following news just an hour earlier on Thursday that Amazon has bought its first Premier League television rights package as the online giant launches a threat against Sky Sports and BT Sport in a ground-breaking shift in domestic broadcasting.

In the division of Premier League TV rights for the 2019 to 2022 period two packages were still to be purchased following the initial bidding phase in February.

Amazon has now secured one of the remaining packages with BT Sport taking the other.

The three-way tussle has angered fans who believe they are being fleeced for every penny to watch the game they love.

'If you want to watch every Premier League game on TV from next year youâ€™ll need: Sky Sports, BT Sport, Amazon and A hell of a lot of money' slammed @unitedkanamixer.

@TheShaw2009 blasted: 'So, to watch football on TV from 2019-20, you will need subscriptions to Sky, BT Sport and now Amazon Prime. Let me just shake some cash from the money tree outside #Football #TVRights #PremierLeague.'

@SimplyCostaÂ wrote: 'So the premier league have sold games to Sky sports, BT SportÂ and now Amazon but then they wonder why people try to illegally stream matches? Imagine all the money youâ€™ll have to spend to watch these games.'

@RealKevinPalmer was as equally as exasperated as he tweeted: 'So now Sky, BT Sport and Amazon will screening live Premier League football....

'Canâ€™t imagine any fan will sign up for all three, but the money is all that matters to the big clubs now.'

THE BIG MONEY DEAL AND HOW IT WILL AFFECT FOOTBALL FANSÂ 

2019-22 PREMIER LEAGUE UK BROADCASTING RIGHTS

BT SPORT â€“ Â£975million

32 â€“ matches at 12.30pm on Saturday

15 â€“ matches from two midweek fixture programmes

5 - matches from the split weekendÂ 

SKY SPORTS â€“ Â£3.579bn

32 â€“ matches at 5.30pm on Saturday

8 â€“ matches at 7.45pm on Saturday

32 â€“ matches at 2pm on Sunday

32 â€“ matches at 4pm on Sunday

24 â€“ matches at either 8pm on Monday or 7.30pm/8pm on Friday

AMAZON - cost undisclosed

20 â€“ matches on Boxing Day and from one midweek fixture programme

HOW MUCH WILL IT COST FANS?Â 

Sky Sports Customers:

Sky Sports - Â£38 a month

BT Sport - Â£27.99

Amazon Prime - Â£5.99 a month

Total - Â£71.98Â  a month /Â Â£863.76 a year

BT Sport Customers:

BT Sport - from Â£6 a month plus additional broadband cost

Sky Sports - Â£27.50 a month

Amazon Prime - Â£5.99 a month

Total - Â£39.49 a month /Â 473.88 a year (plus additional broadband cost)

HOW DO YOU ACCESS AMAZON PRIME?

Customers can access Amazon Prime through their television using FireTV or a FireTV Stick.

It is also possible to access the service through a smart television using the Prime Video app.

Subscribers can log in and watch content directly from the Amazon Prime website.

Users can also watch on their smartphones using the Prime Video app as well as games consoles and other streaming media players such as Apple TV andÂ Roku.

item.content:encoded:
BT Sport have confirmed that there will be a mid-season break with the first to beÂ  implemented during the 2019-20Â Premier League season.

The broadcaster confirmed on Thursday that they had won the live rights to an additional 20 Premier League matches and also announced a slight change to the TV schedule for three seasons from 2019 until 2022.

In February, five of the seven packages were sold to the highest bidder, with Sky Sports claiming four of them and subsequently winning 128 matches per season, while BT took the other one on offer worth 32 matches.


EUROPEAN WINTER BREAKS

La LigaÂ 

Dates of break (including cup games): December 23-January 3

Days between league matches: 14

BundesligaÂ 

Dates of break (including cup games): December 20-January 12

Days between league matches: 25

Serie A

Dates of break (including cup games): January 6-January 21

Days between league matches: 15

Ligue 1

Dates of break (including cup games):Â December 20-January 6

Days between league matches: 22

Russian Premier League

Dates of break (including cup games): December 11 - March 2

Days between league matches: 90

Â 

Based on dates from last season.

BT moved yet again on Thursday though, and will be the first to show several midweek Premier League matches on the same evening and also confirmed teams will be granted their wishes for a mid-season winter break.

The change will see one set of matchday fixtures split across two weekends, which will result in five fixtures played on each.

BT purchased 'Package G' which entitles them to 15 matches from two midweek fixture periods and five from the split weekend.Â 

It is likely, then, that clubs could be handed a two-week break from Premier League action as a result of this.

BT claimed one of the last two remaining packages to take their total spend to Â£885m before Amazon entered the war for top flight television rights by picking up the final one.

It entitlesÂ Amazon to broadcast either 20 matches from one Bank Holiday and one midweek fixture programme or 20 matches from two midweek sets of fixtures.

The creation of mid-season winter break has long been demanded due to the demands of a lengthy league season, accompanied by numerous FA Cup, League Cup and European fixtures. It has been argued that it leaves players exhausted come May, with many linking the ruthless scheduling of games to the demise of England teams at major tournaments.

Arguments have also been made for English clubs, claiming they are at a disadvantage when it comes to European competition, given that Spain, Italy and Germany offer their leagues a winter break.

item.title: Premier Leagueâ€™s elite clubs secure larger share of TV money in a massive victory for the â€˜big sixâ€™
item.description: Clubs have voted to tinker with the international television revenue share from 2019, with more emphasis placed on teams finishing higher up the league.
item.content:encoded:
The Premier Leagueâ€™s elite clubs secured a larger share of TV money on Thursday in a massive victory for the â€˜big sixâ€™.

Clubs have voted to tinker with the international television revenue share from 2019, with more emphasis placed on teams finishing higher up the league.

The news will be viewed as success in boardrooms of Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United, Tottenham, Manchester City and Liverpool.


A Premier League statement read: â€˜The maximum a club can receive in total central revenue payments is 1.8 times the amount received by the lowest-earning club.â€™

Regardless, it represents a shift from the norm and creates a further wedge between the big six and others in the top division.

They needed 14 of the 20 Premier League clubs to vote in their favour of a TV share based largely on league position.

HOW IT WORKS

â€˜The maximum a club can receive in total central revenue payments is 1.8 times the amount received by the lowest-earning club.â€™

For example if the lowest-earning club earns Â£10million, the maximum the top-earning club can receive is Â£18m.Â Â 

Despite some surprising support from clubs lower down the league, the giants were only able to gain a slight addition to their pot.

The numbers still pale into insignificance when compared to La Liga, Serie A, Bundesliga and Ligue 1, with a maintained share of at least double that of the other big European leagues.

Richard Scudamore added: â€˜When the Premier League was formed in 1992 nobody could have envisaged the scale of international growth in the competition which exists now.

â€˜Back then the clubs put in place a revenue sharing system that was right for the time and has served the League well, enabling them to invest and improve in all areas.

â€˜This new agreement will continue that trend with a subtle change that further incentivises on-pitch achievement and maintains the Premier Leagueâ€™s position as the most equitable in Europe in terms of sharing central revenues.

â€˜By coming together and agreeing this change, the clubs have provided a platform for the future success of the League for many years ahead.â€™Â

item.title: Premier League TV revolution as Amazon buys package of matches to launch threat against Sky Sports and BT Sport â€“ meaning fans will have to pay a minimum of Â£860 a year to see all games
item.description: CHARLES SALE: US tech giants Amazon have dipped their toes into the Premier League waters by agreeing a three-year deal to stream 20 Premier League matches a season.
item.content:encoded:
TheÂ richest football league in the world now has the current most profitable business in company history as one of its TV partners.

US tech giants Amazon have dipped their toes into the Premier League waters by agreeing a three-year deal to stream 20 Premier League matches a season.

This is a considerable coup for the top flight and its departing executive chairman Richard Scudamore.


Amazon are understood to have only paid a cut-price Â£30million a year for broadcasting simultaneously a full round of midweek fixtures in early December followed by a full festive programme â€” one of two unwanted packages that went unsold at the Premier League rights auction last February when bids failed to reach the reserve price.

Disappointingly, for the first time the Premier League failed to reveal how much Amazon had paid when all their previous domestic deals had been transparent. It was claimed that there was no regulatory obligation to announce the Amazon numbers officially.

With BT Sport paying Â£90m for the other package, total domestic revenues are estimated at Â£4.65bn. That figure is around Â£450m less than the current Â£5.1bn domestic rights deal but the shortfall will easily be covered by the increase in overseas revenues.

And having Amazon on board means the Premier League have every opportunity over the next three years of attracting the Seattle-based company to invest a lot more when the TV rights are sold again in another competitive market.

Amazon will also stream a weekly highlights show and have begun preliminary talks about additional football programming to support their new content which starts in the 2019-2020 season. The football will be shown on Amazon Prime Video in the UK at no extra cost to Prime members.

Jay Marine, vice-president of Prime Video in Europe, said: â€˜We are always looking to add more value to Prime and we are delighted to now offer live Premier League matches. Over those two December fixture rounds, Prime members will be able to watch every team.â€™

Scudamore said: â€˜Amazon is an exciting new partner for the Premier League and we are very pleased they have chosen to invest in these rights. Prime Video will be an excellent service on which fans can consume live Premier League football including a full round of fixtures for the first time.â€™

It was widely predicted that the two packages left on the shelf for four months would go to Sky and BT for next to nothing, with Scudamore being blamed for mis-reading the market and over-estimating the interest of the big digital beasts â€”Amazon, Facebook and Netflix â€” having devised the two 20-match packages with online streaming in mind.

But Scudamore tweaked Package G to include five weekend matches from the two split weekends to accommodate the winter break. And that helped BT agree to pay Â£90m and increase their output to 52 matches per season, for which they have paid a total of Â£975m over three years.

Sky, who are content with their four prime packages of 128 matches a season costing Â£3.5bn over three years, made no bid for either package. But BT were also in the market, allowing Scudamore to have competitive bidding when all had seemed lost. To complete Scudamoreâ€™s good day at the Premier Leagueâ€™s summer meeting in Harrogate, the clubs quickly brought an end to their impasse over the distribution of overseas rights income.

Within half an hour of the summit start, a new formula was announced whereby foreign rights money, in excess of the Â£3bn from the current deal, will be shared among the clubs on a sliding scale based on league position â€” this will be capped at the top club receiving 80 per cent more than the team who finish bottom.

The formula was based on central revenues from 2017-18, showing the highest earner Manchester United making 60 per cent more than the lowest earner Stoke.

THE BIG MONEY DEAL AND HOW IT WILL AFFECT FOOTBALL FANSÂ 

2019-22 PREMIER LEAGUE UK BROADCASTING RIGHTS

BT SPORT â€“ Â£975million

32 â€“ matches at 12.30pm on Saturday

15 â€“ matches from two midweek fixture programmes

5 - matches from the split weekendÂ 

SKY SPORTS â€“ Â£3.579bn

32 â€“ matches at 5.30pm on Saturday

8 â€“ matches at 7.45pm on Saturday

32 â€“ matches at 2pm on Sunday

32 â€“ matches at 4pm on Sunday

24 â€“ matches at either 8pm on Monday or 7.30pm/8pm on Friday

AMAZON - cost undisclosed

20 â€“ matches on Boxing Day and from one midweek fixture programme

HOW MUCH WILL IT COST FANS?Â  *at current prices

Sky Sports Customers:

Sky Sports - Â£38 a month

BT Sport - Â£27.99 a month

Amazon Prime - Â£5.99 a month

Total - Â£71.98Â  a month /Â Â£863.76 a year

Sky customers will be able to add BT Sport to their subscription from early 2019 but the cost of a complete sports package has not been revealed

BT Sport Customers:

BT Sport - from Â£6 a month plus additional broadband cost

Sky Sports - Â£27.50 a month

Amazon Prime - Â£5.99 a month

Total - Â£39.49 a month / Â£473.88 a year (plus additional broadband cost)

HOW DO YOU ACCESS AMAZON PRIME?

Customers can access Amazon Prime through their television using FireTV or a FireTV Stick.

It is also possible to access the service through a smart television using the Prime Video app.

Subscribers can log in and watch content directly from the Amazon Prime website.

Users can also watch on their smartphones using the Prime Video app as well as games consoles and other streaming media players such as Apple TV andÂ Roku.

Â 

Amazon's plunge into sports broadcastingÂ 

Amazon is becoming an increasing force in sport broadcasting and already have the rights for ATP and US Open tennis.

It alsoÂ commissioned a Â£10m fly-on-the-wall documentary inside Manchester City during the title-winning campaign.Â 

American Football is also broadcast on the website with the NFL renewing its deal to show Thursday night matches for two more seasons in April.

Amazon also produces a sporting documentary series titled 'All or Nothing'.Â 

The programme takes viewers behind the scenes of three major American sports teams. Series have been focused on theÂ Arizona Cardinals,Â the Los Angeles Rams andÂ the Dallas Cowboys.Â 

Said to be worth a staggering Â£521.98billion in February, Amazon chief executiveÂ Jeff Bezos claimed the Prime streaming service has more than 100 million subscribers worldwide in April.

item.title: Arsenal legends Robert Pires and Ray Parlour launch club's new away kit in 'peacoat navy'... but the fans aren't too happy with final Puma design
item.description: Arsenal launched their home kit last monthÂ - the club's first release under their new manager Unai Emery - and have now revealed their away kit that will come in 'peacoat navy'.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal have launched their new away kit for the 2018-19 season with the help of club legends Robert Pires and Ray Parlour.Â 

Former team-mates Parlour and Pires joined forces with Arsenal Women stars Alex Scott and Danielle Carter at the launch in Leicester Square.Â 

Scott and Parlour wore the blue and burgundy shirt while Pires and Carter donned the home strip as the quartet showed off the Visit Rwanda sleeve sponsor.Â 


ArsenalÂ launched their home kitÂ last monthÂ - the club's first release in the Unai Emery era - and have now revealed their away kit that will come in 'peacoat navy'.

With the standard top setting supporters back Â£55 and the long-sleeved version to cost Â£60, Puma have also created an 'authentic' version to match the home stripÂ  which will also cost Â£100.

The Puma kit is made up of an 'evoKNIT performance fabric' which includesÂ thermo-regulation technology,Â an enhanced moisture management and adaptive cooling system.

A red 'WM' can be seen stretched across the sleeves and the chest of the shirt, which pays homage to the famed formation employed by legendary Gunners boss Herbert Chapman in the 1920s and 30s.Â 

Presenting our 2018/19 @pumafootball away kit

Get yours - plus a free Â£10 gift card - here ðŸ‘‰ https://t.co/sWawsTub6l pic.twitter.com/U178CjVbk1

â€” Arsenal FC (@Arsenal) June 7, 2018

The concept behind this technology is to keep the Arsenal players from overheating during their matches and will keep their body temperature at the perfect level.

Engineered cooling zonesÂ inside the shirt's material act as channels to regulate body temperature, whilst moisture management is aided by 'dryCELL' technology.Â 

The release, for the Gunners' final season with Puma (adidas are in pole position to replace them), has received mostly bad reviews from supporters on social media, with some labelling both home and away kits 'terrible'.

One fan wrote on Twitter: 'Puma clearly donâ€™t want our business anymore.Â These are terrible - nothing good about any of them. Whoever comes in next just needs to make a yellow away shirt and weâ€™ll be over the moon!'

'Awful, Puma strikes again,' another wrote.

OthersÂ  also went on to criticise their launch video, which shows only parts of the kit, covered up by dark lighting.Â 'Dreadful, dreadful kit. No wander (sic) this video has been shot in the dark. Canâ€™t wait for Adidas next season,' wrote on angry Gunners fan.

It is clear many fans are not too keen on this season's kits, with the home strip receiving an equal amount of criticism. However, Emery will not be concerned by his new side's appearance should he help recover their form and lead them back into the top four.Â

Dreadful dreadful kit. No wander this video has been shot in the dark. Canâ€™t wait for Adidas next season

I think its good that we cant see it properly!
