item.title: Championship clubs are heading down a black hole as report reveals that 99% of revenue is being spent on wages in a desperate gamble to reach the Premier League
item.description: IAN HERBERT: All but four clubs in English football's second tier were in the red during the period investigated for accountants Deloitteâ€™s latest annual review of football finances.
item.content:encoded:
Clubs are playing a dangerous game by overspending in a desperate attempt to reach the Premier League, the annual report on the game's finances will reveal on Thursday.

As troubled Aston Villa continue their battle to stave off administration, the report shows teams in the second tier are gambling 99 per cent of their revenue on wages â€” way beyond the recommended figure of 70 per cent.Â 

All but four clubs in the division were in the red during the period investigated for accountants Deloitte's review of football finances. 'Owners and managers have... taken the decision to stretch themselves financially to gain promotion,' Deloitte said.


Villa's parlous finances have raised concerns this week and on Wednesday they saw off the immediate threat of administration by finding Â£2million to pay an overdue tax bill owed to HMRC.

The report reveals 13 Championship clubs spent more on wages than they earned in 2016-17.

The finance experts said the temptation to over-stretch was heightened by what they are calling 'the Newcastle effect' â€” in which the Tyneside club earned promotion after they increased their wage bill by eight per cent despite being relegated from the top flight in May 2016.Â 

Newcastle's ratio of wages to revenue in the Championship was 131 per cent. The club recorded the biggest operating loss in the league â€” Â£55m. 'Newcastle was effectively run as a Premier League club... to secure an immediate return,' Deloitte said.

The club's wages accounted for 16 per cent of the total wage bill of the Championship. They spent 82 per cent more than Villa â€” the second highest spender in 2016-17. Villa ran up losses of Â£19.2m and spent Â£61.4m on wages. That's Â£40m more than Huddersfield Town, who were promoted that season.Â 

Of Newcastle's high-risk gambit, Deloitte said: 'It remains to be seen whether Newcastle's success emboldens other clubs relegated from the Premier League to follow this strategy.'

Wolves took the same huge gamble last season â€” laying out Â£12.8m to Benfica for winger Helder Costa and Â£15.8m to Porto for Ruben Neves. But by the time they are pursued by the EFL for a breach of Financial Fair Play they will be massive Premier League earners.

Villa, who lost to Fulham in the Championship play-off final last month, need to make Â£40m in savings to avoid being fined for breaching FFP rules and have dire cash-flow problems.Â 

In the Premier League, only Swansea (77 per cent) spent more than the recommended 70 per cent of revenue on wages.

Tottenham (42 per cent) spent the lowest percentage of revenue on wages in 2016-17. Manchester United, Arsenal and Leicester City spent less than 50 per cent of their revenue on wages. Burnley spent exactly 50 per cent.

Arsenal's commercial might is revealed by the new report. They have become the first club other than Manchester United to turn in a profit of more than Â£100m.

The overall proportion of revenue spent on wages in the Premier League is 55 per cent â€” the lowest since 1997-98. For the first time ever, no Premier League club reported an operating loss.

item.title: Premier League executive chairman Richard Scudamore sweats on overseas TV money pact
item.description: CHARLES SALE - SPORTS AGENDA: Premier League clubs are finally expected to reach a compromise on the TV money dispute at their summer meeting starting on Thursday.
item.content:encoded:
Premier League clubs are finally expected to reach a compromise on the overseas TV money dispute at their summer meeting starting on Thursday.

But it will be a close-run thing for executive chairman Richard Scudamore, who has taken the precaution of scheduling an additional session on TV rights on Friday if the impasse remains.

The Big Six clubs are likely to start the debate â€” and Scudamore has staked his reputation on a successful outcome â€” with the support of West Ham, Leicester, Everton and Brighton, with Huddersfield wavering.Â Â 


But that is still well short of the 14-6 majority needed for a change in the PL statutes which since 1992 have decreed an equal distribution of foreign TV rights income.

The Big Six want the champions to receive 80 per cent more than the bottom club â€” with others receiving money on a sliding scale â€” but more likely is for common ground to be found at 60 or 70 per cent.Â 

Â 

Thursday's Premier League meeting will discuss an offer from Coca-Cola, believed to be Â£10million a year, to become their seventh official partner.Â 

The deal will help the League bring in more revenue from a set of backers than from one title sponsor.Â 

Â 

The woeful Stan Collymore, now reduced to working for Kremlin apologists Russia Today, has a loud over-bearing voice, which meant his terrible interview technique received a wide audience at the England media day.Â 

Collymore's ignorant opening gambit to Raheem Sterling was to suggest he was the only one in the room who could hold his hand up as a current Premier League title-winner.Â Nearby were Sterling's three Manchester City colleagues John Stones, Kyle Walker and Fabian Delph.Â 

Collymore was as disparaging as ever about media colleagues, including calling your Sports Agenda columnist a 'rotter' and a 'fat frog' in a live Twitter video.

Â 

A staff reshuffle at the top of the FA signals that a potential bid to host the 2030 World Cup has moved a step forward.

Director of communications Rob Sullivan is to head a beefed-up international department given added responsibilities.

Sullivan's workload is likely to include the seven games at Wembley during Euro 2020, the bid to host the women's Euro 21 and preparing the ground for a possible World Cup bid, provided Europe are the chosen region and UEFA unite behind England. Sullivan's able deputy Louisa Fyans will become the new FA communications chief after the World Cup.

These changes, including others in the IT and participation departments, also point to chief executive Martin Glenn staying at the helm at least until Euro 2020 when there had been speculation he would leave earlier.Â 

Â 

Will Trump cost 2026 bid?

FIFA'S fear that anti-Donald Trump feeling could mean them missing out on $11billion (Â£8.2bn) profit from a 2026 World Cup in the United States, Canada and Mexico led to speculation that Morocco, their only rivals, would be eliminated at the evaluation report stage, long before the FIFA congress vote next Wednesday.

However, the joint bid presidents were unanimous on Wednesday in saying Trump hasn't come up in campaigning over the last four months.

USA bid leader Carlos Cordero also insisted their projected revenue of $14bn, helped by an average ticket price of $431 (Â£321), that Morocco are so sceptical about had been subject to detailed FIFA checks.

Meanwhile, the joint bid trio chose to host their media briefing Wednesday in a Kensington hotel next door to the Moroccan embassy.Â 

Â 

The cost-cutting review at Twickenham that could mean twice the 20 job losses initially feared is serious enough for community rugby chief Steve Grainger to email RFU councillors about the fall-out from the process.Â 

Grainger writes: 'There is an inevitable impact on motivation and morale as colleagues face a period of uncertainty.'

item.title: Chelsea stars anxious over delay in naming Antonio Conte's successor amid Maurizio Sarri's Napoli stand-off
item.description: Sportsmail has been told agents were initially informed that the managerial situation would be sorted by the end of May but they and their clients are still awaiting an outcome.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea's delay in tying down a replacement for Antonio Conte is causing some concern among the squad as they wait to discover who will be in charge next season.Â Â 

Sportsmail has been told agents were initially informed that the managerial situation would be sorted by the end of May but they and their clients are still awaiting an outcome.Â 

Conte is still set to leave but Chelsea have found themselves in a mess over who will take over from the 48-year-old Italian.


Maurizio Sarri was in pole position but Chelsea refused to pay a Â£7million release clause to Napoli to sign him. He is still in the frame but the stand-off between Sarri and the Italian club continues.

Former Paris Saint-Germain manager Laurent Blanc is another candidate interested in the vacancy.

As well as player concerns, one other worry for Chelsea is that they are unable to press ahead fully with plans for next season until they know who will be in charge.

It is now almost three weeks since Chelsea won the FA Cup by beating Manchester United at Wembley Stadium.

Conte has 12 months left on his near Â£9m-per-season deal and wants Chelsea to pay him compensation in full.

item.title: Exclusive: Premier League winner and Leicester City defender Christian Fuchs is starting his own esports team
item.description: The former Premier League champion and current Leicester City left-back is going to become the first ever Premier League footballer to have his own video game teams in FIFA 18 and more.
item.content:encoded:
According to our sources, former Premier League champion and current Leicester City left-back Christian Fuchs will become the first ever Premier League footballer to have his own video games team.

Professional video gaming, also known as esports, is a rapidly rising industry estimated to create around Â£650million in revenue this year alone.

Fuchs is creating his own team which will have professional FIFA players representing him at tournaments around the world. We are also told that he will look to expand into other esport titles but it wasn't specified which ones.

Many football players have become more open for their interest in video games with the likes of Deli Alli streaming himself playing Fortnite online with Harry Kane and Harry Maguire while other superstars including Antoine Griezmann have performed Fortnite-inspired celebrations after scoring.

WHAT ARE ESPORTS?

Football teams all around the world have invested in FIFA players who represent them at gaming tournaments with big names such as Manchester City, Paris-Saint Germain, West Ham and more already involved.

PSG and Schalke have even gone one step further by investing in esports titles outside of FIFA, moving into games such as Rocket League, League of Legends and DOTA 2.

Some football players have followed suit, including Netherlands and Chelsea legend Ruud Gullit who is developing young FIFA players through his own club, Team Gullit.

On top of that, Arsenal, Crystal Palace and Swansea already have some interest in esports thanks to their American owners. All three reportedly are looking into buying a LoL team, which will reportedly cost around Â£10m.

Arsenal's Stan Kroenke is the co-owner of Overwatch League team the Los Angeles Gladiators, a spot which cost $20m. Meanwhile, SwanseaÂ co-owner Steve Kaplan is a majority shareholder in esports organisation Immortals and Palace's owners Josh Harris and David Blitzer also own British esports organisation, Team Dignitas.

Overall, there are over 200 sports clubs who currently have their own esports players and teams. Professional video gaming may not be a sport but you cannot ignore the rising industry which has the attention of top football clubs and players.Â

item.title: Liverpool considering move for Stoke forward Xherdan Shaqiri as Jurgen Klopp looks to add depth to his attack
item.description: The Switzerland international will leave the bet365 Stadium following Stoke's relegation and his ability means he will be on the radar of many Premier League clubs, including Everton and Southampton.
item.content:encoded:
LiverpoolÂ are interested in Xherdan Shaqiri and will consider a move for the Stoke City forward.

The Switzerland international will leave the bet365 Stadium following Stoke's relegation and his ability means he will be on the radar of many Premier League clubs, including Everton and Southampton, plus teams in Europe.

Jurgen Klopp wants to add quality depth to his squad to enhance Liverpool's prospects domestically and in the Champions League and the club's technical department have several options in terms of providing back up for Mohamed Salah, Roberto Firmino and Sadio Mane.


Shaqiri bluntly explained at the end of last season that playing in the Championship 'wasn't what I signed up for' and Stoke are aware of his feelings. They are resigned to losing one of their top assets.

He still has two years remaining on his contract but a break clause would enable prospective clubs to sign Shaqiri for Â£13million, only a fraction more than the Â£12m they paid Bayern Munich in 2015.

Liverpool have made a brisk start to their summer dealing, paying Â£40m for Fabinho from Monaco. Lyon's Nabil Fekir remains the top priority in terms of bolstering their attack, with the France international regarded as Philippe Coutinho's replacement.

Shaqiri, though, would be an economical alternative. Liverpool are also interested in Malcom, Bordeaux's Brazilian forward and Moses Simon, the Nigeria winger who plays in Belgium for Gent.

Liverpool, meanwhile, have bolstered their backroom team by appointing Philipp Jacobsen as the new Medical Rehabilitation and Performance Manager.Â 

Jacobsen, who previously worked at Aspetar in Qatar, assisted Adam Lallana while the midfielder received treatment on a hamstring issue in South Africa in April.

West Ham will hope to have a progress report on their bid to sign Felipe Anderson when his agents meet his club Lazio on Thursday.

West Ham are understood to have offered a deal worth around Â£33million for Anderson, which has been rejected.

But the 25-year-old Brazilian is keen on a move to London to link up with Manuel Pellegrini.

item.title: Everton goalkeeper Joel Robles in talks to join Spanish side Getafe
item.description: Everton goalkeeper Joel Robles is in talks to join Spanish side Getafe. Robles is being lined up to replace Vicente Guaita who is expected to sign for Crystal Palace.
item.content:encoded:
Everton goalkeeper Joel Robles is in talks to join Spanish side Getafe.

Robles is being lined up to replace Vicente Guaita who is expected to sign for Crystal Palace.

Getafe are poised to sign Robles on a free transfer, with his contract at Everton set to expire at the end of this month.


The 27-year-old Robles was signed for Everton by Roberto Martinez who had brought him to England while at Wigan Athletic.

Robles wants regular first team football after being marginalised by the arrival of England's expected number one for the World Cup Jordan Pickford.Â Â 

JOEL ROBLES' CAREERÂ 

2009-2013: Atletico Madrid

2012: Rayo Vallecano (loan)

2013: Wigan (loan)

2013-present: Everton

Last season Robles didn't feature at all in the Premier League for Everton and was restricted to just two appearances in the Europa League.

An Everton player since 2013, when he joined from Wigan, Robles has played 65 times for the Toffees in total.

In addition to Pickford, Everton are also able to call upon experienced goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg.Â

item.description: Leicester have triggered the Â£3m release clause in Jonny Evans's contract and a move could be completed this week. Sportsmail reported that Leicester were working hard on signing Evans.
item.content:encoded:
Leicester have triggered the Â£3m release clause in Jonny Evans's contract and a move could be completed this week.

Sportsmail reported on May 18 that Leicester were working hard on signing the West Bromwich Albion defender but a Â£4m agent's fee was proving prohibitive.

Negotiations over that additional sum have now progressed to the point where Leicester have contacted West Brom to make the formal bid that, according to terms, must be accepted.


Leicester have tried to sign Evans, 30, for the last three transfer windows and saw a Â£23m offer rejected last summer.

The club now finally look to be closing in on their long-term target, with a deal understood to be worth Â£100,000 per week on the table for the Northern Ireland international.Â 

JONNY EVANS' CAREERÂ 

2006-2015: Manchester United

2006: Royal Antwerp (loan)

Evans had attracted interest from Manchester City and Arsenal and was waiting to see if either side would return this summer, but each is looking at different options.

Leicester want to partner Evans with Harry Maguire at the heart of defence. Evans should become Claude Puel's second transfer of the window after Porto right-back Ricardo Pereira joined for Â£22m.

item.title: 'I've told my family I don't want them going out there because of racism': England star Danny Rose makes tough call ahead of World Cup in Russia
item.description: There are widespread concerns surrounding racism on the eve of the World Cup, with the Russian Football Union fined Â£22,000 by FIFA for racist chanting in a March friendly against France.
item.content:encoded:
England left back Danny Rose has told his family not to travel to Russia for the World Cup over fears of racial abuse.

The 27-year-old Tottenham defender will jet off with the rest of the Three Lions ahead of the tournament but has asked his loved ones to remain behind.

There are widespread concerns surrounding racism on the eve of the World Cup, with the Russian Football Union fined Â£22,000 by FIFA for racist chanting in a March friendly against France in St Petersburg.

England boss Gareth Southgate says protocols are in place if anything flares up during matches, but Rose has made the difficult call of asking his family not to head to Russia to cheer him on.

'I've told my family I don't want them going out there because of racism and anything else that may happen,' he told the London Evening Standard.

'I don't want to be worrying, when I'm trying to prepare for games, for my family's safety.


'If anything happens to me, it wouldn't affect me like it would if my family had been abused.

'I'm fine with whatever may or may not happen, and I like to think I'll be able to deal with it in the right way.

'My dad's really upset. I could hear it in his voice. He said he may never get a chance again to come and watch me in a World Cup.

'That was emotional, hearing that. It's really sad. It's just how it is. Somehow Russia got the World Cup and we have to get on with it.'

Rose has reason to be suspicious when it comes to the punishments dished out for racism.

He was sent off after the final whistle of an under-21 clash with Serbia in 2012 after suffering racial abuse and reacting at the end of the match.

'I have no faith in the justice system so I don't let anything affect me,' he added.

'I didn't get any support after Serbia. I never had a conversation with anybody outside of England.'

item.description: The Portugal Under 21 international has joined the club for Â£17.4million. United wanted a right back to compete with Antonio Valencia, who is 33 and needs constant treatment on a knee injury.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have completed the signing of full backÂ Diogo Dalot from Porto on a five-year deal.

The Portugal Under 21 international has joined the club for Â£17.4million and has the option to stay an extra year in his contract.Â 

United wanted a right back to compete with Antonio Valencia, who is 33 and needs constant treatment on a knee injury.Â 

The 19-year-old can also play left back. He broke into Porto's first team in February in that position and played in his club's 0-0 Champions League draw at Liverpool.

He helped Portugal win the 2016 UEFA European Under 17 Championship, scoring twice in five games in Azerbaijan including once in the final against Spain.Â 

On signing the teenager, United manager Jose Mourinho told the club's official website : 'Diogo is an extremely talented young defender with all the qualities to quickly become a great player for this club.Â 


'He has all the attributes that a full back needs: physicality, tactical intelligence and technical quality, combined with a Porto Academy mentality which prepares players for the maturity they need at the professional level.Â 

'In his age group, he is the best full back in Europe and we all believe he has a bright future ahead of him at Manchester United.'Â 

Dalot joinsÂ Brazilian midfielder Fred, who became United's first summer signing on Tuesday, at the club.Â

item.title: How will Â£52m Brazilian star Fred fit in at Man United? Can he turbo-charge their sluggish play and will he help get the best out of Paul Pogba?Â Â
item.description: Manchester United have wasted little time making Fred their first signing of the summer? But is he the man to speed up Jose Mourinho's often sluggish side and can he liberate Paul Pogba?
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have wasted little time in making their first signing of the summer, bringing in the Brazilian midfielder Fred from Shakhtar Donetsk for Â£52million.

Having completed his medical and agreed a five-year deal with the Old Trafford club, Fred is expected to be officially unveiled as a United player at some point soon.

But what type of player is Fred and how is he going to fit into Jose Mourinho's plans next season? Can he help United raise their game above the often sluggish and monotonous performances of last season?


Â 

Where does Fred play and what type of player is he?

Asked to describe his manner of playing a couple of years ago, Fred put it rather nicely: 'I am a conductor.'

Well, the United orchestra has been out of tune for some time under Mourinho and they'll hope and pray Fred is the midfield virtuoso that can get them back on song next season.

He is commonly described as a box-to-box midfielder, a dynamic player who offers both defensive and offensive attributes, a disruptor and a creator rolled into one.

Mourinho has signed a versatile asset - Fred was originally a left back before being converted into midfield when he signed for Internacional in his homeland in 2011.

Because he is comfortable on both feet, Fred had been deployed as an attacking midfielder at times during his career before settling into a central or deeper midfield role.

The most important thing for United is that he is quick to spark attacks by carrying the ball from defence and feeding the attacking players.

They have been crying out for something like this for a while - all too often last season United were sluggish breaking forward, allowing opponents to track back and regroup.

Fred's speed of both feet and thought, plus his passing range, should help United be speedier in their transitions from front to back next season.

What are Fred's strengths?

We've already mentioned versatility, speed in transition and passing capability with both feet.

Naturally as a Brazilian, he boasts plenty of technical ability and can beat an opponent on the dribble, while another key attribute is that Fred possesses plenty of stamina to fulfil the box-to-box job.

Mourinho will also be satisfied that Fred can put in a defensive shift if United find themselves under the cosh.

At Shakhtar, he earned the trust of coach Paulo Fonseca, who allowed him to freely perform both the defensive and offensive duties of a midfielder.

It remains to be seen if Mourinho, who often puts the tactical straitjacket on his players, will give him such liberty.

Funnily enough, Fred revealed in 2016 that his role model was compatriot Fernandinho, who will of course play across town at Manchester City next season.

But actually a better comparison might be with Chelsea's N'Golo Kante in terms of that box-to-box stamina, adaptability and dynamism. If he turns out to be a Kante, United fans will be pretty chuffed.

And what about his weaknesses?

He only stands 5ft 7in tall, so don't expect Fred to be winning too many headers.

But he more than makes up for that in terms of tenacity - he was Shakhtar's most prolific tackler in the Champions League last season with an average of 2.9 per game (Kante's average was 3.3).

However, United should be wary that this tenacity can sometimes spill over into ill-discipline. He received 14 yellow cards and one red in 29 games for the Ukrainian side last season.

The other concern is that while Fred has played 39 European matches for Shakhtar, the Ukrainian Premier League isn't exactly at the same standard of the Premier League.

United fans may have to be patient while the Brazilian gets up to speed next season, especially as he'll probably be entering the campaign off the back of a lengthy run at the World Cup in Russia.

How will he fit into a 4-3-3 system at United?

Mourinho went with a 4-3-3 formation in a good number of United's matches last season and this would appear to be the best solution when it comes to accommodating both Fred and Paul Pogba in the midfield.

He would play either in the middle or on the right of the midfield three alongside Nemanja Matic, with Pogba stationed on the left.

Some of Pogba's best performances for United have come from this left-sided station and potentially Fred could offer the answer when it comes to belatedly getting the best out of the Frenchman at United.

The key is in the link-up and transition between the deep-lying Matic and the rampaging Pogba, plus a forward line of Jesse Lingard, Alexis Sanchez and Romelu Lukaku further on.

There should be a good balance about United's midfield with Fred aiding Matic in the defensive responsibilities when required and then springing Pogba.

The idea is that the speed of these transitions will give United the thrust going forward they have so often lacked under Mourinho.

How will he fit into a 4-2-3-1 system at United?

In certain games, Mourinho will revert to the tried and trusted 4-2-3-1, with Fred likely to sit in alongside Matic in defensive midfield.

This would be a more conservative role, with opportunities to break forward more limited, but Fred is certainly capable of the tactical discipline Mourinho would want with this set-up.

One of the chief criticisms of Pogba - and a reason why the youngster Scott McTominay was drafted in for big games last season - was that he lacked this discipline and would over-complicate things.

Problem is, it's now hard to see how they all could be accommodated in this formation and Pogba could well be seeing more of the United bench.

Reason being that United have so many decent attacking options Pogba wouldn't slot in.

Who is going to make way?

In the 4-3-3, the man who looks like he has the most to lose is Ander Herrera.Â 

The Spaniard was drafted in to try to solve the Pogba conundrum but, though his passing is excellent, he struggles in the midfield battle.

Fred has a far greater dynamism in this regard - he's also quicker, more skilful, more tenacious and more attack-minded - so you have to fear for Herrera.

Mind you, given the sheer volume of matches United will have to get through domestically and in the Champions League next season, plus the inevitable injuries and suspensions, Herrera will no doubt still feature at times.

Is Fred the man to get the best out of Pogba?

Having spent two seasons trying to figure out the Pogba equation, Mourinho will certainly hope that is the case.

As explained, Fred should have the attributes to fit in as the link-man between Matic and Pogba, theoretically allowing the Â£89m man to forget defensive duties and concentrate on aiding United's attack.

It may take a few matches, a few months even, for Fred and Pogba to get used to playing alongside one another. They may well thread on each other's toes at first.

What Mourinho should have here is the ideal man to bring the best out of Pogba in an attacking sense. If that doesn't happen, then United may have to cut their losses.

Who else are United likely to sign?

Mourinho's second signing of the summer looks likely to be the 19-year-old Porto defender Diogo Dalot.

Dalot completed his United medical after they triggered the Â£17.4m release clause in his contract and the deal should be completed this week.

That may not be the last defensive addition, however, with Mourinho in the market for a top class centre-half such as Tottenham's Toby Alderweireld or Clement Lenglet of Sevilla.

Then there is the tantalising possibility of a megabucks move for Gareth Bale, who couldn't have made it clearer after the Champions League final that he wants to leave Real Madrid.

It would cost United upwards of Â£85m to sign the Welsh star but he would certainly bring some X-factor to United's forward line if partnered with Lukaku and Sanchez.

Having completed his medical and agreed a five-year deal with the Old Trafford club, Fred is expected to be officially unveiled as a United player at some point soon. But what type of player is Fred and how is he going to fit into Jose Mourinho's plans next season? item.title: Chelsea's stand-off with Antonio Conte set to scupper transfer plans as targets remain reluctant to join during managerial uncertainty
item.description: The Blues cannot fully press ahead with plans for next season until they know who will be in charge, with Maurizio Sarri currently the clubâ€™s top target and Laurent Blanc another contender.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea risk hindering their chances of building a Premier League title-challenging team for next season the longer their stand-off with Antonio Conte continues.

The Blues cannot fully press ahead with plans until they know who will be in charge, with Maurizio Sarri currently the top target and Laurent Blanc another contender.

Potential summer signings also want to know who will be their boss at Stamford Bridge next season, putting Chelsea at risk of falling behind on their rivals.


While others are already getting down to business, such as Jose Mourinhoâ€™s Manchester United, there has been a slow start to the summer from Chelsea.

Almost three weeks on from their FA Cup win, Conte remains in charge at Chelsea but the Italian is still set to be sacked once a replacement is confirmed.

The squad know they will likely have a new manager to work with next season and Conte may not receive too many thanks from his players on social media.

The former Italy boss has fallen out with several stars, including Diego Costa, the popular Premier League winner who left for Atletico Madrid.

Conte has emerged as a leading candidate at Real Madrid as he remains the only manager with a recent proven track record who is likely to be available this summer.

Massimiliano Allegriâ€™s reluctance to take the Bernabeu job has turned the troubled European champions towards Conte.

Real want to buy a goalkeeper, pursue the signature of Neymar, off-load Ronaldo and were not willing to give Zinedine Zidane full powers in the transfer market.

Conte has complained of being in a similar situation at Chelsea on occasions and his abrasive attitude had made him someone the club did not immediately consider when they drew up their first post-Zidane shortlist.

But with Mauricio Pochettino and Jurgen Klopp wedded to their current clubs and tied to long contracts Madrid started to widen the net.Â

item.title: Liverpool keen to land Â£10m rated Moses Simon as Jurgen Klopp looks to add depth to his attacking options
item.description: Moses Simon has one year left on his Gent contract and is expected to command a fee of around Â£10million. He would be seen as back-up to Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mane at Anfield.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool are keen to sign Nigerian winger Moses Simon as Jurgen Klopp looks to add depth to his attacking options this summer.

Simon, who is wanted by several Premier League clubs, has a year left remaining on his current contract at Belgian side Gent.

According to the Liverpool Echo, the 22-year-old is expected to cost in the region of Â£10million and would be seen as back-up to Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mane.


Simon is versatile and can play on either flank but was primarily used on the left by Gent last season.

He scored six goals and added a further three assists to help his team to a fourth-place finish in the Belgian league.Â 

Simon will not be representing his country at this summer's World Cup after being overlooked for a place in Nigeria's final 23-man squad by Gernot Rohr.

Jurgen Klopp has already strengthened the squad that finished fourth in the Premier League and lost in the Champions League final.

Naby Keita will join this summer from RB Leipzig while Brazilian midfielder Fabinho became the club's first signing of the window last month and will arrive from Monaco.

A goalkeeper also remains a priority for the Reds while their interest in France and Lyon attacker Nabil Fekir is still very much alive.Â

item.title: 'The patient next to me was diagnosed with cancer... what's up with my knee is nothing': Benjamin Mendy reveals how he put injury woes into context during time in hospital last season
item.description: Manchester City and France left back Benjamin Mendy has opened up about how a cancer patient in the hospital bed next to him in Barcelona gave him perspective during his time out injured.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City and France left back Benjamin Mendy has opened up about how a cancer patient in the hospital bed next to him in Barcelona gave him perspective during his time out injured.

The 23-year-old ruptured his right knee ligaments against Crystal Palace in September 2017 and only returned to action in the remaining games in a bid to prove his fitness for the World Cup.

Mendy earned a place in Didier Deschamps' 23-man squad and speaking to SFR Sport, the Frenchman explains how he quickly realised his injury worries paled in significance to those around him in the hospital.Â 


'When I was in Barcelona, the patient next to me, a Spaniard, was diagnosed with cancer,' he said.

'We found out two days later. He was dying. I told myself: "What's up with my knee, it's nothing". I think that helped with my recovery.

'When you've hurt your knee or your ligaments, it's nothing at all compared to folk who suffer things that are far more serious.'

Mendy marked his return to action for Pep Guardiola's side in late April at home against Swansea, when he was introduced from the bench.Â Â 

Mendy is known as one of football's best characters and he has kept spirits high among an optimistic young French squad this summer.

Deschamps side begin their group against Australia on June 16 before facing Peru and Denmark ahead of the knockout stages.Â Â

item.content:encoded:
Stoke City are prepared to pay nearly Â£30million to pair Benik Afobe and Andre Gray in a new look strikeforce.

Wolves triggered their option to buy Afobe last week and will make a quick profit with Stoke prepared to pay more than other Championship rivals.

Watford are prepared to listen to offers for Gray, who cost them Â£18m from Burnley last year.Â

Stoke have opened talks with Joe Allen over a new contract while West Ham have shown an interest in defender Ryan Shawcross.

The Potters were relegated from the Premier League at the end of last season and have a new manager in Gary Rowett.Â

item.title: Manchester United add Â£52m Fred to their list of Brazilians... but will he be a samba star or an Old Trafford flop like Kleberson or Rodrigo Possebon?
item.description: Manchester United are poised to seal the Â£52million signing of Brazil midfielder Fred from Shakhtar Donetsk. He will become the seventh Brazilian to play for the club.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United are poised to seal the Â£52million signing of Brazil midfielder Fred from Shakhtar Donetsk.

Jose Mourinho moved quickly to sign Fred on a five-year contract as United pipped their neighbours Manchester City to the 25-year-old's signature.

He will become the seventh Brazilian player in United's history and we take a closer look at the six that came before him here.


Â 

KLEBERSON

United 2003-2005; 30 appearances, two goals

Sir Alex Ferguson didn't get a whole lot wrong during his time at Manchester United, but the 2003 signing of Jose Kleberson Pereira doesn't reflect well on him with hindsight.

'One of the reasons we sold Seba Veron was because we knew we were getting Kleberson - that shows how highly we regard his talent,' said Fergie when United sealed his Â£5.93m signing from Atletico Paranaense.

Indeed, what a tumultuous summer 2003 was at Old Trafford. They sold David Beckham to Real Madrid for Â£25m and Veron to Chelsea for Â£15m, missed out on another Brazilian, Ronaldinho, but signed a teenager called Cristiano Ronaldo. I wonder what happened to him...

Ferguson's enthusiasm in Kleberson, then 24, wasn't misplaced. He had come from nowhere to become a starter in Luiz Felipe Scolari's Brazilian World Cup winners in 2002 and in the final with Germany set up one of Ronaldo's goals.

Regarded as an industrious and tough-tackling midfielder, Kleberson had initially attracted the attention of Leeds United in that World Cup summer but refused to move to England without his 16-year-old fiancee.

The delay allowed Man United to pounce 12 months later but he never lived up to Ferguson's big build-up, suffered an injury in only his second game and made just 20 Premier League appearances over two seasons.

United cut their losses and sold him to Besiktas for a third of the cost in 2005 and Kleberson's career never came close to scaling such heights again.

He is now the under-12s coach at MLS side Philadelphia Union.

Â 

ANDERSON

United 2007-2015; 181 appearances, nine goals

Anderson was that rare thing - a Brazilian success story in the Premier League. And he became something of a cult hero with United fans during his eight years at Old Trafford.

The midfielder had a sunshine personality off the field - always smiling, amusing his team-mates with his early efforts to learn English, blasting out samba music and living in Cristiano Ronaldo's house for his first seven months in Manchester.

On the field, he was dedicated and committed, admitting in an interview that he played through injuries for 'God of football' Ferguson. He always seemed to play especially well in grudge matches against Arsenal.

His Old Trafford career was something of a slow-burner. Signed for Â£20m from Porto in 2007, he had to compete against the likes of Paul Scholes and Michael Carrick for a spot in the team.

Yet he ended his first season as a European champion. Often forgotten in memories of John Terry's slip and Nicolas Anelka's fateful miss was that in between them Anderson hammered home his penalty.

While at no point an automatic pick in his eight years with United, Anderson still managed 181 appearances for the club, winning four league titles and a host of other medals. Injuries often prevented him playing more.

Having fallen out of favour under Louis van Gaal, Anderson, capped eight times for the Selecao during his career, returned home to join Internacional.

Still only 30, he is currently without a club.

Â 

RODRIGO POSSEBON

United 2008-2010; Eight appearances, no goals

Recommended to Ferguson by United's Brazil-based scout John Calvert-Toulmin while he was checking out the Da Silva twins (more of them later), Possebon joined for Â£3m in January 2008.

United hoped they'd signed the next Brazilian wonderkid and the defensive midfielder started brightly enough, coming on to make his Premier League debut on the opening day of the following season.

But things were never the same after he was injured in a challenge by Middlesbrough's Emanuel Pogatetz in a League Cup fixture the following month. It proved the first of a succession of injury setbacks that blighted his career.

Though he returned and even played enough times to earn a League Cup winner's medal, Possebon didn't make a breakthrough and was loaned out to Braga the following year, making just one appearance.

From there, Possebon rattled through a number of Brazilian clubs without settling and was last spotted at Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam.

Even that wasn't meant to be - a 'back injury and a lack of fitness' was the reason given by the club when he was released in February. Still only 29, it's been a rather sad footballing story for Possebon.

Â 

RAFAEL DA SILVA

United 2008-2015; 169 appearances, five goals

The Da Silva twins, Rafael and Fabio, were playing full-back on opposite sides of the field for Fluminense when united scout Les Kershaw spotted them in the 2005 Nike Premier Cup in Hong Kong.

He described them as 'two little whippets' to Ferguson because of their seemingly boundless energy and resilience and recommended United sign them. That they did eventually, seeing off competition from Arsenal in the process.

The identical twins were only 17 when they came to Manchester but Ferguson had no hesitation throwing Rafael into the cut and thrust of the Premier League and even the Champions League.

Rafael, unlike his brother, was able to hold down a place in the United team and was highly-regarded by Ferguson, even if it did sometimes lead to confusion.

'It wasn't rare that before training he'd look at me and say: 'Come on, go to the left wing.' When that happened, I used to just look at him. Then he'd go: 'I meant right wing, Rafael!' he recalled of the manager.

Indeed, the only way Fergie could reliably tell them apart was because Fabio was married and wore a wedding ring.

Rafael helped United to Champions League finals in 2009 and 2011, as well as three Premier League titles, the League Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup.

He continued to play under David Moyes and also during the initial months under Louis van Gaal. But after returning from an injury, he couldn't force his way back into the team, Van Gaal dealing with the situation in brutal fashion.

'In his first season, Van Gaal called me to his office and said: 'You can leave.' Rafael revealed recently. 'The meeting lasted one minute. That was it: 'You can leave.'

Rafael has since established himself well at French club Lyon.Â 

Â 

FABIO DA SILVA

United 2008-2014; 56 appearances, three goals

Having arrived at United via the same route as his brother, Fabio's competitive debut for the club was delayed by a shoulder injury that required surgery.

He had to wait until January 2009 for his debut, against Tottenham in the fourth round of the FA Cup, but suffered another injury in that very game.

While Fabio invariably impressed when he did get a chance, his United career never gained the same traction as his brothers and by 2012-13 he was out on loan at Queens Park Rangers while Rafael was winning the league.

A red card in United's FA Cup defeat to Swansea in January 2014 convinced Moyes to let him ho and Fabio has since played for Cardiff City and Middlesbrough.

Â 

ANDREAS PEREIRA

United 2011-present; 13 appearances, one goal

Technically, Fred won't be the only Brazilian on the books at Old Trafford. Andreas Pereira is still a United player, even if the playmaker is among the lesser-spotted around Old Trafford.

Pereira was a PSV Eindhoven starlet when he caught United's eye in the Manchester United Premier Cup back in 2011 and it was a personal visit from Ferguson that persuaded him to sign there instead of Arsenal, Chelsea and Liverpool.

The Belgian-born Brazilian became one of the stars of United's academy, working his way through the ranks before Van Gaal, keen to promote youth, handed him a senior debut in that ignominious 4-0 League Cup loss to MK Dons.

All 13 of Pereira's appearances to date came under the Dutch manager, with Jose Mourinho deciding loan experience would be preferable to kicking around in the reserves.

Consequently, Pereira has spent the last two seasons in Spain, first with Granada and then with Valencia, and he has indeed featured in plenty of matches.

It now remains to be seen whether there's a future for him at United or, as is most likely, he'll seek a new club.

item.title: Marcus Edwards 'wants to leave Tottenham this summer' as teenager once compared to Lionel Messi seeks first-team football
item.description: Ahead of his Tottenham debut in 2016,Â Pochettino said of Edwards:Â 'The qualities â€” it's only looks, his body and the way that he plays â€” remember a little bit from the beginning of Messi.'
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham teenagerÂ Marcus Edwards wants to secure a summer move away.

The 19-year-old, who was once compared to Lionel Messi by Mauricio Pochettino, has only played two senior matches to date â€” a 15-minute cameo for Spurs in a 5-0 League Cup win over Gillingham in 2016 and an even shorter appearance for Norwich during a disappointing loan spell in the 2017-18 season.

According to The Guardian, Tottenham still believe in theÂ attacking midfielder's potential but the player himself is said to want immediate first-team football, which is unlikely to be on offer in the short term in north London.

Edwards has fallen off the radar somewhat sinceÂ Pochettino likened him to Barcelona's main man.

Speaking ahead of his Spurs debut in 2016,Â Pochettino said of Edwards:Â 'The qualities â€” it's only looks, his body and the way that he plays â€” remember a little bit from the beginning of Messi.

'He's small, he's left-footed, I remember a little bit (Erik) Lamela when he was at River Plate, remember he had long hair, when he was 14, 15 years old, there is a lot of videos on YouTube that you can see, that he took the ball, didn't give a pass and shot straight away.


'He is a very good prospect and potentially he can be a top player, but we need to be patient and tell him that he has a lot of talent, enough talent to be a top player, a great player.

'But now it's how he builds his future, that's very important. And it's our responsibility to tell him.'

Pochettino spoke then of patience, but it appears Edwards himself is now running low on it. Edwards has two years left to run on his current contract.

item.title: 'City were being punished by Financial Fair Play... it was impossible': Manuel Pellegrini reveals he was unable to sign Alexis Sanchez or Arturo Vidal at Manchester City due to FFP rules
item.description: Manuel Pellegrini has opened up about the struggles he faced as Manchester City boss and reveals he was unable to sign Alexis Sanchez or Arturo Vidal due to Financial Fair Play rules.
item.content:encoded:
Manuel Pellegrini has opened up about the struggles he faced while in charge of Manchester City and reveals he was unable to sign Alexis Sanchez and Arturo Vidal due to Financial Fair Play punishments.Â 

Pellegrini won the Premier League with City in 2013-14 but admits he was unable to bring in all the players he wanted due to the impact of FFP regulations.

'I tried to bring them in but City were being punished by Financial Fair Play - it was impossible,' he explained.Â Â 


The 64-year-old Chilean is the new boss of West Ham but in an interview withÂ outlet El Mercurio, Pellegrini opens up on life at Real Madrid, his relationship with Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho and the player that was the most complicated to manage.Â 

And it is life at Madrid that will be the most eye-opening for football fans - especially as Los Blancos continue their search to replace Zinedine Zidane following his resignation.

Pellegrini was at the Bernabeu for one season and despite having a 75 per cent win percentage, was shown the door in favour of Mourinho.

'One of the most frequent discussions that I had with the Real Madrid directors was about the players' performance,' he continued.

'They told me some players had to play no matter what, but I never compromised.'Â 

The Chilean coached some of the finest talents in world football during that season with both Cristiano Ronaldo and Raul at his attacking disposal.Â 

But while he reveals decisions were made for him in the Spanish capital, he reserves special praise for the two Madrid forwards.Â Â 

'During my career the easiest players to direct have been Cristiano and Raul,' he said.Â 

'It doesn't matter how much they win, they are excellent sportsmen.'

item.title: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang looks coolness personified as he perches on wing of a plane in social media snapÂ
item.description: The Gabon striker, who scored 10 goals for the Gunners last campaign, will not feature at the World Cup. Aubameyang posted a picture of himself sat on the wing of a plane on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal strikerÂ Pierre-Emerick AubameyangÂ may not be heading to the World Cup this month, but he appeared to be off elsewhere on his travels on Wednesday.

The 28-year-old, who scored 10 goals for the Gunners last campaign, will not feature in Russia this summer after Gabon failed to qualify.

Aubameyang, donning a cap, sunglasses, a Nike t-shirt and a fashionable floral tracksuit, looked coolness personified as he perched with a bag on the wing of a small plane as it sat on the tarmac.


Aubameyang also posted a selfie with a Â£250,000 blue Aston Martin on to his InstagramÂ story on Tuesday morning and has been keeping up his fitness following the end of the season.

Alongside the snap he wrote: 'Let's go for some runs,' in a Nike tracksuit top.

It is not clear where Aubameyang was for his training session, but the German number plate on his supercar suggests he may have returned to Dortmund.Â 

Gabon finished third in their World Cup qualifying group last November, which was won by Morocco.

Aubameyang has a new team-mate at the Emirates after the club confirmed the signing of veteran full back Stephan Lichtsteiner on a free transferÂ from Juventus on Tuesday.

The Switzerland international becomes the first Gunners signing confirmed since Unai Emery succeeded Arsene Wenger as manager.

Emery told the club website: 'Stephan brings huge experience and leadership to our squad. He's a player with great quality with a very positive and determined attitude. Stephan will improve us on and off the pitch.'

item.title: Everton's Director of Football Marcel Brands admits high wage bill means selling players could prove problematic: 'A lot of their salaries mean they cannot play anywhere'
item.description: Director of Football Marcel Brands has admitted Everton must sell before they can spend heavily this summer window as he clears up the expensive mistakes of the club's previous failed regime.
item.content:encoded:
Marcel Brands has admitted Everton must sell before they can spend heavily this summer as he clears up the expensive mistakes of the club's previous failed regime.

Brands has arrived from PSV Eindhoven to take over from Steve Walsh as Director of Football; Walsh was sacked from his Â£1million-per-year role last month having overseen a disastrous recruitment drive that saw Everton spend Â£239million on transfer fees over a 12 month period.

Marco Silva, the new manager, has inherited a squad with 38 players. Many have seen their values depreciate and are on lucrative contracts - Everton's wage bill is close to 80 per cent of their turnover - and Brands is conscious that moving people on will be difficult.


There will be a number of meetings with players and agents in the coming weeks and a significant number will move on, headed by those who no longer wish to be on Merseyside - Morgan Schneiderlin, who attracted interest from West Ham in January, is one name on that list.

When asked if Everton needed to sell to buy, Brands replied: 'Yes - but it's not only a money thing. Of course money is also important, but it is also for a coach it is not workable to start with 38 players in your squad.

'A lot of them are not young players any more. We have to be honest when we take the decision with these players, do they have prospects here at Everton? Some of conversations will not be nice, but it has to be honest, and I think Marco must start with a squad that everyone is eager to play.

'I know it's hard. You have to be careful because if you make a new signing - because of the salaries in England - then it's difficult if the player is not successful then what do you do? In most countries they cannot make the wages they get here in the Premier League.

'So a lot of players who don't play (at Everton) cannot play anywhere, as the salaries are not comparable.Â 

'That means even if you have money you have to be careful to spend that money. I always say when you buy 10 players eight or nine have to do well.'Â 

The predicament Brands is bracing himself for is those who are on huge contracts insisting they will stay where they are. It gives an indication of just how excessive the policy was last summer when nine players arrived.

'Hopefully I will succeed to offload the right players,' said Brands. 'And, of course, they are good players so I hope there will be interest for a few of our players.Â 

'There will be meetings with the players and with the agents, yes. We need to offload players to raise money (to spend).'Â

item.title: 'Sometimes to stay on the bench is difficult': Willian admits frustration over Chelsea role last term but respects Antonio Conte's decision
item.description: 12 team-mates played more minutes for Chelsea last season than Willian, despite the Brazilian winger - who is now focused on the World Cup - later being named as the Players' Player of the Year.
item.content:encoded:
Willian has admitted he found it frustrating to be forced to sit on the bench at Chelsea last season when he felt he was showing the best form of his career.

Twelve players were handed more minutes by Antonio Conte but Brazilian Willian was named the club's Player of the Year, as voted by his Chelsea team-mates.

Willian previously caused controversy when he posted an Instagram picture of the Chelsea squad lifting the FA Cup trophy but blocked out his Italian boss using emojis.


It seems the frustration has not entirely left as he told Sportsmail on Tuesday: 'I was happy with my performances throughout the season. I played very well.

'I always try to do my best. I always try to work hard. Sometimes to stay on the bench is difficult.

'I respect the decision of the manager who thinks that and I have nothing more to say about my club. I now want to focus here on the national team, on the World Cup. I am ready for it.'

Willian scored six goals and assisted seven in the Premier League last season and added: 'I had a good season with Chelsea, winning the best player of the season for my team, I was very happy with that. The important thing is to follow up. I have to keep getting better.'

item.title: 'Arsenal and Liverpool aren't bad clubs but...': Jasper Cillessen aware of interest from Premier League duo but will only move if Barcelona want him to
item.description: The 29-year-old goalkeeper admits he is aware of interest from Premier League clubs with Liverpool and Arsenal both believed to be keeping an eye of his situation at the La Liga Champions.
item.content:encoded:
Jasper Cillessen said he could be open to a move the Premier League, but only if Barcelona told him they do not want him to stay at the Nou Camp.

The 29-year-old goalkeeper admits he is aware of interest from Premier League clubs with Liverpool and Arsenal both believed to be keeping an eye of his situation at the La Liga Champions.

Nine of Cillessen's 11 appearances for Barcelona last season came in the Copa del Rey which Barcelona won by beating Sevilla 5-0.

'I think that I played well in the matches I had in the Copa del Rey,' Cillessen told Fox Sports.

'I need to wait patiently. The only thing I know is that Barcelona won't sell me.

'Arsenal and Liverpool aren't bad clubs but if Barcelona say, "We love you", then I'll accept their decision and continue there.


'I'll wait until we return on the 16th July to see what they've decided.

'I don't know anything. If the club wants to keep me, I'll accept that. I signed a five-year deal with them.'

Cillessen only conceded three goals in the 11 games he played for Barcelona.Â

item.title: 'I know he will come back from that': Loris Karius backed to get over Champions League final blunders as Kevin Trapp gives 'props' to Liverpool goalkeeper for playing onÂ concussed
item.description: PSG stopper Trapp, who is going to the World Cup with Germany ahead of compatriot Karius, said:Â 'If it is true that he had a concussion and that led to the mistakes, that would be madness'
item.content:encoded:
Kevin Trapp has backed fellow goalkeeper Loris Karius to come back stronger after his two major mistakes in Liverpool's Champions League final defeat by Real Madrid.

Karius threw the ball straight at Karim Benzema to gift Real their first goal, before fumbling a speculative Gareth Bale shot into his own net for the Spanish side's third.

It emerged earlier this week that Karius had been playing with concussion after a collision with Sergio Ramos moments before Benzema's opener.

PSG stopper Trapp, who is going to the World Cup with Germany ahead of compatriot Karius, said:Â 'If it is true that he had a concussion and that led to the mistakes, that would be madness.

'Then, that he played on, props to him for doing that. I had a concussion once and I couldn't play... at all.

'But maybe the adrenaline pushed him through and he didn't realise it. If it impacted him, I don't know, I wasn't in his body. But I know Loris a little bit. I know he will come back from that.'


Karius appears likely to leave Liverpool this summer, or at least be replaced as the club's No 1 keeper by a new recruit.

But Trapp is convinced that 24-year-old Karius is an excellent keeper.

'I know how it feels to make a mistake,' Trapp explained. 'As a goalkeeper, mistakes can happen, it is completely human.

'It is hard for him, because he has had a great career thus far. He fought to be Liverpool's first-choice goalkeeper again, he got to the Champions League final, he performed well. And then this happens in the final, of all things. It can happen, but it is really hard in a game this big.'

item.title: Fulham hike up season ticket prices ahead of Premier League return with fans having to shell out up to Â£1,150
item.description: Newly promoted Fulham have risked angering fans after announcing huge price hikes for season tickets, with some junior supporters having to pay Â£650 more than they did last year.
item.content:encoded:
Newly promoted Fulham have risked angering fans after announcing huge price hikes for season tickets, with some junior supporters having to pay Â£650 more than they did last year.

The dearest Craven Cottage season ticket for anyone under 18 is now Â£999 â€” up from Â£349 â€” while an adult in the Riverside stand will have to pay Â£1,149, up from Â£839.

The west London club secured promotion to the Premier League by beating Aston Villa in the Championship play-off final after four years out of the top flight.

In 2017-18, an adult season ticket could be purchased for as low as Â£299. Now, the cheapest is Â£549 in the Johnny Haynes family stand. The cheapest junior one is Â£129 â€” up from Â£47.


It remains to be seen whether Fulham will continue to leave a â€˜clapperâ€™ on each supporterâ€™s seat as they did last season in the Championship.

A club insider has claimed they sold â€˜99 per centâ€™ of their season tickets when they were available at a lower price before they secured promotion.

Meanwhile, Fulham are waiting for Slavisa Jokanovic to return from holiday to discover what it will take to tie their in-demand manager down to a new deal.

The Cottagers are concerned about interest from Chelsea, which was first reported by Sportsmail in March. Jokanovicâ€™s current contract only has a year to run.

item.title: 'I hope he does well at Manchester United': Chelsea star Willian wishes Fred success and backs Brazil team-mate to improve Jose Mourinho's side
item.description: Brazil midfielder Fred completed his Â£52million move to United fromÂ Shakhtar Donetsk on Tuesday and Willian wished him well. William claimed Fred can improve the Red Devils 'a lot'.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea winger Willian has backed international team-mate Fred to succeed in the Premier League with Manchester United.

Brazil midfielder Fred completed his Â£52million move to United fromÂ Shakhtar Donetsk on Tuesday and Willian wished him well.

He also backed his compatriot to improve Jose Mourinho's current Red Devils side.Â Â 

Asked whether 25-year-old Fred can make an impact at Old Trafford, Willian replied: 'Of course, no doubt about that. He has a lot of qualities.Â 

'He can improve (them) a lot. He goes to one of the best teams in the world. I am happy for him. I hope he does well at Manchester United.'

Willian added: 'He is very happy to come to the Premier League to play. We talked a little bit about that.


'He is excited to start but now is the time to think about the World Cup. I think he is very happy but now it is time to think about national team.'

Brazil play Austria in their final warm-up game on Sunday before starting their World Cup campaign in Russia with a match against Switzerland on June 17.

Willian and Fred both featured as Brazil beat Croatia 2-0 at Anfield last weekend.

item.title: West Ham complete their first signing of the Manuel Pellegrini era as Ryan Fredericks agrees a four-year deal after helping Fulham to promotion
item.description: 25-year-old former Tottenham right-back is looking forward to learning from the experienced Chilean boss and will officially complete his move from west to east London on July 1.
item.content:encoded:
West Ham United have officially confirmed the first signing of the Manuel Pellegrini era, with right-back Ryan Fredericks set to join from newly-promoted London rivals Fulham on a free transfer.

The 25-year-old, also pursued by the likes of Crystal Palace and Newcastle, has put pen to paper on a four-year contract at London Stadium and will arrive after the expiration of his current deal on July 1.

He rejected the offer to pen fresh terms at Fulham over his demands to be made the club's highest-paid player.


New challenge. New league. Same City. #WelcomeFredericks pic.twitter.com/rMKepevxvv

â€” #ImForever (@WestHamUtd) June 5, 2018

'It's amazing for this deal to finally happen,'Â Fredericks told West Ham's official website. 'I know we've been speaking about it for a while and trying to get things in place and finally, we've got it over the line. I'm just buzzing to be here.Â Â 

'West Ham United is one of the biggest clubs in the Premier League. Everyone knows the history of West Ham and there's a lot of factors that brought me to the club.

'Obviously, it's an exciting time for West Ham. The club have just brought in a new manager in Manuel Pellegrini and everyone knows his CV and what he has done in England before and in other leagues as well. I'm sure I can learn a lot from him.Â 

'It just felt like, for the next step of my career, I would be best suited coming here.'

Fredericks made 48 appearances for Fulham last season as they ended a four-year absence from the top-flight and played all but seven minutes of a play-off campaign that saw Slavisa Jokanovic's side overturn a semi-final first-leg deficit against Derby before beating Aston Villa 1-0 at Wembley courtesy of an early effort from captain Tom Cairney.

He appeared 114 times in total for the Whites over three seasons after ending his stay at Bristol City just 25 days after departing Tottenham, where he came through the academy and featured on four occasions in the Europa League in addition to being dispatched for loan spells with Brentford, Millwall and Middlesbrough.

Reacting to his first signing since being appointed to replace David Moyes last month, Pellegrini said: 'I am very pleased to welcome Ryan to West Ham United as our first signing this summer. He joins having had a successful season with Fulham and is a player who will bring great qualities to our squad.Â 

'He has good experience, with more than 150 senior appearances already but, at 25, he is still a young player with his best years ahead of him.

'Ryan has good character, is hungry to succeed, and has shown me that he has great desire to be a West Ham United player. I look forward to working with him.'

item.title: Manchester City have the most Premier League players at the World Cup with 16 but two clubs have none and can you name the one Watford player who will be in Russia?Â
item.description: The World Cup is rapidly approaching and one of the most intriguing aspects of this summer's tournament in Russia will be seeing how the Premier League stars involved get on.
item.content:encoded:
The World Cup is rapidly approaching and one of the most intriguing aspects of this summer's tournament in Russia will be seeing how the plethora of Premier League stars involved get on.

Of the 20 teams that will be in theÂ English top flight next season, 18 of them will have at least one representative in Russia, with Bournemouth and Newcastle the only clubs without a player at the competition.

Last season's champions Manchester City, perhaps unsurprisingly, lead the way for the most players at the World Cup out of the Premier League sides, with 16 members of Pep Guardiola's squad involved, including Kevin De Bruyne and Sergio Aguero, who will hope to thrive for Belgium and Argentina respectively.Â 


PREMIER LEAGUE PLAYERS AT THE WORLD CUPÂ 

Manchester City (16) - Sergio Aguero (Argentina), Gabriel Jesus (Brazil), Fernandinho (Brazil), David Silva (Spain), Raheem Sterling (England), Vincent Kompany (Belgium), Bernardo Silva (Brazil), Nicolas Otamendi (Argentina), Danilo (Brazil), Benjamin Mendy (France), Ederson (Brazil), Fabian Delph (England), Ilkay Gundogan (Germany), Kyle Walker (England), John Stones (England), Kevin De Bruyne (Belgium)

Chelsea (12)Â - Antonio Rudiger (Germany), Eden Hazard (Belgium), Willian (Brazil), Andreas Christensen (Denmark), Thibaut Courtois (Belgium), Victor Moses (Nigeria), Gary Cahill (England), Ruben Loftus-Cheek (England), Cesar Azpilicueta (Spain), Willy Caballero (Argentina), N'Golo Kante (France), Olivier Giroud (France)

Tottenham (12) - TobyÂ Alderweireld (Belgium), Danny Rose (England), Son Heung-min (South Korea), Dele Alli (England), Davinson Sanchez (Colombia), Christian Eriksen (Denmark), Eric Dier (England), Mousa Dembele (Belgium), Kieran Trippier (England), Jan Vertonghen (Belgium), Hugo Lloris (France), Harry Kane (England)Â 

Manchester United (12)Â - Nemanja Matic (Serbia), David De Gea (Spain), Ashley Young (England), Romelu Lukaku (Belgium), Paul Pogba (France), Jesse Lingard (England), Victor Lindelof (Sweden), Marcos Rojo (Argentina), Phil Jones (England), Marouane Fellaini (Belgium), Marcus Rashford (England), Fred (Brazil)

Leicester (8) - Harry Maguire (England), Kasper Schmeichel (Denmark), Kelechi Iheanacho (Nigeria), Jamie Vardy (England), Adrien Silva (Portugal), Wilfred Ndidi (Nigeria), Shinji Okazaki (Japan), Yohan Benalouane (Tunisia)Â 

Arsenal (8)Â - Alex Iwobi (Nigeria), Mohamed Elneny (Egypt), Mesut Ozil (Germany), Nacho Monreal (Spain), Danny Welbeck (England), Granit Xhaka (Switzerland), David Ospina (Colombia), Stephan Lichtsteiner (Switzerland)

Liverpool (7)Â - Roberto Firmino (Brazil), Dejan Lovren (Croatia), Simon Mignolet (Belgium), Trent Alexander-Arnold (England), Sadio Mane (Senegal), Mohamed Salah (Egypt), Jordan Henderson (England)

Southampton (4) - Jan Bednarek (Poland), Dusan Tadic (Serbia), Maya Yoshida (Japan), Cedric (Portugal)Â 

West Ham (4)Â - Javier Hernandez (Mexico), Manuel Lanzini (Argentina), Joao Mario (Portugal), Cheikhou Kouyate (Senegal)

Everton (3) - Jordan Pickford (England), Gylfi Sigurdsson (Iceland), Idrissa Gueye (Senegal)Â 

Huddersfield (3) - Jonas Lossl (Denmark), Aaron Mooy (Australia), Mathias Jorgensen (Denmark)

Brighton (2) - Jose Izquierdo (Colombia), Mathew Ryan (Australia)

Burnley (2) - Nick Pope (England), Johann Gudmundsson (Iceland)

Cardiff (2)Â - Marko Grujic (Serbia), Aron Gunnarsson (Iceland)

Wolves (2) - Alfred N'Diaye (Senegal), Romain Saiss (Morocco)Â 

Crystal Palace (1)Â - Luka Milivojevic (Serbia)

Fulham (1) - Aleksandr Mitrovic (Serbia)

Watford (1) - Andre Carrillo (Peru)

Bournemouth (0)

Newcastle (0)

Tottenham, Chelsea and Manchester United also boast teams packed full of international talent, as demonstrated by the fact that they will both have 12 players at the tournament.Â 

The United contingent includes new signing Fred, who is in the Brazil squad.Â Â 

Arsenal and Leicester are both well represented at the competition with eight players each.

The Arsenal players involved include new signing Stephan Lichtsteiner, who is in the Switzerland squad, and midfielder Mesut Ozil,Â who will be aiming to help Germany regain the World Cup.

Liverpool have seven players in Russia, including Egypt winger Mohamed Salah.Â 

Each of the newly-promoted clubs will have at least one player out in Russia.

Cardiff have two in Marko Grujic of Serbia and Aron Gunnarsson of Iceland.

Wolves also have the same amount as Alfred N'Diaye is in the Senegal squad and Romain Saiss is with Morocco.

Fulham have a single representative in striker Aleksandr Mitrovic, who is in the Serbia squad.Â 

According to FIFA, players who were on loan last season are still affiliated to that club for the tournament.Â Â
item.dc:abstract: The World Cup is rapidly approaching and one of the most intriguing aspects of this summer's tournament in Russia will be seeing how the Premier League stars involved get on. Of the 20 teams that will be in theÂ English top flight next season, 18 of them will have at least one representative in Russia, with Bournemouth and Newcastle the only clubs without a player at the competition. Last season's champions Manchester City, perhaps unsurprisingly, lead the way for the most players at the World Cup out of the Premier League sides, with 16 members of Pep Guardiola's squad involved, including Kevin De Bruyne and Sergio Aguero, who will hope to thrive for Belgium and Argentina respectively.Â

item.content:encoded:
Tottenham target Leon Bailey has been asked to stay for another season at Bayer Leverkusen.

The talented winger has attracted attention from Premier league clubs this season with the likes of Chelsea, Arsenal, Manchester City, United and Liverpool all adding him to their shortlist of targets.

However, it is understood Tottenham were also showing strong interest in the Jamaica-born flyer who scored 12 goals and added six assists in 27 starts for the Bundesliga side.


Leverkusen though are prepared to demand a huge fee to deter suitors this summer and keep Bailey for at least one more season.

Bailey only joined from Genk in January 2017 for Â£17.5million and while his performances have excited he is still seen as a work in progress.

Tottenham want more pace in their side but Leverkusen's Â£60m plus valuation will make negotiations difficult.

item.title: 'I see myself playing in one of the great clubs... like Manchester United': Levante's rising star Emmanuel Boateng dreams of Old Trafford switch
item.description: Levante's promising young striker, Emmanuel Boateng, has put himself on Jose Mourinho's radar after revealing he is dreaming of a move to a 'big club like Manchester United'.Â
item.content:encoded:
Levante's promising young striker, Emmanuel Boateng, has put himself on Jose Mourinho's radar after revealing he is dreaming of a move to a 'big club like Manchester United'.Â 

The 22-year-old announced himself on the world stage last month with a hat-trick against Barcelona in Levante's 5-4 win. It ended Barcelona's unbeaten run at the very end of the league campaign.

Now Boateng is ready for his next challenge and has claimed he see's himself playing for one of the biggest clubs in the world.Â 


â€˜I always dream big, I see myself playing in one of the great clubs of the world in the next five years,â€™ said Boateng.Â 

â€˜Big clubs like Manchester United and Barcelona excite me.â€™Â 

The Ghanian made his international debut against Japan in a friendly last week and scored in the 2-0 win.

Manchester United are reportedly interested in bolstering their attacking options this window and with a view to bringing in someone as a back-up for Romelu Lukaku, Boateng could be an option.

United have already completed one signing this summer, bringing in Brazilian Fred in a deal worth Â£52m.

Boateng has not been prolific in front of goal so far in his career but continues to impress.Â 

He has moved from club to club, having started his professional career at Rio Ave in Portugal.Â 

After one season with the first-team squad he was picked up by Moreirense where he spent two years before moving across the border to La Liga.

Boateng also scored the opener in Levante's 2-2 draw with Real Madrid back in February.

Mourinho will be looking at a number of attacking options and United have also been linked with swoops for Gareth Bale and Marko Arnautovic among others.

item.description: Despite winning the Premier League in record-breaking fashion last season, Pep Guardiola is not resting on his laurels and is looking to bolster his already formidable squad.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City have been hit with a huge setback in their pursuit of Miralem Pjanic as Juventus have rejected a Â£44million bid, according to reports in Italy.Â 

Despite winning the Premier League in record-breaking fashion last season, becoming the first side to reach 100 points, Pep Guardiola is not resting on his laurels and is looking to bolster his already formidable squad.

And according to Italian publication Tuttosport, City have seen a Â£44million offer rejected with Juventus very keen on keeping one of their star players.


Tuttosport report that the Bosnian midfielder is increasingly essential to Massimiliano Allegri's plans for the future.

The Serie A giants see the offer as considerable but not enough to offload him to a European rival due to his importance in the heart of midfield.

Furthermore, the potential income from the sale of Pjanic would barely reach half of what Sergej Milinkovic-Savic would cost Juventus.Â 

Guardiola is attempting to improve his squad even further as they look to continue dominating English football and make a strong assault on the Champions League.

City were knocked out at the quarter-final stage of Europe's top-tier competition after losing against Liverpool over two legs.

item.title: Didier Drogba and Newcastle lead tributes to Cheick Tiote on the one-year anniversary of his sudden death
item.description: On the anniversary of Cheick Tiote's tragic death, compatriot Didier Drogba has shown his respects by sharing an image of the pair together during an Ivory Coast match.
item.content:encoded:
On the anniversary of Cheick Tiote's tragic death, compatriot Didier Drogba has shown his respects by sharing an image of the pair together during an Ivory Coast match.

Tiote died suddenly on 5 June 2017 after suffering from a cardiac arrest. He collapsed during a training session in China at just 30 years old.

He had been playing for Beijing Enterprises having moved from Newcastle just four months earlier, who have also given a tribute to their former midfielder.


Accompanying the image, Drogba said: 'Already a year since you left us, miss you my soldier.'Â 

Newcastle also commemorated the anniversary of their former midfielder's death by giving their condolences to his family.

They said: 'A year ago today, former Newcastle United midfielder Cheick TiotÃ© tragically passed away at the age of just 30. Our thoughts are with Cheick's family.'

Tiote made 139 appearances across six and half seasons in the North East. His only goal for Newcastle was a memorable equaliser as they came back from 4-0 down at home to Arsenal.Â 

A year ago today, former #NUFC midfielder Cheick TiotÃ© tragically passed away at the age of just 30. Our thoughts are with Cheickâ€™s family. pic.twitter.com/e5vvVNAmXb

â€” Newcastle United FC (@NUFC) June 5, 2018

Tiote and Drogba made up part of a golden generation for the Ivory Coast, along with Yaya and Kolo Toure, Solomon Kalour, Emmanuel Eboue and Gervinho among others.

In 2015 they won the African Cup of Nations for the first time in 13 years and only the second time in the nation's history.

Tiote was also a key part of the squad that qualified for the 2010 and 2014 World Cup's. They have only reached the finals on three occasions and did not reach the 2018 tournament in Russia.Â 

At the time of his sudden death, Newcastle manager Rafa Benitez said: 'It is with great sadness that I have this afternoon learned of Cheick's death.

'In all the time that I have known him, he was a true professional, dedicated and above all, a great man. Our hearts go out to his family and friends at such a sad time.'
