item.title: Yaya Toure's agent warns Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola of 'African curse' after fall out with Ivorian starâ€¦ and claims midfielder will play for any top six side for Â£1 A WEEK
item.description: Yaya Toure's agent Dimitri Seluk has warned Pep Guardiola of an 'African curse' following his client'sÂ accusation that the Manchester City boss does not like picking African footballers.
item.content:encoded:
Yaya Toure's agent Dimitri Seluk has warned Pep Guardiola of an 'African curse' following his client'sÂ sensational accusation that the Manchester City manager does not like picking African footballers.

Toure left City at the end of the season after eight trophy-laden years. But in his final campaign his relationship with Guardiola deteriorated and he made only oneÂ Premier League start.

In an interview with a French football magazine, the 35-year-old made the extraordinary suggestion that he was being discriminated against by Guardiola on racial grounds.


'Pep did everything to spoil my last season. He was cruel with me,' said Toure. 'Do you really think he could've been like that with Andres Iniesta? It got to the point I asked myself if it was because of my colour. I am not the first. Other Barcelona players asked the question.

'Maybe us Africans aren't always treated the same by certain people. When you see the problems (Pep) has often had with African players, everywhere he has been, I ask myself questions. He is too intelligent to be caught. He will never admit it. But the day he picks a team with five Africans in it, I promise I will send him a cake.'Â 

Now,Â in an lengthy interview with Russian outletÂ Sport24, Seluk has warned the City boss of an 'African curse' and insisted Toure would be happy to play for another club in the Premier League's top six for a lowly wage of Â£1 per-week.

'Yaya knows Guardiola like no other,' he said. 'He worked with him both in Barcelona and in Manchester City. With all the desire, nothing good about the human qualities of Guardiola can be said.Â 

'God sees everything. As a man who acted with Yaya, the legend of the club, which under different pretexts did not give the opportunity to go on the field. He turned all Africa against himself, many African fans turned away from Manchester City.

'And I'm sure that many African shamans in the future will not allow Guardiola to win the Champions League. This will be for Guardiola an African curse. Life will show whether I am right or not.'Â Â 

Toure played under Guardiola at Barcelona, winning the Champions League in 2009 as well as two league titles and a Spanish Cup. However, the two men never looked at ease with each other when Guardiola succeeded Manuel Pellegrini at City two summers ago.

Seluk bemoaned how the Spaniard first came to the Etihad Stadium and claimed he announced his arrival early purely to disrupt Pellegrini's final season at the helm.

'You can start with the fact that he came to Manchester City in a nasty manner. The transfer was announced at a time when Pellegrini, his co-worker in the coaching department, was still at the helm of the team,' he added.

'Guardiola was afraid that Pellegrini would win the championship and other tournaments that season, as he did before he came to Bayern Munich, when Jupp Heynckes won all that is possible. Guardiola could not repeat the achievements of Heynckes, being the next three years at the helm of the best German club, which without Guardiola again leads and wins.Â 

'What did Guardiola achieve? In two years he won the same as Mancini or Pellegrini. And Pellegrini reached the semi-finals of the Champions League, and Guardiola â€“ not yet. Manchester City has now extended the contract with him for three years.

'I bet that Guardiola will not win the Champions League during this time, no matter how much money he has spent, but he likes to do it. When only Â£200million is spent on the line of defence, when money is not countedâ€¦

'Perhaps, many will say that this is the style of Guardiola, that he plays enchanting football. Only when you buy all the best players in the world, it's much easier than, for example, in the case of (Claudio) Ranieri, who won the Premier League with Leicester.'

As a free agent, Seluk insisted the veteran could still be of use to the other members of the Premier League's top six and claimed next season will be focused on proving Guardiola wrong.

'Now Yaya has many offers from different countries, where they are ready to pay a lot of money, but we decided to dedicate the next season to Guardiola. And to prove and show the fans of Manchester City that Yaya is not finished with football. He is full of energy and wants to play this season in England,' he said.

'At a time when huge sums are being spent in England for the purchase of football players, I officially declare that Yaya is ready to move as a free agent to any English club in the top six with a salary of Â£1 a week â€“ but for certain successes to make a bonus system.

'I believe that a player like Yaya would not harm Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United, Tottenham and Liverpool. Yaya â€“ the winner. And never before has a top footballer with leadership qualities harmed any club, especially when it is not necessary to pay for it.'

Manchester City declined to comment on Monday night.Â

item.title: Roberto Firmino and Ringo Starr merge into one while Mo Salah wears John Lennon's glasses in weird Beatles artwork shared byÂ Simon Mignolet
item.description: The edited cover had Liverpool captain Jordan Henderson in place of Paul McCartney, while Salah wore Lennon's hair and glasses. Mignolet's face featured in place of George Harrison's
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet geared up for the World Cup by declaring on Twitter: 'The Beatles are going to Russia!'.

Mignolet, who is heading to this summer's tournament as one of Belgium's back-up keepers, accompanied his message with a comically-photoshopped version of The Beatles' 1968 cover artwork from the single 'Back in the U.S.S.R.'

The edited cover had Jordan Henderson in place of Paul McCartney, while Mo Salah wore John Lennon's hair and glasses.


Mignolet's face featured in place of George Harrison's, while Roberto Firmino and Ringo Starr merged into one in the bottom right corner.

'Like your new haircut, @MoSalah,' joked Mignolet, before asking Jordan Henderson if he was 'ready' for England's clash with Belgium on June 28.

Mignolet has not played for Liverpool since January when he was displaced by Loris Karius as the club's No 1 stopper.

But the Belgian has responded to his demotion with class. He has not once questioned his manager's decision publicly and has remained fully supportive of his team-mates.

After last month's Champions League final defeat at the hands of Real Madrid, unused sub Mignolet tweeted: 'I know this morning we are all desperately disappointed, players and fans. Despite an amazing campaign the journey ends here. I'd like to thank the fans for their terrific form all season. Proud of all Reds'.

item.title: Trophies and tension... Pep Guardiola and Yaya Toure enjoyed great success with Barcelona but, like at Manchester City, their relationship was strained
item.description: PETE JENSON: Not many could complain about a midfield three of Sergio Busquets, Andres Iniesta and Xavi but Toure did. Still, he played 77 games for Guardiola during their time at Barcelona.
item.content:encoded:
'It is a very sweet night, one of the happiest of my football life,' said Pep Guardiola as Barcelona won 6-2 away to Real Madrid in 2009. Yaya Toure put in a swaggering performance in a deep central midfield position for all but five minutes of the contest. It was a perfect night.

The relationship between the manager, who had been a midfielder himself, and the Ivorian was not always so 'sweet'. When Guardiola promoted Sergio Busquets from the B team into the holding role, Toure found himself out of favour. Not many could complain about a midfield three of Busquets, Andres Iniesta and Xavi but Toure did.

Still, he played 77 games for Guardiola, winning both the Champions League and the Copa del Rey, playing the finals as a central defender. He also left the club with two Spanish league titles.


When he departed for the Premier League in 2010, this is what he had to say. 'Whenever I asked him something, he (Guardiola) always gave strange answers. He pretty much ignored me until City's offer came in. That's why I eventually opted to leave. I didn't speak to Guardiola for a year,' he was quoted as saying on Goal.com.

'If he had talked to me, I would have stayed at Barcelona. I did not want to go and wanted to end my career at Barcelona. However, he had no faith in me.'

Guardiola denied the claims, telling AS: 'I talk to anyone and the doors to my office and house are always open for the players.

'The truth is that (Toure) asked to leave. We even tried to convince him to stay.'

Guardiola coached three big name players of African descent at Barcelona as well as French defender Eric Abidal, born to Martinican parents in Lyon.

Toure was not the only one from that group who fell foul of his manager.

Guardiola wanted to sell Samuel Eto'o before taking over the first team but was dissuaded by other senior players.

He also asked that both Deco and Ronaldinho were got rid of before his first campaign started. They were sold in 2008, Eto'o departed a year later after playing a key role in the team winning the treble.

Guardiola developed a close bond with Abidal after an early row about what language was spoken in the dressing room and he spoke of the unparalleled 'humanity' of Mali international Seydou Keita, who was his first signing at Barcelona and was with him for four seasons.

Abidal said subsequently: 'It was complicated at the start. Guardiola confronted me about not speaking Spanish but always speaking in French with Thierry Henry.

'I told him: "Firstly, don't talk to me like I am a little boy. And secondly why can the Catalans speak to each other in Catalan?".

'From there the argument got more heated until I had to go to the president to explain it to him.'

Abidal went on to say in the same interview: 'He is a top class coach. I learned every day with him.'

Keita played 188 games for Barcelona under Guardiola after signing from Sevilla in 2008.

'He has been my moral barometer all these years,' said Guardiola of the Mali player.

'There are very few players who have given as much as he has. I have never met person with more humanity and doubt I ever will.'Â

item.title: Manchester City named a training pitch after him... but can they still love Yaya Toure now?
item.description: IAN HERBERT: Buried in the latest stream of invective from Toure is a plain, inconvenient truth about his last season at City. He ran out of power. When all was said and done, his legs had gone.
item.content:encoded:
Buried in the latest stream of invective from Yaya Toure is a plain and inconvenient truth about his last season at Manchester City. He ran out of power. When all was said and done, his legs had gone.

His performance at the heart of the team's midfield in the League Cup semi-final first leg against Bristol City, six months ago, got to the heart of it. Toure laboured desperately, lasted 70 minutes and was replaced by Sergio Aguero, who scored a 90th-minute winner to rescue the team from embarrassment. Bristol City finished the season 11th in the Championship. Toure barely featured again.

This is an outcome which befalls every player in the final outcome and while most accept it with good grace, grateful for what they have had, Toure's extraordinary outburst against the manager who presided over his last years is an act of narcissism. To embellish his attack on Pep Guardiola with a casually vicious claim of racism discredits those many individuals who are genuinely working to remove the scourge of discrimination from football.


The suggestions that Guardiola's team selections represent an illicit form of anti-African sentiment lack any kind of credibility - and not only because the manager in question is about to pay out Â£75million to Leicester City for Riyad Mahrez, an Algeria international.

It is Toure's suggestion that Guardiola 'stole' his 'farewell' from City which really drives a stake through his personal credibility. This is a player who, less than a month ago, was being feted to the heavens. A training pitch at City's academy has been named after him, decorated by a mosaic of his winning goal in the 2011 FA Cup Final against Stoke City. Only the hugely loved Pablo Zabaleta has been afforded anything like the same treatment.

We are witnessing an ego talking: a individual who cannot contemplate someone else commanding centre stage. Toure does not care for Guardiola's controlling man-management style. Yet when it comes to Guardiola's coaching â€“ the aspect that really matters â€“ he can't admit it is anything less than impressive.

He might display more credibility and command more respect at moments like this if he had only engaged a less intellectually challenged agent than Dmitri Seluk.

Seluk has been a malign influence on Toure ever since he took a punt on the young player in 2003. Toure was drifting, having just experienced a cool reception on trial at Arsenal and ultimately failed to secure a British work permit. He has somehow always felt a debt of obligation to Seluk for giving him a break.

But thought the agent has fuelled a sense of victimhood in his client, it is not the whole story. Toure is 35 now â€“ old enough to see that his complaints are ridiculous. No birthday cake, not enough photographs of himself on display, not enough money despite more than Â£200,000 a week. Has any player cried wolf quite so much?

The irony of it all is that City had actually wanted to maintain lasting attachment to this individual because he, as much as any player, has taken them up to the top table during the club's often challenging Abu Dhabi decade, scoring at the critical moments. Club chairman Khaldoon al-Mubarak said just two weeks ago that Toure would 'always have a place' at the club. That promise looks extremely hard to keep now.

item.title: Premier League executive chairman Richard Scudamore has a plan to end TV money scrap after pressure from Liverpool owner John Henry
item.description: CHARLES SALE - SPORTS AGENDA: The issue will dominate this week's summer meeting, with Scudamore not wanting clubs to leave Harrogate until there is the necessary 14-6 majority.
item.content:encoded:
Premier League executive chairman Richard Scudamore is banking on a new formula for the distribution of overseas TV money solving an issue which is splitting the 20 clubs.

Scudamore has staked his reputation on finding a solution to the Big Six wanting more money from the overseas deal, when the PL have always previously divided the proceeds equally.

The issue will dominate this week's summer meeting, with Scudamore not wanting clubs to leave Harrogate until there is the necessary 14-6 majority needed for a rule change.

Liverpool owner John Henry has ramped up the pressure, saying: 'It's a disagreement based entirely on governance. You cannot stick with the age-old media strategy any more than you can stick with the same football tactics for ever.

'Everyone in the league knows what the large clubs bring to the value of foreign rights, but the large clubs do not have the votes to change something that should have changed as media rights changed over the past 25 years.'

The new proposal is for the overseas cut to be based on the top club income from domestic and foreign TV compared to that of the bottom club. Last season, leading earners Manchester United received 1.6 times as much as Stoke.


The Big Six would like a ratio of two to one while the others want that figure to be more like 1.3 to one. The big hope for Scudamore is that consensus can be reached somewhere around 1.6.

A lot of work still needs to be done, because only West Ham, Leicester and Everton were in the Big Six camp when the last TV meeting was cancelled last October with no hope of 14 clubs backing the change.

Henry added: 'The top three clubs receive less overall TV money than the bottom three when you include parachute payments. It's hard to imagine that continuing much longer.'

Â 

The shock departure of combative communications director Susannah Gill from Arena Racing Company, who run 16 racecourses and 35 per cent of the fixtures, is understood to follow a major fallout with her boss Martin Cruddace. It reached the point where ARC top brass would not accept the outcome of an industry board meeting because Gill was there representing them.

Â 

Initial problems for FA

The number of people travelling to Russia in the official FA World Cup party is still to be announced, but surely the figure will not reach the ridiculous level it did in Brazil four years ago.

As a result of negative publicity over the 90-plus FA personnel there, kit suppliers Nike will no longer identify travel bags with numbers, but use initials instead so as not to draw attention to how many people are on the trip.

But this brings its own complications. If there are two RS's, for example â€” an old-fogey FA blazer and Raheem Sterling â€” what's to stop them picking the wrong bags off the bus?

Â 

FIFA desperately needs a transparent 2026 World Cup hosting ballot a week on Wednesday after the utterly corrupt vote in 2010. Yet the latest FIFA shenanigans have seen South American confederation CONMEBOL refuse a presentation request from Morocco because they are committed to supporting the rival bid of the USA, Canada and Mexico. All the other confederations will allow both sides to present in Moscow.

Â 

Former FIFA referee Mark Halsey has finally received an England cap to recognise his career achievements. Lesser match officials had been given the coveted caps, which are handed out now by FA referees chief David Elleray. Halsey complained about his snub to FA chief executive Martin Glenn, who intervened on his behalf.

Â 

Harlequins are expected to make the low-key appointment of Australian Billy Millard as general manager after going over budget to recruit England defence coach Paul Gustard as head coach. Millard filled the same role at Cardiff Blues until April 2017.

item.title: Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino rejected chance to become Real Madrid manager over fears of being labelled a mercenary
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino rejected the chance to become Real Madrid's next manager because he didn't want to labelled a mercenary.
item.content:encoded:
Mauricio Pochettino rejected the chance to become Real Madrid's next manager because he didn't want to labelled a mercenary.

Sportsmail understands Pochettino was, for all intents and purposes, offered the vacant manager's job at the Bernabeu after discreet overtures from Real officials.

The prospect of returning to Spain to take one of the biggest jobs in world football was certainly an attractive prospect for Pochettino.


But sources claim the Argentine turned his back on a dream switch to Real, knowing such a move would lead to serious questions over his loyalty.

Pochettino showed a huge commitment to Tottenham at the end of last month by agreeing a new five-year deal to stay in north London.

And the South American is well aware that leaving Tottenham for Real just days after signing his Â£8.5million-a-year contract would leave his credibility in tatters.

Since agreeing his new deal, Pochettino has held talks with a number of key players, pleading with them to follow his example by signing extensions at Tottenham.

Among others Pochettino has held face-to-face discussions with Christian Eriksen, who is now poised to sign fresh terms.

Harry Kane and Dele Alli have also been lined up for improved contracts.

Having spoken about how much he values loyalty to his players, Pochettino knows the consequences if he decided to jump ship.

Knowing chairman Daniel Levy would rebuff any approach from Spain, Pochettino knew he would have to force the issue if he wanted the Real job.

It's now apparent that Pochettino was unwilling to risk his reputation, fearing his integrity would suffer an irreparable blow.

item.title: 'You cannot stick with the same media strategy forever': Liverpool owner John Henry demands the Big Six get their fair share of overseas TV money
item.description: Premier League's leading clubs will seek a larger slice of international television cash at a summit this week, with Liverpool owner John Henry irritatied at subsidising lower teams.
item.content:encoded:
The Premier League's leading clubs will seek a larger slice of international television cash at a summit this week, with Liverpool owner John Henry expressing irritation at the ongoing subsidising of lower-ranking teams.

Along with the rest of the top six, Liverpool last year failed to secure an agreement on a new formula to end the equal split of income from overseas channels between the 20 clubs.Â 

But talks have continued and the divisive issue is set to be the main talking point at the league's annual meeting on Thursday when a consensus will be sought.


'It's a disagreement based entirely on governance,' Henry said. 'Everyone in the league knows what the large clubs bring to the value of foreign rights, but the large clubs do not have the votes to change something that should have changed as media rights changed over the past 25 years.'

About half the clubs in October accepted 35 percent of the foreign TV revenue being dispersed based on league positions but any change requires the approval of 14 teams.

There is a meritocratic allocation of domestic TV revenue, with half split depending on a team's finishing place and live appearances on British channels. The remaining half is shared equally, giving each team Â£34.8m.

Since international revenue is distributed equally, the 20 clubs each collected Â£40.8m last season regardless of where they finished in the standings or how appealing their games are to foreign viewers.

'You cannot stick with the same media strategy forever any more than you can stick with the same football tactics forever,' said Henry, the Boston Red Sox owner who led the Fenway Sports Group takeover of Liverpool in 2010.

Liverpool earned Â£145.9m from the league in the recently-completed season. For finishing fourth, the club collected Â£32.8m.Â 

Demonstrating their domestic appeal, the Champions League finalists banked Â£32.7m based on their Premier League appearances in Britain - more than the three teams above them and the same as sixth-place Arsenal.

The distribution model ensured that even last-place West Bromwich Albion received Â£94.7m, bulked out by the foreign cash that does not take into consideration the team's popularity.Â 

British broadcasters are also obliged to show each team live at least 10 times per season. Despite only nine of its games being aired, West Brom still received domestic income based on the minimum requirement being met.Â 

Additionally, to soften the blow of relegation, West Brom will also receive up to Â£90m over the next three years if it remains out of the top-flight.

'Because of this arrangement (the distribution of overseas revenue) and due to parachute payments to relegated clubs, the top three clubs each year in the Premier League receive less overall TV monies than the bottom three clubs when you include parachute payments,' Henry said.Â 

'It's hard to imagine this continuing much longer. In America, where we have closed leagues, you can argue for these types of arrangements, but it's much more difficult to ask independent clubs to subsidise their competitors beyond a certain point when you have relegation and especially with the way media is rapidly changing and being consumed today.'

When the league was established in 1992, clubs never anticipated the overseas demand to watch games with English football in the doldrums after being blighted by crowd disorder.

But now the league is enjoying a huge uplift in the value of rights overseas. There was a tenfold increase in China to Â£525m and NBC's six-year deal in the United States through 2022 is worth Â£750m.

The league has looked to the sale of overseas rights to provide an upsurge after the value of domestic rights flat-lined.

item.title: Arsenal preparing move to land Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini on free transfer
item.description: The Belgian international, who was named in his country's World Cup squad on Monday, will become a free agent at the end of this month if United fail to agree a new deal.
item.content:encoded:
Arsenal are understood to be preparing a move for Manchester United midfielderÂ Marouane Fellaini.

The Belgian international, who was named in his country's World Cup squad on Monday, will become a free agent at the end of this month if United fail to agree a new deal.

Sportsmail revealed in May thatÂ Fellaini was demanding at least a two-year deal to stay beyond this season, while United only offered one year with the option of an additional 12 months.


The Belgium midfielder's representatives have been in talks with a number of clubs for some time, including teams from the Premier League, Turkey and Italy.Â 

The Gunners are believed to be interested in strengthening their midfield ranks with Fellaini.

In 23 appearances in the season just finished he scored five goals and provided one assist.Â 

The 30-year-old moved to Old Trafford back in 2013 forÂ Â£27.5million from Everton and is on Â£80,000-a-week.

Arsenal brought in Sven Mislintat as their new head of recruitment back in NovemberÂ andÂ announcedÂ Unai Emery as their new boss on May 23.

Mislintat is credited with bringing Robert Lewandowski, Shinji Kagawa and Ousmane Dembele to Borussia Dortmund, as well as being a key player in signing Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang from the German club in January.Â 

He will work closely with Emery as well as chief executive Ivan Gazidis and oversee the club's global scouting network in order to revolutionise the way they recruit players.

item.title: Marko Arnautovic claims Manchester United are yet to approach him but is flattered by interest: 'It's nice to hear'
item.description: Marko Arnautovic has admitted links with Manchester United are 'nice to hear' but insists there has been no contact as of yet.Â Mourinho is reportedly interested in signing the forward.
item.content:encoded:
Marko Arnautovic has admitted links with Manchester United are 'nice to hear' but insists there has been no contact as of yet.Â 

Jose Mourinho is reportedly interested in bringing the West Ham forward to Old Trafford as he looks to bolster his attacking options.Â 

Arnautovic is currently on international duty with Austria and only joined the Hammers from Stoke last year.Â 


When asked about the rumours, ArnautovicÂ Â said: 'It's nice to hear.

'I've not heard anything from my brother, my agent.

'You can keep asking this question, you'll never hear the answer from me.'Â 

The 29-year-old impressed during his year in East London, scoring 11 goals and producing six assists, during what was a difficult season for West Ham.

They now value the striker to be worth around Â£50m as he proved to be a real asset to them under David Moyes, helping to guide them to Premier League safety.Â 

Man United are looking to add players in a number of areas and already set to complete the signing of Fred from Shakthar Donetsk.

Arnautovic is a versatile player and can fill in across the front-line, with Man United particularly keen to bring in additions who can play on the right-wing, where the Austrian spent most of his time at Stoke.

Jose Mourinho was also reluctant to talk about the speculation after claiming he hadn't spoke to Arnautovic, but did not deny he had plans to.Â 

Mourinho said: 'He was on holiday, he told you. I haven't spoken to him, he was on holidays.'Â 

With Austria not at the World Cup after finishing fourth in their qualifying group, Mourinho will have all summer to negotiate a move with the forward.Â

item.title: Everton boss Marco Silva and director of football Marcel Brands vow to work together in the transfer market... as they admit Wayne Rooney could go
item.description: Marco Silva and Marcel Brands have vowed to work 'together' in the transfer market as they aim to overhaul Everton's squad amid a fresh start for the Merseyside club this summer.
item.content:encoded:
Marco Silva and Marcel Brands have vowed to work 'together' in the transfer market as they aim to overhaul Everton's squad amid a fresh start for the club.Â 

Silva, who replaces Sam Allardyce as manager at Goodison Park, was unveiled to the media at the club's Finch Farm training ground on Monday.Â 

The former Hull and Watford boss will be put straight to work and said he had identified transfer targets which he would be working on over the summer.


'I have big names. The list is not so big,' said Silva.

'We will do everything we can to improve. I like to see competition between players every day.'

Director of football Brands, another new arrival, said he would work alongside Silva on bringing new players to the club.

'We do it together,' he added. 'I worked with a lot of good coaches, with LVG (Louis van Gaal), with Ronald Koeman, Phillip Cocu and we didn't have one player we didn't agree on.'

Both Brands and Silva did not totally close the door on striker Wayne Rooney who has held talks with DC United about a possible move to Major League Soccer in the United States.

Brands said: 'There is a possibility he will leave. He is talking with Washington, it is no secret. We will also talk with him.'

'He has already started his deal (talks),' added Silva. 'Rooney is a club legend and we need to understand everything. The door is open every time for him.'

item.title: Fred Q&A: Who is the Shakhtar Donetsk star closing in on a Â£53million move to Manchester United?
item.description: Who is Fred, and what can Manchester United fans expect from him if the deal goes ahead as expected?The midfielder is on the verge of making the switch to Old Trafford for Â£53million.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United are set to make their first signing of the summer transfer window this week, with Fred poised to undergo a medical before completing his move from Shakhtar Donetsk.Â 

The midfielder is on the verge of making the switch to Old Trafford for Â£53million and will hope to provide Jose Mourinho's side with a different dimension next season.

So, who is Fred, and what can United fans expect from him if the deal goes ahead as expected?


Who is Fred?

Born in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, on March 5, 1993; Fred spent time in the youth setups of Atletico Mineiro and Porto Alegre prior to making the switch to Internacional in 2010.

It was at Internacional where he made his first steps in senior football, with some encouraging performances eventually earning him a transfer to Shakhtar Donetsk in 2013.

In the ensuing period, Fred has enjoyed much success, winning three league titles and three Ukranian cups, while he has also become increasingly involved with the Brazil national team, for whom he now has eight caps.

Â 

Where exactly does he play?

Earlier in his career Fred received some playing time as an attacking midfielder but he is now fully settled in a slightly deeper position.

Although he can play in a more defensive role at times, Fred is at his best as a central midfielder and relishes helping his side to build up play with neat passes, while he can also make good use of his pace to burst past opponents.

Â 

What are his key attributes?Â Â 

Most importantly, Fred's passing is of a very high standard and it is likely that he will give United some much needed composure.Â 

In addition to his searing speed, Fred is also excellent technically and can help to push his side forwards.

Fred's stamina is one of his main attributes and he should help to provide United with plenty of energy.

Â 

What are his weaknesses?

Fred is just 5ft 6 1/2 inches so, understandably, isn't especially impressive aerially.Â 

He also isn't particularly prolific when presented with goalscoring chances.

Â 

Which United players should fear for their places?Â Â Â Â 

The main player that could see his playing time significantly reduced as a consequence of Fred's arrival is Ander Herrera.

Fred is considerably more dynamic than the Spaniard, who can find it difficult to cope in the midfield battle at times.

The arrival of Fred also indicates that Marouane Fellaini, whose contract expires at the end of this month, is likely to leave.

Â 

Who is Fred's famous agent?

Fred is represented by former Arsenal midfielder and Brazil international Gilberto Silva.

Prior to that, Fred's agent was Ronaldinho's brother Assis.

Â 

Why was Fred banned last year?

At the 2015 Copa America, Fred tested positive for hydrochlorothiazide, a medication that is often used to treat high blood pressure.

In March 2017 he was hit with a suspension by FIFA that lasted until July that year and covered both international and club football.

Â 

Who is Fred's girlfriend?

Fred's girlfriend is Monique Salum, a chemical engineer from Brazil. Fred frequently posts pictures on InstagramÂ of them together.

5. Mohamed SalahÂ (Â£150m)

item.title: Chelsea and Arsenal line up moves for Barcelona goalkeeper Jasper Cillessen as they look to recruit a new No 1
item.description: Chelsea and Arsenal have both been linked with a summer move for Barcelona goalkeeper Jasper Cillessen as they look to recruit a new No 1. He is keen to play more first team football.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea and Arsenal have both been linked with a summer move for Barcelona goalkeeper Jasper Cillessen as they look to recruit a new No 1.

Thibaut Courtois' stay at Stamford Bridge appears to be coming to an end while the Gunners are keen to sign a long-term replacement for 36-year-old Petr Cech.

Cillessen signed for Barcelona in 2016 but has been largely consigned to a place on the bench due to the consistency of Germany's Marc-Andre ter Stegen.


According to Spanish outlet SPORT,Â Barcelona will not let the Dutchman go for anything less than hisÂ â‚¬60 million (Â£52m)Â release clause.

However, his desire for regular first team football pay prove key in a departure from the Nou Camp with both London clubs able to offer that.Â 

Liverpool have also been linked with a move for the 29-year-old in recent days as their search for a new goalkeeper continues.

Cillessen made just 11 appearances in all competitions during a frustrating season at the Catalan giants.

He kept eight clean sheets in those games and conceded just three goals in 990 minutes of action.Â

item.title: Fred set to undergo Manchester United medical on Monday as Brazilian star closes in on Â£53m transfer
item.description: Fred is expected to complete his Â£53m move to Manchester United in the next 24 hours after he left Brazil's camp to undergo a medical. Hhe will become United's first signing of the summer.
item.content:encoded:
Fred is expected to complete his Â£53million move to Manchester United in the next 24 hours after he left Brazil's camp to undergo a medical.

The Shakthar Donetsk midfielder, who came off the bench in the 2-0 win over Croatia on Sunday, will become Jose Mourinho's first signing of the summer.

The 25-year-old has been in talks with the Old Trafford club after a January move to rivals City collapsedÂ and Brazil head coach Tite wants business concluded swiftly.


'This is inevitable when we're meeting up in the summer,' said Tite.

'Players are always thinkingof their careers. What you say is Please resolve it as soon as possible so we can get them focused back on the task in hand with the national team. If I was a club manager, I would be looking to sign him.

Gabriel Jesus added: 'Fred's future? We thought he was going to Manchester City but now I can't say anything. It's something up to him. If he joins United I can't root for his team, but I will root for him on an individual basis.'

Fred replaced Philippe Coutinho with 10 minutes to go as Brazil stepped up their World Cup preparations with a win over Croatia at Anfield.

Second-half goals from Neymar and Roberto Firmino handed the South Americans victory and they now have just one more game, against Austria next Sunday, before the World Cup begins.

They have been drawn to play Switzerland, Costa Rica and Serbia in Group E of football's showpiece tournament.Â

item.title: 'He's going nowhere - he is a big investment for us':Â Barcelona chief Josep Bartomeu insists Ousmane Dembele will remain at Nou Camp amid Liverpool and PSG links
item.description: Ousmane Dembele isn't going anywhere next season, according to Barcelona president Josep Bartomeu. Dembele has been linked with loan moves to Liverpool and Paris Saint-Germain.
item.content:encoded:
Ousmane Dembele isn't going anywhere next season, according to Barcelona president Josep Bartomeu.

The Frenchman has been linked with moves to Liverpool and Paris Saint-Germain in recent weeks after reports suggested the Catalan club wanted to loan out the Â£98million star next season.

But Bartomeu has insisted that the club have made a big investment on the 21-year-old as he is predicted to be 'one for the future'.


'Dembele will go nowhere. He and [Philippe] Coutinho are a big investment for us,' Bartomeu said, according to Spanish news outletÂ Sport.

'They are very important to our project and we expect a lot from them.

'Coutinho in the last four months has been very active in the team but Dembele is a very young player and talented and we expect great things. Next season will be different.Â Â 

'It's not easy to play at Barca in your first year because the style of football is quite different from at other teams.'Â 

While Bartomeu remained confident that Dembele wouldn't be leaving, the 55-year-old suggested that the club will be fairly active in the transfer market this summer.

'Some players will come, others will go, that's normal. But there's no doubt that, without naming names because a lot of them are negotiating now with the club, new players will arrive.'

Thiago, currently at Bayern Munich, has been linked with a return to Barcelona but the reigning La Liga champions will have to part with Â£70m if they are to bring the Spaniard back to the Nou Camp.

The Catalan giants have also been heavily linked with a move for Atletico Madrid's Antoine Griezmann, with a move reportedly close to being completed.Â

item.title: Manchester United star Chris Smalling makes the most of his summer without the World Cup by visiting the Golden Triangle alongside wife Samantha
item.description: Manchester United defender Chris Smalling has continued to make the most of his time off this summer by sharing more memories of his trip toÂ Southeast Asia with wife Samantha.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United defender Chris Smalling has continued to make the most of his time off this summer by sharing more memories of his trip toÂ Southeast Asia.

Smalling was axed from Gareth Southgate's World Cup squad and therefore has some time to himself before returning for pre-season training with Jose Mourinho.

The 28-year-old has continued his Asian adventure alongside wife Samantha by posing for a snap at the famous Golden Triangle.


The Golden Triangle is the area where the borders of Thailand, Laos and Myanmar meet at the Ruak and Mekong Rivers.Â 

The couple have been taking advantage of the region's finest cultural highlights and took a cookery class, a Muay Thai session and a trip through the mud on a quad bike in Thailand this week.

Smalling is seen as one of the biggest causalities since Gareth Southgate took charge of the Three Lions in November 2016.

Southgate, himself a former England defender, views Smalling as a defender without the finesse to play out from the back, something that continues, no doubt, to irk the United centre-half.

Speaking after being dropped for friendlies in November by Southgate, Smalling said: 'You donâ€™t play for one of the biggest clubs in the world for as long as I have and win every trophy bar the Champions League without being able to do everything a top defender needs to do, be it playing or defending.'

But with John Stones, Harry Maguire, Jones, Kyle Walker and Gary Cahill ahead of him, Smalling never looked likely of earning a spot in the 23-man squad and under Southgate, his international future looks bleak.Â

item.title: The Pep effect can help Brazil at the World Cup, says Fernandinho while Manchester City team-mate Danilo is also full of praise for Guardiola
item.description: Two of City's World Cup-bound superstars have hailed Guardiola for restoring their belief and confidence. Brazil meet Croatia in their penultimate warm-up fixture at Anfield on Sunday.
item.content:encoded:
Two of Manchester City's World Cup-bound superstars have hailedÂ Pep Guardiola for restoring their belief and confidence.

Brazil meet Croatia in their penultimate warm-up fixture at Anfield on Sunday, the latest stage in their determination to erase the humiliation of four years ago when they were thrashed 7-1 by Germany on home soil in the semi-finals.

Midfielder Fernandinho, an integral part of City's record-breaking Premier league title success, credits Guardiola with turning him into a far better player which, he says, can only stand him in good stead in Russia.Â 

Brazil begin their World Cup campaign against Switzerland on June 17 under charismatic new coach Tite but Fernandino says the contribution of his club manager is just as important.

'You see football differently with him,' said Fernandinho. 'He treasures things he believe can make a player better. In two seasons working with him I improved considerably. It's a privilege to work with him. He's one of the best and has improved all of us at City in terms of teamwork.'

City's Brazilian full back Danilo echoed those sentiments. 'We have four City players in our squad and the pressing game we play has been so important for me,' he said. 'The way he rotates tactically with the emphasis on ball possession has helped me so much.'


When it comes to potential opponents in the latter stages of the World Cup, Fernandinho rates Spain as the biggest European obstacle to Brazil's chances, significantly not even mentioning England. 'I watched their recent 1-1 draw in Germany and was really impressed by their quality. Of course there is Germany and we also have France and Belgium but I would say overall Spain are far ahead.'

One Brazilian in particular will be conspicuous by his presence on the field on Sunday. Philippe Coutinho returns to Anfield for the first time since his multi-million pound to Barcelona and Fernandinho said: 'He played there for five years and although I haven't spoken to him about it I'm sure he's looking forward to it. he had so many good moments.'

Another player who Fernandinho knows well, of course, is Raheem Sterling. The Brazilian can't understand why the England forward has taken such stick over the now-infamous gun tattoo. 'First of all, he's a top player and was so important for us last season. I don't understand why the British press are pursuing him in this way. He's a lovely guy and I'm so glad to share the dressing room with him.'

item.title: 'I am not close at all... I think being the coach of a club is my job': Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho casts doubt on being Portugal boss in future
item.description: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho has distanced himself from a switch into international football after suggesting he is further away than ever from taking the Portugal job.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho has distanced himself from a switch into international football after suggesting he is further away than ever from taking the Portugal job.

The Portuguese had previously suggested that he will eye the national job once he becomes tired of club football but the United boss looked to ensure supporters he has no plans for a swift exit.

'No. No! I am not close at all,' Mourinho exclusively told GQ magazine.


'I think being the coach of a club is my job. I need to play matches every week and train every day.Â 

'I would say I am even further away from being tired now than I was a few years ago.'

After a disappointing campaign with the Red Devils that ended in an FA Cup final defeat to his old employers Chelsea, Mourinho, while taking a well-earned break, is busy trying to add to his squad.

Exclusively revealed by Sportsmail, United are closing in on Brazilian midfielder Fred from Shakhtar Donestk with a medical planned for the forthcoming week.Â 

The move for the midfielder - who saw a transfer to United's rivals Manchester City collapse in January - would cost an initial Â£43million with add-ons seeing the fee rise to Â£52.2m.

Mourinho is also known to want to add to his defensive options with Porto right back Diogo Dalot also edging closer to a move to Old Trafford.Â Â

item.title: Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis reveals he has rejected Â£44m bid for Jorginho from Manchester City
item.description: Manchester City's hopes of signing Jorginho appear to have taken a setback with Napoli presidentÂ Aurelio Di Laurentiis revealing he has rejected a Â£44million bid.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City's hopes of signing Napoli midfielder Jorginho appear to have taken a setback with the Italian club's presidentÂ Aurelio De Laurentiis revealing he has rejected a Â£44million bid.

The Premier League champions were hopeful of making the midfielder their first summer signing once Italy had played Holland in a friendly on Monday.

But in an interview withÂ Corriere dello Sport, De Laurentiis, renowned as a tough owner to deal with, insisted the Manchester club's bid was rejected out of hand.


'Jorginho? I have refused an offer from Man City worth â‚¬45m (Â£39m) plus â‚¬5m (Â£4.3m) in bonuses,' Di Laurentiis said.

The 26-year-old played a key part in Napoli's title challenge this season, though ultimately the Neopolitan side fell short of Juventus.

Jorginho is highly admired and technically gifted in the centre of the pitch and would give Pep Guardiola another strong option as he plots to win back-to-back league titles.

Given he is not going to the World Cup in Russia after Italy failed to qualify, it is a deal Guardiola is keen to wrap up early.

While Di Laurentiis is playing hardball over Jorginho, he accepted he is open to allowing captain Marek Hamisk leaving as links to China refuse to evaporate.

'If Hamsik wants to go to China, we won't stop him,' the owner added. 'But how much will they give?'

item.title: Chelsea's future looks bleak as former Blues chief executive who sold club to Roman Abramovich fears meltdown
item.description: Chelsea are facing life without a new stadium, top manager or star player if the row over Roman Abramovichâ€™s visa rumbles on, the clubâ€™s former chief executive claimed on Friday.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea are facing life without a new stadium, top manager or star player if the row over Roman Abramovichâ€™s visa rumbles on, the clubâ€™s former chief executive claimed on Friday.

Russian oligarch Abramovich put a stop to Chelseaâ€™s Â£1billion project to redevelop Stamford Bridge this week in retaliation for the treatment he has received at the hands of the Home Office after his UK visa expired.

Abramovich is now reported to have withdrawn his visa application. And Trevor Birch, the executive responsible for selling Chelsea to Abramovich in 2003, says the Russia diplomatic row risks throwing all of the clubâ€™s plans into turmoil.


On the field, leading player Eden Hazard has suggested he is not willing to sign a new contract before seeing who Chelsea sign in the summer. Goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois has made similar noises.

There is also uncertainty over the managerial situation, with Abramovich searching for a new boss despite going cold on Napoliâ€™s Maurizio Sarri.

Birch, who has also been chief executive at Everton and Leeds, told BBC Radio 4â€™s Today programme: â€˜If the visa issue isnâ€™t resolved, anything could happen.Â 

There have been rising costs in the stadium and itâ€™s a difficult project to deliver â€” but this is clearly Roman upping the ante in his spat with the Home Office.

â€˜Thereâ€™s obviously a great deal of concern around at the moment. The Chelsea fans face the prospect of no stadium, no manager and no star player if Eden Hazard moves to Real Madrid.â€™

Club sources are adamant that Abramovich is not looking to relinquish control of the club he has helped to five Premier League titles as well as glory in the Champions League.Â 

Birch says that, were the Russian looking to sell, he would not be short of suitors â€” provided investment in the squad increased on last year.

â€˜Itâ€™s eminently sellable as a club, based in west London,â€™ he said. â€˜With TV rights increasing, if Manchester United are valued at over Â£3billion, I think Chelsea are valued at Â£1.5billion â€” and very attractive. Of course to maintain the value of his (Abramovichâ€™s) investment he needs to invest in players â€” and he didnâ€™t last season.â€™

item.description: Chelsea are ready to revive their interest in Stoke City's Jack Butland should Thibaut Courtois leave this summer. The Blues are bracing themselves for a bid from Real Madrid.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea are ready to revive their interest in Stoke City's Jack Butland should Thibaut Courtois leave this summer.

The Stamford Bridge club are bracing themselves for an offer from Real Madrid after the European champions shortlisted the Chelsea number one and Roma's Alisson as their main targets.

Alisson is also on Chelsea's wish list while Liverpool are pushing to sign him too. That interest will help Roma drive up the asking price and, with ongoing concerns about what funds Israeli based owner Roman Abramovich will release, Chelsea may be forced to look at a more economic option.


Wary of Madrid and PSG interest in Courtois, Chelsea made enquiries for Butland earlier in the season and know he would cost considerably less than Alisson while having the added advantage of being English with Premier League experience.Â 

Stoke will reluctantly listen to offers for the 25-year old Butland but want a British record fee - outstripping the Â£30million Everton agreed to pay Sunderland for Jordan Pickford.

The two will contest the England number one role at this month's World Cup.

Wolves and West Ham have made tentative enquiries for Butland too but are also exploring other options with the Molineux club keen on Rui Patricio from Sporting Lisbon.

item.title: 'Someone send help!': Chelsea supporters in meltdown as fears over Roman Abramovich's future escalate club crisis... but rival fans are loving it
item.description: After romping to the Premier League title in 2017, Chelsea slumped to fifth and missed out on a place in next season's Champions League. There is so much uncertainty around the club.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea fans have taken to Twitter to express concern at a perceived club crisis... but many rival supporters appear to be loving it.

After romping to the Premier League title in 2017, the Blues slumped to fifth place and therefore missed out on a spot in next season's Champions League.

There is uncertainty about who will lead the first team going forward as manager Antonio Conte is set to be sacked later this month.


The future of Russian owner Roman Abramovich has also been called into question after the renewal of his UK visa was delayed.

That delay prompted plans for the development of Stamford Bridge to be put on hold, meaning the future of the club's home is also unsure.

Amid the mounting problems at Chelsea, Blues fan Younes H-Hamou used an amusing dog meme to mask his frustration.

Another supporter recoiled in horror after reading rumours that Avram Grant could be a potential candidate to replace Conte.

Meanwhile, one fan expressed his annoyance as Chelsea's reported reluctance to pay the required compensation to Napoli for manager Maurizio Sarri after paying Â£35million to sign midfielder Danny Drinkwater from Leicester last summer.

When you hear about Chelsea getting Sarri and being linked with Icardi + Mertens.. then find out the next day we canceled stadium plans and then read about the potential "crisis" pic.twitter.com/6SPRpxGrvv

â€” Feroze Ali (@feroze17) May 31, 2018

While Chelsea fans were despondent, many followers of rival clubs revelled in the problems at Stamford Bridge.

'Chelsea deserve to be in the absolute shambles they are at the moment,' wrote a Liverpool supporter.

A Manchester United fan added: 'Chelsea are falling apart daily. Their owner has been denied a visa, can't afford the new stadium, manager leaving with uncertainty over Sarri's release clause, no Champions League football and they're selling (Thibaut) Courtois.'

Tottenham fans were also keen to twist the knife, with one writing: 'Abramovic (sic) banned from working in UK. Chelsea cancel their new stadium build. Europa League group stages. Players despise the manager, manager hates his job. Took ten years and a few trophies, but the house of cards is coming gloriously down.'

item.title: The Royal Dyche! Pub sticks to early season promise and renames after Burnley boss Sean Dyche guided club to Europa League
item.description: Owners of the pub made headlines in November when they said they would rename the drinking haunt after Sean Dyche should he pull off a remarkable Europa finish. Against the odds, he did just that.
item.content:encoded:
Sean Dyche's reputation in Lancashire could hardly be higher right now. Having returned Burnley to the Premier League in 2015-16, the boss guided his unfancied side to a Europa League finish last season.

And for The Princess Royal pub in Burnley, a European finish ensured they had a promise to keep.

Owners of the pub made headlines in November when they said they would rename the drinking haunt after Dyche should he pull off a remarkable Europa finish. Against the odds, he did just that and the new sign was unveiled on Friday morning.Â 


The pub, located next to Turf Moor, has had a long-standing affinity with Dyche and wanted to offer an incentive beyond the free drinks deal he secured the previous year.Â Â 

Viral in November, the board outside the pub read: 'Sean, get us into Europa and not only will you drink here for free... we will name this pub The Dyche.'

Despite back-to-back defeats to Arsenal and Bournemouth to conclude the season, the Clarets secured a famous seventh-placed finish and will enter the 2018-19 Europa League at the second qualifying round.

Dyche and his players do not have long to wait until they know their opponents as the draw for the competition takes place in Nyon on June 19.

The club are currently on a short training camp in Ireland as they prepare for an early return for pre-season.Â 

But until then, Dyche can walk to work knowing he is eligible for a free drink in a self-titled pub.Â Â

item.title: 'Everyone will be excited by Marco Silva' says Phil Jagielka as Everton prepare for return to attacking football
item.description: Phil Jagielka has been canvassing opinion on new Everton boss Marco Silva and is excited by what he has heard. The Portuguese officially succeeded Sam Allardyce on Thursday,
item.content:encoded:
Phil Jagielka has been canvassing opinion on new Everton boss Marco Silva and is excited by what he has heard.

The Portuguese officially succeeded Sam Allardyce on Thursday, heralding what Everton hope will be brighter times ahead after the struggles of last season.

Silva's experience of the Premier League consists of short spells at Hull, where he could not prevent relegation, and Watford, who sacked him after accusing Everton of an 'unwarranted approach' last November.


Having failed to prise the 40-year-old away from Vicarage Road and turned to Allardyce, the Toffees have finally got their man seven months down the line.

Jagielka said on evertonfc.com: 'Everyone I've spoken to about him has said they've really enjoyed playing under him.

'I've got a few good friends at Watford and Hull and I haven't heard a bad word said about him. He's got high standards. He'll expect us to work hard and train hard - and he'll let us know exactly what he expects from us.

'I know the players and the fans will all get behind him. We have a new manager and new ideas and everyone will be super excited.

'He's obviously seen the potential and how much of a big club we are and that's why he wanted to come here. He's a young manager too. We have enjoyed having managers here for long periods in the past - it gives us solidity and I believe we can move forward in the years to come.'

Despite guiding Everton from the lower half of the table to an eighth-placed finish, Allardyce was the subject of protests from fans unhappy with the style of play.

Silva was keen to stress his commitment to entertainment in his first interview on Thursday, and Jagielka is looking forward to playing with freedom.

The Toffees captain said: 'That attacking brand is what the fans love to see here. If we can do that, and the results come too, everyone will be happy.

'You always look forward to those sorts of games where you're allowed to go and express yourself a little bit more. It is about doing it at the right time but also having a plan B and plan C, too.

'There will be a little bit of added pressure coming back with everyone needing to perform straightaway. That can only be a good thing. Everyone will be in the same boat. It'll be like the first day at school. We want to get to a good start next season and move the club forward.'

item.title: 'I think he will eventually leave Real Madrid to go back to England': Fabio Capello claims Cristiano Ronaldo wants Manchester United return to be reunited with boss Jose Mourinho
item.description: The Portugal star's future in the Spanish capital is in question after he spoke about playing for Real Madrid in the past tense in the immediate aftermath of their Champions League triumph last weekend.
item.content:encoded:
Fabio Capello has claimed Cristiano Ronaldo wants to return to Manchester United to reunite with Jose Mourinho.

The Portugal star's future in the Spanish capital is in question after he spoke about playing for Real Madrid in the past tense in the immediate aftermath of their Champions League triumph last weekend.

Zinedine Zidane, who departed Madrid on Thursday after two-and-a-half years at the helm, is understood to have wanted to explore the option of swapping Ronaldo for Paris Saint-Germain star Neymar after his comments, but the boardroom powerbrokers disagreed - something that may have fuelled his decision to quit.


PSG are still interested in Ronaldo, as are United, but former Madrid boss Capello believes the 33-year-old has only got his heart set on joining one club.

'Cristiano wants to return to Manchester United alongside Mourinho,' the Italian told Sky Sport 24. 'I think he will eventually leave Madrid to go back to England. When? This I don't know.'

The forward established a strong rapport with his countryman Mourinho during his spell with Madrid, and Capello clearly feels that could be enough to convince Ronaldo to return to his former club.

United executive vice chairman Ed Woodward has been desperate to sign the five-time Ballon d'Or winner ever since taking over the club's transfer strategy five years ago.Â 

Ronaldo has previously flirted with the idea of returning to United and his mother recently admitted she would prefer him to return to England than join PSG's star-studded squad.Â 

Â 'I like Paris,' she said. 'I come every now and again. The last time was when my son received the Ballon d'Or. It was a great honour. When I arrived I was treated well by everyone.

'Convince Cristiano to sign for PSG? To be honest, it wouldn't annoy me, but I would prefer him to return to Manchester United.'

item.title: Laurent Blanc Q&A: The Frenchman is a serious candidate to take over at Chelsea... but has he had success elsewhere and why has he been out of work for two years?
item.description: Former Paris Saint-Germain boss Laurent Blanc has emerged as a serious candidate to take over as Chelsea manager this summer. So, who is Blanc, and what can Chelsea fans expect?
item.content:encoded:
Former Paris Saint-Germain boss Laurent Blanc has emerged as a serious candidate to take over as Chelsea manager this summer.

The Blues are on the verge of changing manager for the 14th time in 15 years, if you include caretaker bosses, andÂ Blanc appears to be the man primed to follow Antonio Conte.

So, who is Blanc, and what can Chelsea fans expect if he is to succeed Conte at Stamford Bridge this summer?


Who is Laurent Blanc?

Blanc was a formidable defender in a playing career that saw him turn out for Montpellier, Napoli, Saint-Etienne, Barcelona, Inter Milan and Manchester United among others.

He has experience of English football after spending two seasons under Sir Alex Ferguson between 2001 and 2003. His stint at Old Trafford was very much in the twilight years though and, after helping United win the 2002/03 Premier League title, he called time on his playing career once his contract expired.

Blanc was also part of the French squad that won the 1998 World Cup on home soil. Nicknamed 'Le President' at Marseille because of his leadership strengths, Blanc was ruled out of the final against Brazil after being sent off in the last four against Croatia for slapping Slaven Bilic.

Â 

What has he done as a manager?

In his first job at Bordeaux Blanc not only won the league and cup double in his second season at the club, but also took them to the quarter-finals of the Champions League. It was Bordeaux's first league title in 10 years, and they haven't finished in the top four since his departure.

Then the French national team job came calling in 2010 following the scandal involving Raymond Domenech at the World Cup in South Africa. Blanc led his country to the quarter-finals of Euro 2012 where they were eventually beaten by Spain.

He was hired by PSG after Carlo Ancelotti departed for Real Madrid in 2013. Blanc left after three seasons in charge in June 2016 afterÂ the club managed to win Ligue 1 and the French Cup but failed to reach the Champions League semi-finals in his final year in charge.

Blanc won 11 trophies during his time in charge of PSG, and on two occasions won the domestic quadruple of Ligue 1, the French Cup, the League Cup and the French Super Cup.

Â 

Why is he out of work?

There is not one specific reason for Blanc being out of work for two years but his lack of Champions League success may concern the continent's top teams when they are inspecting the market.

At PSG he never made it past the quarter-final stage and, as we have seen with Unai Emery, domestic success will only please the Qatari owners for so long.Â 

Blanc has also admitted to being particularly picky when asked about potential jobs. He has said: 'I know I'm fussy, only a big club would interest me. If not, I'll face facts and think of something else.'

Â 

What can Chelsea expect?Â 

Blanc prefers to concentrate on his own team's set-up rather than tailoring his tactics to counterÂ the opposition's strengths.

There is a serious onus put on possession with Blanc's teams wanting to dominate the ball. His time at Barcelona as a player, although brief, has clearly had some significance on his coaching style. The defender spent just one campaign at the Nou Camp and signed on the day that Johan Cruyff was sacked.

Both PSG and Bordeaux boasted the highest possession in France with Blanc in charge while he also put his faith in a number of youngsters in Paris with Adrien Rabiot, Kingsley Coman and Presnel Kimpembe all integrated.

Â 

Is he any good in the transfer market?

It may be too difficult to judge given the riches he was afforded when in charge of PSG.

Edinson Cavani and Marquinhos, both crucial players at Parc des Princes now, were purchased in his first summer in charge while David Luiz and Angel Di Maria followed in the windows after.

Chelsea's absence in next season's Champions League may make it harder to lure players to Stamford Bridge this summer with a shake-up in terms of personnel needed after a disappointing campaign.Â 

Â 

What happened toÂ Maurizio Sarri?

Chelsea are expected to move into gear when director Marina Granovskaia returns from a break next week but Sarri no longer appears to be first choice to succeed Conte amid concerns about his past.

The situation with Sarri was already complicated by a Â£7million release clause at Napoli but Chelsea are now more alarmed by an exchange the Italian had with new Italy manager Roberto Mancini.

Mancini accused Sarri of hurling homophobic insults at him during a touchline row when he was Inter Milan boss. Sarri was fined â‚¬20,000 and banned for two Coppa Italia matches.Â 

At a time when Chelsea are dealing with historic abuse and racism claims, there is understandably no desire to appoint a controversial manager.Â Â

So, who is Blanc, and what can Chelsea fans expect if he is to succeed Conte at Stamford Bridge this summer?

item.title: Everton fan is jailed for attacking Lyon goalkeeper while carrying a CHILD during Europa League tie
item.description: A raging Everton fan who tried to attack Lyon players while holding a young child has been jailed for eight weeks. Michael Fitzpatrick, of Derby Square, Prescot, threw a punch seemingly towards Anthony Lopes.
item.content:encoded:
A raging Everton fan who tried to attack Lyon players while holding a young child has been jailed for eight weeks.

The incident happened during a Europa League game at Goodison Park between Everton and Lyon in October last year.

Everton player Ashley Williams appeared to shove Lyon goalkeeper Anthony Lopes into advertising boards during the Blues' 2-1 defeat.


Up to 20 players became involved in a pitchside bust-up before spectator Michael Fitzpatrick, of Derby Square, Prescot, threw a punch seemingly towards Lopes.

The 30-year-old pleaded guilty to a Section 39 or common assault, when he appeared at the Community Justice Centre in Bootle.

He was also given a six-year football banning order due to the serious aggravating factor of the assault taking place while holding a child.

In an interview with the Sunday People shortly after the incident, Fitzpatrick said: 'I was out of the police station inside half an hour with my solicitor. But I'm ashamed of what I've done. I already know. I'm not a f****** d***head.'

Superintendent Dave Charnock said after the court case: 'The majority of fans went to the game to enjoy it for what it was - a football match between two passionate clubs.

'The police will not tolerate the selfish and idiotic actions of a few attempting to spoil a game of football that the vast majority of people went along to enjoy.

'We will continue to work closely with all of our local clubs to make matches safe and enjoyable occasions for everyone, and ensure that we look to prosecute anyone who commits this type of behaviour.

'Fitzpatrick will now will have a criminal record and the consequences of this in the future could be significant.'

Callum McCready, 19, of Clock Face, St Helens, was also charged with a Section 39 assault in connection with the incident at Goodison and was given a caution.Â

item.description: Zidane quit as Real Madrid boss by calling a shock press conference on Thursday, saying: 'I'm not going to coach another team right now. I'm not looking for another team.'
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea are monitoring Zinedine Zidane's future as they step up the search for a new manager.Â 

Zidane quit as Real Madrid boss by calling a shock press conference on Thursday, saying: 'I'm not going to coach another team right now. I'm not looking for another team.'

But Chelsea are understood to be set to try to persuade Zidane to change his mind.


The Premier League club are in peril having still not sacked Antonio Conte with previous favourite Maurizio Sarri no longer thought to be in the running.Â 

Laurent Blanc is the latest contender but Chelsea will ask about the availability of Zidane.

The Stamford Bridge club are in a difficult place less than a fortnight after winning the FA Cup.

Since lifting what was their 15th major trophy under the ownership of Roman Abramovich, the club halted work on their new Â£1billion new stadium project and appeared to shelve plans to appoint Sarri as their new manager.

item.description: Having been relieved of his duties at the end of the season, Stuart Pearce made the shock admission on the ownership which is likely to anger the club's already disillusioned supporters.
item.content:encoded:
Stuart Pearce revealed he never met co-owner David Sullivan or vice-chairman Karen Brady during his seven-month spell at West Ham.

Pearce, who represented the Hammers as a player between 1999-2001, was recruited to be David Moyes' assistant in November as the club were steered clear of relegation.

But having been relieved of his duties at the end of the season along with Moyes, Pearce made the shock admission on the ownership which is likely to anger the club's already disillusioned supporters.Â Â 

'I never met Sullivan or Brady in the 7 months I was there' ï¿½ï¿½

Stuart Pearce reveals David Gold was the only #WHUFC owner he met during his time at club... âš’ï¸

ï¿½ï¿½ https://t.co/AYsRgJWZEr pic.twitter.com/NhlPEOjUpB

â€” The Alan Brazil Sports Breakfast (@SportsBreakfast) June 1, 2018

talkSPORT Privacy Policy

'I never met Mr Sullivan or Karen Brady in the seven months I was there. Never met them,' Pearce said on talkSPORT.Â 

'If I owned a football club or run any sort of organisation, I would like to think that I would make it my business to welcome new faces to the football club.Â 

'The working environment is the training ground so I've got to say, unless they decided that Mr Gold was the face of the board, and he was going to come down.Â Â 

'To be fair he is very personable, would come in every game, would pop into the dressing room, training ground or whatever.Â Â 

'I can't speak for David (Moyes) because he had dealings with them but I never met two of the three in the seven months I was there.'

Moyes was replaced by former Manchester City title-winning manager Manuel Pellegrini as he looks to lift the club up the table.

The Spaniard is on the brink of making Fulham right back Ryan Fredericks his first signing after the 25-year-old opted not to sign a new deal with the Cottagers following promotion to the Premier League.Â Â

item.title: Jurgen Klopp 'keen to bring Ousmane Dembele to Liverpool'... but may have to sell players to fund move with new goalkeeper top priority
item.description: Jurgen Klopp has already added Naby Keita and Fabinho to his ranks this summer, but he is far from done as he attempts to land Ousmane Dembele. A deal could be done if both parties agree to a loan.
item.content:encoded:
Jurgen Klopp has already added Naby Keita and Fabinho to his ranks this summer, but he is far from done as he attempts to land Ousmane Dembele.

A deal could be done if Barcelona and Dembele are willing to agree to a loan, with Liverpool unable to afford a move to buy the Frenchman if they keep Mohamed Salah.

They are also prioritising the signing of a goalkeeper but all their current targets will command significant fees.

Klopp is determined to add the former Borussia Dortmund man to his attacking options, according to Spanish newspaper Mundo.Â 

But behind the scenes, Liverpool are less keen. They are unwilling to spend the Â£88m it would take to bring him to Anfield. They fear the only way a deal could be funded would be through selling Salah.


Meanwhile, Dembele would prefer a permanent move. He wants assurances and guarantees over his future.Â 

Klopp will speak to the 21-year-old's mother in a bid to get her on side about a move to England, which he believes will be mutually beneficial.Â 

Dembele has enjoyed a slower start to life at the Nou Camp than he would have envisaged, having missed 27 games through injury last season.

He joined Barcelona from Dortmund last summer on a deal worth around Â£98m but potentially rising to Â£135m.Â 

With the addition of Philippe Coutinho in the January window and a deal to bring Antoine Griezmann in from Atletico Madrid looking likely, Dembele's place in the first-team looks under serious threat.

Klopp likes the player because of his pace, ability to keep wide and take players on one-on-one. He is said to be looking for alternative options to his current front-three, who are lacking in quality back-up.

But Liverpool are also looking to strengthen the goalkeeper position after a string of blunders from Loris Karius and Simon Mignolet.Â 

Karius made two howlers in the Champions League final that cost them a real shot at taking the title.

Liverpool have been linked with Barcelone number two, Jasper Cillessen, who featured in their Copa del Rey run but only twice in the league and Champions League.Â 

They are also currently looking at Roma's Alisson, Atletico's Jan Oblak and Milan'sÂ Gianluigi Donnarumma, but these will cost above Â£60m as Liverpool look to continue their summer spending spree.

They are also prioritising the signing of a goalkeeper but all their current targets will command significant fees.

item.title: Ryan Fredericks on brink of joining West Ham on free transfer to become first signing for boss Manuel Pellegrini
item.description: Ryan Fredericks is on the brink of joining West Ham on a free transfer after an impressive campaign with play-off winners Fulham and will be Manuel Pellegrini's first signing since taking charge.
item.content:encoded:
Ryan Fredericks is on the brink of joining West Ham on a free transfer after an impressive campaign with play-off winners Fulham.

The 25-year-old right-back will become Manuel Pellegrini's first signing as the new West Ham manager looks to bring in a number of transfer targets quickly.

Fulham looked to keep hold of the defender after Premier League interest from Crystal Palace and Newcastle but he looks set to swap west LondonÂ for east London ahead of the new campaign.Â 

He was a regular for Slavisa Jokanovic's men in 2017-18, playing 48 times for the Cottagers.

Fulham defeated Aston Villa 1-0 in the play-off final at Wembley on Saturday to seal a return to the Premier League after four seasons away from the top tier.

Villa felt Fredericks could have been sent off after a first-half tangle with Jack Grealish but it was Fulham who eventually emerged victorious thanks to a 23rd minute goal from Tom Cairney.

item.title: Wolves complete Â£22m double signing of Willy Boly and Benik Afobe after the duo enjoyed successful loan spells
item.description: Wolves have completed a Â£22million double signing of Benik Afobe and Willy Boly, who had both been on loan at Molineux last season.
item.content:encoded:
Wolves have completed a Â£22million double signing of Benik Afobe and Willy Boly, who had both been on loan at Molineux last season.

Afobe has passed his medical with the club ahead of completing his transfer while French defender Boly, 27, has signed for Â£10m from Porto.Â 

Afobe left Wolves for Bournemouth in January 2016 for a fee in the region of Â£10million, though found his opportunities limited for Eddie Howe's side.Â Â 

In February Wolves secured a deal to take the Leyton-born forward back on loan until the end of the 2017/18 season.

Afobe impressed as Wolves secured promotion back into the top flight of English football.


The former Arsenal forward scored 23 goals in 48 appearances during his first spell at Molineux.

Upon his return Afobe struckÂ six goals in 16 league games for the Championship winners.

As part of the loan deal Wolves inserted an option to buy at the end of the campaign, a clause which they will now look to activate.

The striker looks set to make his return for a fee in the region of Â£12.5m, according to reports.

Nuno Espirito Santo's side are currently on a recruitment drive ahead of their return to the big time.

The club have this week been linked with Sporting Lisbon goalkeeper Rui Patricio, who is also wanted by Napoli as a replacement for the departing Pepe Reina.

item.title: Chelsea 'offered Gonzalo Higuain' as Juventus step up effort to bring striker Alvaro Morata back to Serie A
item.description: Chelsea have been offered the opportunity to buy Gonzalo Higuain as part of a plan by Juventus to bring Alvaro Morata back to Serie A, according to reports.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea have been offered the opportunity to buy Gonzalo Higuain as part of a plan by Juventus to bring Alvaro Morata back to Serie A, according to reports.

Juventus are keen to secure the services of the striker once more, and are considering how to tempt Chelsea to part with their Â£75million record signing.

Morata only arrived at Stamford Bridge last summer, signed by Antonio Conte to replace Diego Costa and lead the line following a successful season prior which ended in Premier League glory.

Despite a strong start in English football, things soon went sour for Morata with an injury-hit season preventing him from hitting consistent form.

The 25-year-old lost his place in Spain's World Cup squad as a result but may now be offered a lifeline by his former club, as report the Evening Standard.


Morata spent a successful spell in Turin from 2014-16, before returning back to his former club Real Madrid who activated a buy-back clause.

Juve are believed to be keen to have Morata leading their line once more, though must get 30-year-old Higuain off the wage bill first.

Higuain,Â who has scored 55 goals since joining from Napoli for Â£78million in 2016, earns Â£125,000-a-week at the club.

Morata signed a five-year deal with Chelsea last summer, though was seen talking to Juventus sporting director Fabio Paratici last week.

Chelsea would seek to replace Morata should the striker be allowed to leave for Italy, and have been heavily linked with a move for Bayern Munich forward Robert Lewandowski.

The Poland star is said to be looking for a new challenge this summer after his agent told the club of his desire to move on.
